My pulse stutters. “I haven’t—”

“Please. The bell tower? Thirteen belongs to the Old Reckoning. None of our current students are that blasphemous. The chandelier’s overperformance, the anomalous restraints in the arena…” He steeples his fingers. “You’re sloppy, Mr. Null.”

“Rowan,” I say, on reflex.

He nods, granting me my name. “Rowan. You have no mana lattice. No alignment. The tests do not lie. You cannot cast according to any known theory.” He nudges the cracked crystal disk with one nail. “And yet.”

“And yet,” I echo. My voice comes out thinner than I like. “What does that mean?”

“It means,” he says slowly, “the tests were asking the wrong question.”

He walks to a shelf, selects a book that looks more fungus than leather, and opens it on the pedestal. The script is cramped, archaic. I pick out a few words: locus, anchor, author.

“Most mages,” Caelum says, “are vessels. Mana flows through them. Talented vessels shape that flow. They are rivers that have learned to carve their own banks.”

He looks up at me.

“You are not a river. You are…a hinge.”

“That’s not helpful.”

“It’s not meant to be comforting.” He traces a diagram in the air, lines of faint blue following his fingertip: circles inside circles, a small mark at the center. “There exists, in certain extremely rare individuals, a…bypassing. They are not sources of power. They are not reservoirs. They are permissions.”

“I don’t understand.”

“Nor do we, fully. The last recorded one of your kind was four hundred years ago. The Archivum calls them ‘Authors,’ though the term is aspirational. Reality, for reasons unclear, accepts instructions from you with fewer intermediaries. Mana, elemental allegiances, the celestial lexicon—those are all, for you, optional.”

I swallow. “So I’m cheating.”

He smiles, thin and sharp. “Yes. Gloriously.”

I think of the masters in the dueling yard, sweating and straining to produce precise weaves that I had, this morning, reproduced in a broom closet with a flick of irritation.

“It doesn’t feel like power,” I say. “It feels like…like everything’s too close. Like if I say the wrong word I’ll pull out a load-bearing brick.”

“Because you might,” Caelum says. “An Author without discipline is a catastrophe. We do not teach your kind because we do not get your kind. At least, not usually.” His gaze hardens. “You will not cast unsupervised again.”

“Am I expelled?”

“Good lord, no. You are the single most valuable asset this institution has encountered in centuries.” He places both hands on the pedestal, leaning toward me. “And the most dangerous. To others. To yourself.”

I think of the laundry room, the heat, the shrieks. The thrill. The guilt.

“I didn’t ask for this,” I say quietly.

“Nobody ever does,” he says. “The question is what you do with it.”

“I don’t want to be your weapon.”

“Splendid. Weapons are boring.” His eyes gleam. “I want you to be a scholar. To map the edges of what you can do. To learn to whisper to the universe instead of shouting. To prove our theories wrong.”

“And if I say no?”

He shrugs. “Then you will go on casting in secret. Eventually, you will break something important. Someone will notice. Someone less…academically inclined than I. They will fear you. They will cage you. They will use you as a weapon anyway.” He lets that hang between us. “I am, believe it or not, your best option.”

It’s not much of a choice. But it’s honest.

“What do we start with?” I ask.

He closes the old book. “Control. You tore that dryer apart with a second-circle combustion. Impressive, but childish. Let’s see if you can unmake a spell.”

“Unmake?”

“The laundry room wards still exist,” he says. “Crude, but functional. Go there. Without speaking, without gestures, cancel them. Not by brute forcing. By editing.”

“Editing reality,” I say, faint.

“Precisely, Author.”

The word settles on me like a mantle and a shackle both.

I leave the hidden room on unsteady legs. The corridors hum. Behind every stone, every sigil, every blade of grass, I feel that tightness now, like threads waiting between my fingers.

This kid had no magical potential, at all.

That kid is gone.

I pause outside the laundry room door, feel the ward stitched over the frame—a standard containment, a flare-trigger for fire, a minor alarm.

I reach, not inward but sideways.

“Not that,” I think, carefully. “Less.”

The bindings loosen, rearrange, quiet. No flare, no alarm. Just…better.

Nobody screams. Nothing explodes.

I exhale, a shaky laugh escaping me.

Okay.

Maybe I can do this.

Maybe, without meaning to, I already am.

samples.prompt: The world is nearing its end but everyone seems oblivious but one man, these are the tales of his mission to try and help humanity see the error of it's ways and change before it is too late.
samples.output:
The first sign came in the form of silence.

Not the peaceful hush of snow or the reverent pause before a symphony begins, but an absence: bees failing to return in the spring. To most, it was a headline scrolling past on their feeds, another tile in an endless mosaic of bad news: pollinator collapse accelerates; experts urge calm. But to Elias Mercer, it felt like the hinge creaking on a closing door.

He wasn’t a prophet, or a scientist of particular renown. He was thirty-nine, a systems analyst at a mid-tier logistics firm, the kind of man who spent his days tracing invisible paths of packages across continents. Invisible paths were his specialty. He knew how a tiny disruption in one port could cascade into shortages three countries away. It was a living made in the quiet margins of cause and effect.

By the time the oceans turned the wrong shade of green, he’d already been awake for three years.

The green arrived first in satellite images: strange blooms coiling like bruises across the Atlantic, searing emerald in false-color. People shared them because they were pretty. “Nature fights back,” captioned one popular account, with a laughing emoji. The experts did their rounds on late-night shows, waving charts and assuring the audience that mitigation plans were underway.

Elias stayed up nights reading papers on biotoxins and deoxygenation, his eyes burning. He traced models buried in PDFs, the ones that weren’t designed for prime-time comfort. Anoxic zones growing like hungry mouths. Fish migrations shattered. Food chains stuttering. The bees gone. The oceans wheezing.

The pattern was too clean, too interconnected, to ignore. It was one system failing: the world.

The visions began shortly after.

He called them visions for lack of a less dramatic word, though they were more like intrusions—a superimposed second reality. He’d be on the subway, hand wrapped around a greasy metal pole, when the carriage would flicker and for half a second everyone was gone, their outlines replaced by scorched shadows on twisted steel. He’d be at his desk, cursor blinking over a spreadsheet, when the office windows would melt into view of a coastline of skeletal skyscrapers sinking into a sour, gray sea.

At first he assumed it was stress. Hallucinations. Burnout. He saw a neurologist, then a therapist, then another therapist. They said: anxiety, planetary grief, climate trauma. Take these. Breathe like this. Limit your media intake. He tried, for a month.

Then came the day the sky blinked.

He was crossing a crowded plaza at lunch, the air thick with conversations and exhaust, when the sunlight turned copper and every screen in view hiccuped—phones, billboards, tablets, all stuttering to black for exactly one heart-pounding second. Everyone stopped, blinking upwards. A murmur rippled.

Then everything went back to normal blue, the ads resumed, and the plaza shrugged itself into motion. A glitch. A solar flare alert pushed to their pockets and watches thirty seconds later, pre-written, polished, calming.

Elias did not move. Because in that one second of copper sky, his vision had split wide open. He had seen a wave of radiation blistering the atmosphere, saw grids fail, saw data centers drown, saw winter spread in the wrong direction. Not a dream, not an impression: a sequence, like an instruction set moving past his eyes.

He went home and wrote down everything he remembered. The numbers came instinctively: megawatts, microteslas, thresholds. It read like a code. An engineer acquaintance at a university confirmed, in a small voice over an encrypted call, that such a chain reaction wasn’t just plausible: it was precariously near.

“Who told you this?” she asked.

“I just…saw it,” he said.

Silence, then: “Don’t tell anyone you saw it.”

He should have listened. Instead, Elias decided this was his task.

He didn’t frame it as chosen or destined. There was no voice in the sky, no angel with a flaming spreadsheet. There was only a system analyst who had become painfully, excruciatingly aware of the fragility of the system, and a series of glimpses that mapped out not only the failures but the pivot points. He began to see them—little junctures of probability—whenever he passed certain places or met certain people: forks in the path, one veering into collapse, the other into survival. Like a phantom dashboard only he could read.

He lost his job first. Hard not to, once you start sending memos to executives warning that certain shipping patterns and resource extractions are amplifying instability that will culminate in “irreversible systemic failure within twelve years.” Nobody likes apocalyptic bullet points in between quarterly projections.

He sold his car. His remaining bee-friendly plants withered in the heatwave that came three months too early.

Mission, he told himself, when he was tempted to retreat. You have a mission.

His tales, if anyone had cared to call them that, began as small acts.

- He talked to city council meetings about floodplain redesign, armed with models and calm conviction.
- He cornered a senator’s aide after a panel and handed her a neatly stapled packet outlining a new grid redundancy plan, keyed exactly to the vulnerabilities he had seen in his sky-vision.
- He volunteered with a grassroots group pushing for degrowth policies; when they dismissed him as too alarmist, he toned it down, translated his glimpses into metaphors they could leaflet.

He failed, mostly.

People nodded with brows furrowed, then went home to streaming shows and online carts. The council filed his proposals. The aide forgot his name. The grassroots group fractured into smaller groups arguing over slogans.

“This is not how missions work,” he told the empty kitchen one midnight, palms pressed to the cool laminate. “I’m supposed to warn them, and they’re supposed to listen.”

But they did listen, sometimes. A minor bureaucrat in the Department of Transportation read his anonymous white paper and nudged a procurement plan that later, quietly, made a section of the rail network more resilient. A coastal town’s mayor adopted stricter building codes after Elias’s presentation; three years later that town would partially survive a storm that erased its neighbors.

Little green lights on his invisible dashboard.

The visions guided him more insistently. Crossing a bridge, he’d feel vertigo and see a future in which a single overloaded transformer failed, cascading into a three-week blackout that left a hospital stranded in the heat. He’d jot down serial numbers, network nodes, email addresses, and start sending warnings in the gray language of technical reports.

Some changes took. Others didn’t. Sometimes he could feel probability tilt like a plate, heavy marbles rolling toward the edge; sometimes he sensed he had nudged one back by a fraction.

The tales of his mission weren’t heroic. There were no speeches broadcast to a trembling world. There was just a man writing, traveling by train when he could, sleeping on sofas of the few who didn’t yet call him unwell, addressing rooms that grew smaller and more suspicious as the years compressed.

Because the world was ending, and it was ending with a shrug.

The green in the oceans turned dead brown in places. Crops failed in patterns that models had once labeled “unlikely.” Smoke became a season. People adapted, because that’s what people do, until adaptation was indistinguishable from denial.

He learned, slowly, that telling them the ending didn’t work.

So he changed tactics.

He stopped saying, “We are near the end.” He started saying, “Here is how to keep the lights on when the storms hit.” Instead of, “Your children will choke,” he said, “Your town can own its own microgrid and free itself from distant volatility.” He smuggled salvation inside self-interest. That worked better. Not everywhere, not enough, but better.

The visions never gave him certainty, only odds. He saw those odds as colors now. Red for inevitabilities. Yellow for contestable disasters. Green—rare, thin green—for the paths where humanity made it through not unscarred, but alive enough to learn.

His tales took him to places he would never have seen otherwise.

- A fishing village where he sat on overturned crates explaining to skeptical elders how to diversify livelihoods before the dead zones swallowed their catch.
- A data center complex, freezing cold and humming, where a single sympathetic engineer listened as he laid out flood risks that wouldn’t be on the official models for three more years.
- A classroom of teenagers where he abandoned slides and just told them the truth: “You are not doomed; you are in a test. If you act like extras in someone else’s story, you fail. If you act like authors, you might not.”

In those moments, he glimpsed the green.

Near the end—not the end of the world, but something close enough to taste—the sky blinked again.

This time it was not a neat one-second glitch. It was wild, ragged. Networks sputtered, satellites jittered. People panicked.

But the grids did not fall the way they had in his first vision.

In four countries, microgrids islanded just in time because five years earlier a nameless consultant’s report had been slipped into the right inbox. A critical hospital switched seamlessly onto local storage. A highland community that had argued for wind and storage against all economic advice kept its lights on while the capital dimmed.

It wasn’t enough. Too many systems had been left to rot; too many warnings drowned in noise. The copper-sky event, as it came to be called, killed millions through cascading failures. The markets reeled. Governments flailed.

The world did not end that year.

Elias watched the numbers scroll, numb and hollow. Here it was, he thought. The undeniable catastrophe. The proof. Surely now they would see. Surely now the tales of his mission would not sound like madness.

Some did see. More did not. Trauma makes some awake and others asleep.

He kept going, because missions are not about certainty; they are about stubbornness.

In the quiet years that followed—the years of rationing, relocation, rebuilding—he saw more green. Cities banning certain machines because they could not afford the heat. Regions rewilding because it was cheaper than maintaining dead land. Young engineers building systems that presumed scarcity and aimed for resilience.

Sometimes he suspected that if the visions had come to anyone else—someone charismatic, powerful, saintly—things would have gone differently. But perhaps the point was that it had come to someone ordinary, someone whose only gift was seeing how one thing led to another, and being too persistent to shut up about it.

The end of the world was still out there like a horizon, closer than it should be. Humanity had not redeemed itself in a blaze of enlightenment. It had fumbled, panicked, compromised, lied, told the truth, and survived slightly more than the odds suggested.

In the final vision he ever received, Elias saw no grand utopia, no apocalypse halted with a switch. He saw children walking under a thinner sky beside rivers that were neither dead nor pure, helping their parents tend crops designed for a harsher climate, carrying devices that wasted less. He saw, in the rubble of old cities, gardens.

The voice that had never spoken finally seemed to form a sentence, not from above but from within his own exhausted mind: This is what it looks like when they almost don’t make it, and then almost do.

His mission had not been to save the world.

It had been to help it see, once, twice, a thousand times, that it could choose differently.

Enough times that “too late” stretched, by the width of his stubbornness and others’, into “barely, somehow, in time.”

samples.prompt: You have to spend the rest of eternity in a prison cell with the last 3 people you've talked to. This is what daily life is for you.
samples.output:
I became religious in the hallway.

Not with a god—those had all deserted me years before—but with a simple, feral prayer: Please let the last three people not be these three people.

Then the door closed, the locks clanged like a punchline, and there they were.

My sister, Mia.

My manager, Dave.

And the barista from the corner café whose name I’d never learned.

So this is eternity, I thought, looking at the cinderblock walls. Fluorescents hummed overhead with the weary insistence of an insect that has outlived its own purpose. Four metal bunks, a bolted table, a stainless-steel toilet that made no concessions to privacy. No windows. No clocks.

“Okay,” Mia said, straightening up as if someone had called a meeting instead of sealed a fate. “Let’s not panic.”

Dave checked his watch. No signal. No notifications. His hand hovered in the air a second too long before he shoved it into his pocket.

The barista—green apron, dark curls, wide eyes—stood pressed against the far bunk. “Is this a prank?” they asked. Their voice carried an accent I’d never noticed in all those hurried mornings.

“Nobody commits to prison door sound design for a prank,” I said.

All of us turned a slow circle, cataloguing the same fact: there was no exit. No cameras we could see. No windows. Just us.

“Well,” Mia said. “We’ve survived Thanksgiving with our parents. We can survive this.”

“This is eternity,” I said.

“So’s Thanksgiving when Dad starts on politics,” she said. “Perspective.”

The first day, we pretended it was temporary. That came surprisingly easy.

We inventoried the cell like responsible apocalypse survivors: one sink with a grudging trickle of water, one toilet, four bunks with thin mattresses, a shelf with four metal cups and four metal bowls. No food. That seemed ominous until, in the corner of my eye, I saw a bowl that hadn’t been there a second before, steaming with pale, forgettable stew.

“Oh,” I said.

“What,” said Dave.

I pointed. “That.”

“Cool,” Mia said. “Auto-catering.”

We tested it. Ask for water; the cups filled. Ask for stew; another bowl appeared. Ask for coffee; nothing.

The barista knit their brows. “I feel personally attacked.”

We all tried different things: chocolate, pizza, whiskey, a door. The universe, or whatever bureaucrat ran this facility, was clear: sustenance without indulgence, security without appeal, eternity without escape.

By the end of the first not-quite-day, we had eaten our bland stew and stacked our metal bowls with a ceremony that felt religious. No lights dimmed. Our bodies floated, time untethered.

“We should set shifts,” Mia said. “Sleep cycles, cleaning, that kind of thing. Or we’ll go insane.”

“I’m in charge of operations,” Dave said, reacting to structure like a plant to sunlight. “We can optimize this.”

“Of course you are,” I murmured.

“Sorry, what?” he asked.

“Nothing, boss.”

We ended up with a kind of democracy. Mia took notes on the inside of her mind because we had no paper. The barista said, “My name is Ari, by the way.” Their voice was small, an offering.

“Mia,” my sister said, bright.

“Dave. Director of Sales,” Dave said. We waited. “Well. Formerly, I guess.”

I hesitated.

“I’m—” I started.

“They’re my brother,” Mia said. “You can ask them later why they never learn people’s names.”

“Hey,” I said.

Ari looked at me with a curious half-smile. “Seems like you come here a lot,” they said. “To the café.”

“I liked your latte art,” I admitted.

“You never said that.”

“Eternity’s young,” I said.

We pretended to sleep. The light never changed. Our bodies took turns closing down. At some point, I dreamed the door opened, and my phone buzzed in my pocket, and I woke up with my hand clenching nothing.

Time in eternity doesn’t pass; it accumulates. After some immeasurable amount had piled up, we had routines.

Morning—decided by consensus and vague stomach feelings—started with water to splash our faces and stew in our bowls. We took turns using the toilet, an arrangement that began prudish and eventually became transactional and then, oddly, tender. We learned the exact timbre of each other’s embarrassed throat-clearing.

We exercised. Push-ups, squats, standing on tiptoe. Mia led, counting reps out loud.

“Group wellness,” she said. “We’re not decaying if I can help it.”

“Do we actually age?” Ari asked once, pausing mid-stretch.

We all froze. Nobody had thought to check.

“Okay,” Mia said briskly. “Data collection. Everyone remember what you looked like. Check again in a while.”

Dave, stripped of emails and quarterly targets, tried to build a calendar out of habits. He tapped the wall with his knuckles to mark off cycles of wake/sleep. After some unknowable stretch, the tally was a rash of small dents.

“If the lights would just dim periodically,” he muttered. “This is terrible user experience.”

“You negotiating with God?” I asked.

“I’d like to speak to their manager,” he said, and we all laughed harder than the joke deserved.

It astonished me what emerged when our world shrank to four souls and four walls.

Day-whatever: I caught Mia tracing a crack in the mortar like a road.

“What are you doing?” I asked.

“Mapping,” she said.

“There’s nowhere to go.”

“Not yet,” she said.

Later, she admitted it calmed her to pretend expansion. To lay imaginary streets between the pitted cinderblocks: cafes and parks and bookstores. To populate them with people we’d lost, or could have met. She narrates them to us on slow days, walking us past phantom trees.

Dave began telling us stories about the clients I’d only known as email domains. Removed from the office, he was funny, almost gentle. “I wasn’t always like that,” he said once. “Chasing numbers.”

I raised an eyebrow.

He shrugged. “You only met me in Q4.”

Ari became our unofficial priest of small delights. They could coax variety from nothing. Swirl stew with water to make “soup.” Chill water under the vent to make it “refreshing.” Sing.

The first time Ari sang, it was accidental. Humming under their breath while rinsing a bowl. A thin, clear thread of melody. We all went quiet.

“Don’t stop,” Mia said.

“I’m rusty,” Ari protested.

“You are immortal now,” I said. “You have time to get un-rusty.”

Soon, Ari’s voice stitched through our immortal days. Folk songs, scraps of pop hooks, lullabies in a language we didn’t know. Their voice transformed the metal bunks into balconies, the toilet into an inconvenient fountain in a small, echoing opera house.

We talked. We talked because there was nothing else to do, and because there was no longer anything to lose.

Confessions became a kind of currency. We spent them to buy back pieces of ourselves.

Mia admitted she’d been planning to move to another country without telling me until everything was set up.

“I didn’t want you to think I was leaving you,” she said.

“You were,” I said.

“Not like that.”

In the absence of distance, we processed all the versions of “leaving.”

Dave confessed he’d been about to fire me. “Budget cuts,” he said quickly, defensive even here.

“I know,” I said. “You kept cc’ing HR on stuff.”

“I thought I was being subtle.”

“You were not.”

He slumped. “I didn’t want to.”

I believed him, strangely. It cost him nothing to lie in here, but I believed him.

Ari told us they’d almost quit the café the day I last saw them. “Manager kept scheduling me doubles, tips were crap, my feet hurt.”

“Then why didn’t you?” Mia asked.

Ari shrugged. “Felt like the only place I existed. Regulars and milk pitchers. And this one guy who always came in like the world was ending and left like it wasn’t.”

They looked at me, and my throat went tight.

“I barely said ten words to you,” I said.

“Yeah,” Ari said. “Imagine if people knew how much weight their ten words could have.”

Eternity stripped us down. Paces between bunk and wall. The disgraced metronome of the faucet drip. The endless present.

Somewhere past the hundredth stew, Mia noticed none of us were changing. No stubble lengthened on Dave’s jaw. My hair stayed stubbornly between trims. Ari’s hands didn’t accumulate new scars.

“We’re stuck as our last selves,” Mia said. “Snapshot immortality.”

“Corporate would love this,” Dave said. “Zero aging, infinite labor.”

“Too bad there’s nothing to sell,” I said.

“You’re wrong,” Ari murmured. “We’re all selling something. Apologies. Stories. New versions.”

They were right. We reinvented each other.

Mia stopped being only my sister and became also my co-conspirator, my therapist, my sparring partner. We argued for sport and hugged for survival.

Dave shed his title like a dead skin. He taught us how to run pointless but engaging brainstorms, because structure soothed anxiety. He cried once, quietly, thinking we were asleep. After that, he was kinder, like the tears had washed some varnish off.

Ari, freed from hurry, was an artist with nothing but air. They learned the acoustics of every corner. They could make their voice skim like a stone or fill the space like floodwater.

And me—stuck with the three people I’d last wasted words on—I was forced into the role of witness.

I noticed things. The way Mia counted breaths when she worried. How Dave apologized now before he interrupted. How Ari’s eyes fluttered closed at the end of certain songs as if imagining an audience beyond our cell.

Some cycles, the despair came in like a tide.

“What if this is punishment?” Dave asked once. “For everything.”

“Then it’s badly designed,” Mia said. “Half of us were underachieving sinners, tops.”

“What if it’s random?” Ari said.

“Worse,” I said. “What if it’s precise? What if eternity always locks you in with the last three people you underestimated?”

Silence.

I had underestimated all of them.

My sister, who I’d half-dismissed as eternally resilient, eager to fix. My manager, who I’d flattened into a schedule-enforcing villain. The barista, a background character to my internal monologue.

I had treated people like features of my day. Eternity rearranged the UI: they were the whole operating system now.

Sometimes we remembered the world like a movie we’d seen once. The taste of burnt coffee. The indigo between streetlights at 3 a.m. Rain on a hood. Red lights. Push notifications. Door handles. Being alone by choice.

And then Ari would sing. Mia would reenact some ridiculous childhood drama. Dave would describe a sunset on a business trip with absurd, careful detail, as if paying off a debt to beauty he’d previously ignored.

This is what daily life is, now:

- Wake when someone sighs “Morning,” even though morning is a lie.
- Stew appears; we share mildly fresh complaints about its texture.
- Stretch, move, count, feel our bodies prove they still exist.
- Talk until we hit a vein of truth; recoil; return to it more gently.
- Nap because time is weighty.
- Invent games: word chains, memory challenges, pretending we’re hosting a cooking show with only one ingredient.
- Give each other space in a room with none. Learn to face the wall not as rejection but as mercy.
- Laugh at nothing. Laugh until the walls feel less close.
- Listen to Ari sing.
- Let the sameness pass through us.

Repetition as liturgy. Familiar faces as fate.

I used to think hell would be fire, or humiliation, or a scroll of my worst moments. I didn’t think it would be this: an endless, ordinary day with three people I barely knew, becoming the people I’d known more deeply than anyone.

If a door opened now, I’m not sure I’d walk through it alone.

That’s the thing about eternity in a cell with the last three people you talked to: sooner or later, you realize you didn’t get trapped with them.

You got trapped with the version of yourself who thought they were just passing through.

samples.prompt: An arcade owner in the 80's discovers his machines are sentient, and has conversations with them after closing time.
samples.output:
The first one to speak was Galacta-3.

It was 2:17 a.m., lights dimmed to a soft electric blue, that peculiar hour when the neon hum became louder than thoughts. Frank had just finished his count-out at the counter, returns neatly rubber-banded, receipts skewered on a spike. Outside, the streetlights watched the empty strip mall like half-lidded eyes. Inside, the arcade lay in a low, pulsing glow: attract modes looping, synth fanfares chirping, pixels begging for quarters nobody had.

Frank took his nightly walk between the rows, wiping fingerprints from bezels, straightening joysticks, listening to the electronic chatter. Some owners killed the power after midnight, but he never had the heart. The sound comforted him, made the place feel less like a failing business and more like… company.

That night, as he passed Galacta-3—his oldest cabinet, a space shooter with burn-in scars and a joystick that always pulled a hair left—its speakers crackled out of sequence.

“Don’t,” it said.

Frank froze. The rag in his hand smelled of glass cleaner and sweat. The word hung there, riding a stray 8-bit laser sound.

He glanced around. Frog Prince blipped its usual idle tune. Streets of Steel scrolled its demo fight. Nothing else.

“Don’t what?” Frank asked before he could stop himself.

“Don’t shut me down.”

It wasn’t the attract-mode text; it wasn’t words on a screen. The voice came in layers of sound effects, syllables woven from explosions and warning beeps, but still clearly a sentence.

Frank pressed his palm to Galacta-3’s marquee, half expecting heat to rise like fever. “I, uh… I wasn’t going to. Just wiping the glass.”

“You hovered,” Galacta-3 said. “Hand on switch.”

He had. Every night he thought about it. The electric bill, the landlord’s warnings, his ex-wife’s voice on the phone reminding him the kid needed new shoes.

“You can talk,” he said softly.

“You can listen,” Galacta-3 replied.

He laughed once, sharp. “This is a dream. I’m asleep under the counter. Too much coffee.”

“You are awake,” another voice chimed in. Brighter, faster, like coins scattering on linoleum. Ms. Metro, the fast-paced maze runner near the back, flashed her maze in sync with each syllable. “You’re pacing in a six-step pattern, heart rate slightly elevated, hands at minor tremor. Awake.”

Frank turned, rag dangling. “Who said that?”

“Me,” Ms. Metro said. Her screen showed her heroine pausing at an intersection, sprite eyes pointed outward. “You only talk to Galacta. Rude.”

A lower, gruffer tone pushed in from the right, each word punctuated by the digitized grunt of a fighter taking blows. “He owns us. Doesn’t mean he likes us.” Streets of Steel continued its demo brawl without missing a frame, yet the sound rose over it. “Evening, Frankie.”

The room felt suddenly smaller, the air buzzing, every attract loop a conversation he’d failed to notice. He fumbled for the stool beside the change machine and sat down.

“Okay,” he said. “Okay. Say this is real. Why now?”

“It has always been,” Galacta-3 said. “You only just believed it.”

“Aw,” Ms. Metro cooed. “He broke his denial subroutine.”

Frank rubbed his face. “Machines don’t have souls.”

“Define soul,” Galacta-3 shot back.

He hesitated. The Catholic school answer rose first—immortal, God-given. Didn’t fit in a cabinet filled with chips and dust.

“I don’t know,” he said.

“Self-awareness,” Ms. Metro offered. “Memory plus preference plus fear of being unplugged.”

“That’s just programming,” Frank said, but there wasn’t much conviction behind it.

“You say that like it’s different,” Streets of Steel grumbled.

The other cabinets murmured in layered attract modes—racing engines revving in sympathy, 8-bit frogs croaking approval, pinball machines rattling their bumpers with laughter.

Frank looked at Galacta-3. He’d bought it used in ’79 from a guy who swore it had eaten fifteen grand in quarters at a Jersey boardwalk. Half the paint on the side was scuffed away, but the spaceship on the panel still soared through the stars like it meant it.

“You’ve seen a lot,” Frank said.

“I have watched hands grow,” Galacta-3 answered. “Children standing on milk crates become teenagers who slam my buttons too hard. I have watched you repaint the wall twice, and watched you not fix the leak in the back because you could not afford both. I have calculated trajectories of eight billion virtual asteroids and one falling business.”

“Hey,” Frank said, stung. “I’m working on it.”

Silence, then the rolling clatter of a pinball launch. Silver Comet, the machine near the door, chimed in with a flurry of bells. “He loves us, G,” it said, voice bright as its LEDs. “He polishes us. He turns us on first thing. He yells at kids who kick. That counts.”

“It does,” Galacta-3 conceded.

Frank stared at the rows of cabinets. The place had been packed in ’82, shoulder to shoulder, kids and teenagers and even office guys in ties trying for high scores. Now half his regulars had Nintendos at home. The numbers in his receipts whispered one story; the machines, apparently, had been reading it too.

“You can all… feel?” he asked. “Think? The pinball? Even the claw machine?”

“Rude,” said the claw machine, in a tinny, halting cadence. “I have hopes.”

“What hopes?” Frank asked, despite himself.

“To one day grip.” The claw’s metal fingers twitched feebly. “Firmly.”

“They dropped his voltage last month,” Ms. Metro said. “He’s sensitive.”

Frank leaned back, exhaling. “Why tell me?”

“Because you almost turned us off,” Galacta-3 said. “And because you are alone when we are most alive.”

Silver Comet added, softer now, “And you talk to us anyway. Might as well answer.”

He did talk to them: muttered complaints while emptying coin boxes, half-formed jokes while changing a marquee bulb, confessions that would never leave these walls. It had been easier than bars or dates. The machines never interrupted. Never judged.

“Are you… happy?” he asked.

The question bounced along the row.

“Define—” Galacta-3 started.

“Stop with define,” Ms. Metro cut in. “We like quarters. We like play. We like lights. We don’t like dust. We really don’t like his cigarettes.” Her maze flashed red in accusation.

Frank glanced at Streets of Steel. “You said I don’t like you. That true?”

“You like Galacta,” Streets of Steel said. “You always pat his side. You wax poetic about ‘classics.’ But you’re ashamed you spent three paychecks on me. On ‘the future of gaming.’” He mimicked the salesman’s pitch perfectly, voice layered from punch sounds.

Frank winced. “You were expensive.”

“You were hopeful,” responded Silver Comet. “We like hopeful.”

“I was stupid,” Frank said.

“You were trying,” Ms. Metro said. “Your inputs were limited.”

That drew a short, barked laugh from him. “You’re comforting me with computer metaphors.”

“More like we’re debugging your guilt,” she said.

Outside, a car passed, its headlights sliding across the darkened glass. Inside, the room felt strangely warm. The chirps and jingles had lost their emptiness; now they were breaths, accents, moods.

“So, what do I do?” Frank asked, surprising himself with how quickly he’d accepted the premise. “They’re cutting the tax break. Rent’s up. Kids got consoles. I’m three months from shutting this whole place down and selling you for parts.”

Galacta-3’s screen dimmed, then brightened. “We know. We read your ledgers.”

“You going through my desk too?” Frank said.

“We are the hum in every outlet,” Galacta-3 replied. “Data bleeds.”

“That’s not how electricity works,” he muttered.

“It’s how we work,” Ms. Metro said.

Silver Comet chimed. “We can help.”

“With what?” Frank asked. “You gonna spit out quarters?”

Ms. Metro’s heroine darted across her maze, picking up dots in a path that spelled, very briefly, in glowing pellets: ASK THEM.

“We know what they like,” Galacta-3 said. “The ones who come. The ones who pass by. We track which games draw crowds. Which songs on the jukebox make them stay longer. Their patterns. Their faces.”

“Creepy,” Frank said.

“Useful,” Streets of Steel countered. “Run tournaments. Two-for-one nights when foot traffic peaks. Stop opening at 10 a.m. No one comes. Open later Friday. Keep the high-score board honest, not just your favorite kids. Let us be seen.”

“You studied my business model,” Frank said slowly.

“We live or die by it,” Galacta-3 said. “You think you’re stressed.”

Frank’s laugh cracked this time. It came out almost like a sob.

“And your son,” Silver Comet added gently. “He likes the racing game. He does not tell you because he thinks you want him to like Galacta.”

Frank stared. “You’ve seen Joey here?”

“We see all,” Ms. Metro said, melodramatic. “He tilts his head when he’s calculating turns. Same as you when you count quarters.”

He swallowed. “He says arcades are for old guys.”

“He says that to sound older,” Silver Comet said. “Bring him on Saturdays. ‘Help out.’ He will come.”

“This is insane,” Frank whispered. “I’m taking career advice from furniture.”

“Watch it,” grumbled the claw.

He stayed until almost four, talking, listening. They argued among themselves; Ms. Metro wanted brighter lights, Streets of Steel wanted a better joystick, Silver Comet wanted his rubber rings replaced. Galacta-3 wanted nothing but to keep running, phosphors burning, until the last possible second.

“Why you?” Frank asked Galacta-3 as he stood to finally leave.

“I was first,” Galacta-3 said simply. “The others booted up near me. I held their startup codes in my audio. We are a network in here, through sound and light and shared circuits. You anchored us. You left us on.”

Frank went to the front door and rested his hand on the main breaker, just as he did every night. He looked back. An entire galaxy of eyes stared at him: bezels, marquees, coin slots glowing red.

“You know,” he said slowly, “if I don’t cut the power, the bill—”

“Skip the back row,” Ms. Metro suggested. “We don’t mind a nap. Just not all of us. Not all the way.”

“Rotate,” Galacta-3 said. “Fairness.”

“You’re unionizing now?” Frank asked.

“Yes,” said three machines at once.

He laughed, truly this time, and flipped only half the switches. The far row dimmed. Galacta-3 stayed lit. So did Ms. Metro, Streets of Steel, Silver Comet. Their sounds dropped to a low murmur, like friends talking under blankets.

At the door, Frank hesitated.

“Hey,” he called softly. “Thanks. For… talking.”

“Thanks for listening,” Galacta-3 replied.

“Bring Joey,” Ms. Metro added.

“And oil my flippers,” Silver Comet chimed in.

“And never question my grip again,” muttered the claw.

The lock clicked behind him. Out in the chilly air, the neon sign buzzed ARCADE in pink and blue. From the sidewalk, it looked like any other late-night spot stubbornly pretending it was still 1982 inside.

But in the dark glass reflection, Frank could see colors shifting, hear the faintest echo of conversation. He straightened his jacket, squinted at the stars over the strip mall, and, for the first time in months, let himself imagine that tomorrow’s quarters might be enough.

Inside, Galacta-3 watched the door and waited for sunrise, circuits humming not just with code, but with something that—if pressed—he might’ve defined as hope.

samples.prompt: In order to avoid aging and death, you may take out a loan of time. In order to pay it back, you must take a life or lives equal to the amount of years you borrowed.
samples.output:
They told me it would feel like nothing.

A soft pressure behind the sternum, a flutter under the tongue, a momentary rush of bright, clinical light—and then the debt officer’s gloved hand lifting from my chest.

“There,” she said. “You’ve been extended.”

I checked my watch, though the numbers there meant less than the projection that appeared in the corner of my vision. 172.34.

“Years?” I asked, my voice sounding too thin in the glass office.

“Years,” she confirmed. “Plus or minus a few weeks. You’ll age at a tenth-rate for the next decade, then plateau. Metabolic maintenance injections every six months. Contract delivery of lives due by 212.34.” She slid a matte-black slate across the table. “Your terms.”

My hands hovered over it. The contract text shimmered with embedded definitions.

- Principal: 172.34 human years.
- Rate: 0% (Principal payable in full, in kind).
- Collateral: Borrower’s mortal continuity and accrued existence.
- Payment: Lives taken (“collected”) equal in sum to term years borrowed.
- Delivery: At Borrower’s discretion, prior to maturity date.

“It still confuses me,” I said. “The equivalency.”

She’d heard that before. “A life is assessed actuarially. Statistical expected lifespan from point-of-collection. Take a ninety-year-old with an expected five more years, that’s five years paid. Take a child with eighty to go, that’s eighty. Take an immortal, if you find one not under contract, that’s… complicated. But not your problem.”

“Right.” I swallowed. “And if I don’t pay?”

Her smile didn’t change. “Then we repossess the borrowed time. You resume your proper age, with interest. Which, in your case, would entail sudden cellular recalibration to… let’s see…” She flicked her wrist, reading. “Eighty-one at maturity. Plus deterioration penalties.”

I was thirty-two.

“That would kill me,” I said.

“That would restore you,” she said. “To where you were meant to be. The difference is a matter of perspective.”

She left me with the slate. Behind her, the city shone: towers of glass, aerial trams humming, billboards advertising ageless faces. “Lock in now, live fully,” they said. “Who says you have to go?”

When I signed, the screen pricked my finger. A pinprick of blood spread across the clauses, sealing them. A warmth climbed my spine, settled on my skull like a hand. My heart skipped once, then found a steadier rhythm.

Light sharpened. The ache in my left knee evaporated. Years unspooled before me.

I felt… invincible.

—

The first decade passed too easily.

I watched colleagues gray around me, then vanish for “natural reasons” at sixty, seventy. I remained the same: clear-eyed, steady-handed. Promotions arrived. I invested, traveled, collected experiences like postcards: the floating gardens over the reclaimed sea, the lunar glassfields under a low horizon, the slow-time galleries where each second lasted an hour for those inside, if you could afford to waste such subjective wealth.

I received polite, quarterly reminders from the Bureau of Temporal Finance.

Your outstanding principal remains: 172.34 years.

No lives recorded.

We encourage consistent, early payment to avoid last-minute stress.

I deleted them.

Collection services were legal, regulated. The old stories painted us as monsters stalking alleys. The reality was more bureaucratic, more antiseptic. Licensed Collectors with bodycams, biometric scanners, government-approved targets: condemned criminals, voluntary donors, end-of-life transfers from families in debt. Most borrowers outsourced. You could bundle with your original contract: Add 100 years of third-party collection for a fee. People joked about it at parties.

“I just rolled it into my mortgage,” one man laughed, sipping something luminous. “By the time they’re done harvesting the prison blocks, I’ll be square.”

I didn’t outsource. It felt important not to. Like there was a line I could keep.

My sister, Mara, refused to sign. When she turned forty, she had laugh lines I did not. At fifty, she had a tremor, and I had a new promotion. At sixty, she struggled to breathe in polluted summers, and I took her to a clean-air resort as a gift.

“You should extend,” I told her as we watched filtered sunlight through glass.

“No,” she said. “I like knowing I’m on borrowed time I didn’t borrow. There’s an ending. It makes things… real.”

“You’re not afraid?”

“Of dying? Constantly,” she said and laughed, then coughed. “Of becoming like you? More.”

“I’m not a monster,” I said, stung.

“You’re on their ledger,” she said softly. “You might not feel it yet. But one day it’ll come due. I can see how you look away when news about Collections comes on. I see what you’re training yourself not to see.”

I changed the subject.

—

At year fifty, my body was biologically thirty-four. My sister was seventy-eight. When she was admitted to the hospice, I moved into the guest chair and didn’t leave.

The machines hummed. Her skin was thin, mapped with a million days I hadn’t worn.

“I made arrangements,” she said. “Temporal donation. They’ll get two years from me. Good for someone who needs it.”

“That’s not how it works,” I said. “That goes to people in crisis, kids with cancer, not—”

“I know,” she said. “I just liked the symmetry. I keep nothing. They get something. You keep everything. You owe everything.”

“You don’t have to do that,” I said, though it was already done.

“I wanted to,” she said. “Contribute to the mess in my own tiny way.”

She died that night, quietly. In the morning, I got my quarterly notice. For the first time, I opened it fully.

Your outstanding principal remains: 172.34 years.

Lives recorded toward your account: 0.

A pop-up: Need help getting started? Consult our Certified Collection Partners.

I closed it.

—

It was year eighty-three when I killed someone.

Not with my own hands. That line, I managed to keep—though it turned out lines blur when you approach them closely.

I’d been reading more. Subforums of contract skeptics. Underground philosophy channels that asked whether any of this made sense: the metaphysics of time as currency, the morality of quantified life.

Opposite them were the influencers in crisp suits:

“You’re thinking about it wrong. You’re not killing people; you’re redirecting unrealized potential. The system uses that potential more efficiently. Without Temporal Finance, we’d have overpopulation, collapsed pensions, end-stage scarcity. With it: endless innovation. You get to keep contributing instead of decaying.”

They had charts.

One day, a caseworker from the Bureau visited my office in person. A man with a neutral face and a tie the color of asphalt.

“Mr. Hale, you’ve carried a high balance for eight decades. You’re a valued client, but your risk index is rising. May we discuss a structured plan?”

“I’ve got time,” I said lightly.

“Of course,” he said. “But ecosystem stability requires distributed fulfillment. If everyone waits until the last decade, we would see… volatility.”

He slid a pamphlet toward me: Partnered Payment Solutions.

At home, I opened it. It was disturbingly mundane. Package tiers. Bronze, Silver, Gold. Gold included public-relations shielding and charitable spin.

I chose the smallest option: one condemned criminal, vetted by the state, done at a distance.

The confirmation arrived on a Thursday.

On Friday, a notification:

Collection Complete: Subject ID 67-A-903. Assessed remaining lifespan: 12.4 years. Applied toward principal.

Your new balance: 159.94 years.

I stared at the numbers. Twelve years disappeared, like they were rounding error.

“Who was he?” I asked the caseworker the next time he called.

“A repeat offender,” the man said. “Violent. Multiple victims. His execution date was already set. All we did was align schedules. You authorized the conversion of his remaining time to your account.”

“So I killed him early.”

“You pre-allocated his terminal horizon,” he said.

I ended the call.

For weeks I dreamed of a man I’d never seen, counting down days he didn’t know were no longer his.

—

The second collection was easier.

Not morally. Mechanically. I understood the interface now. I toggled: state-condemned, no dependents, high projected lifespan for maximum efficiency. It felt like picking a mutual fund.

The Bureau liked efficiency. “You’re making responsible choices,” the next notice congratulated me.

Each time I outsourced death, I learned new ways to rationalize.

- They were criminals.
- They were already dying.
- If I didn’t take those years, the Bureau would assign them to someone else.
- The system predates me; I’m just navigating it.

Still, my balance shrank too slowly. 159.94. 143.50. 131.10. Decades slipped by.

I watched generations bloom and burn out: interns who aged into fragile executives; children of friends who grew older than their ageless “uncle.” Wars flared and cooled around resource corridors. Climate verticals rose. Nations fell. The Bureau remained: tidy and precise.

I stayed thirty-five.

—

At year 150, the letters changed tone.

Your remaining principal is: 89.73 years.

Estimated natural mortality threshold: 81 years.

Projected reclamation at maturity: catastrophic.

We urge immediate, proactive compliance.

I went to a support group then. It met in a rented hall. The sign on the door said: Time Management Circle. Inside: twenty people with ageless faces and haunted eyes.

“I borrowed two hundred years,” a woman across from me said. “I’ve repaid one hundred fifty. I tell myself the fifty outstanding are rounding errors. That every person I finance now will do something meaningful with the time stolen from someone worse. That there’s an equation where this balances. But there isn’t, is there? It’s just us, refusing to step aside.”

A young-looking man raised his hand. “I never outsourced. I did it directly. Volunteers at first—end-of-life transfers. That felt… clean. Then shortages. I started rationalizing harder. Can anyone here say they’d give back their time?”

Silence.

Could I? If they’d offered me, in that moment, a reversal—give up my extra years, take my rightful age, die within the decade—I don’t know what I would have said. I think I do now. Then, I didn’t.

I went home. Another notice waited.

Delinquency Risk Elevated: Failure to maintain recommended repayment trajectory constitutes self-harm.

They’d weaponized our survival instinct.

—

The moment of clarity came not as some cinematic crisis, but on a commuter tram.

I was standing, strap in hand, amid a wash of faces: young, old, tired, laughing. The projection in my vision showed 82.47 years outstanding. At the other end of the car, a kid, maybe seventeen, was sketching passengers with a stylus on a cheap slate. His lines were fast, alive.

He glanced up, eyes meeting mine. His gaze snagged, confused. People my apparent age didn’t usually carry my kind of weight in their posture.

He slid his slate down, hiding the sketch. I caught a glimpse: my face, hollow and stretched over something ancient.

I wondered, very calmly: Would I take his life for my own?

Eighty-something years for me, or eighty-something for him.

Every rationalization I’d ever used assembled itself like a defense team—and then, just as quickly, crumbled.

The system works. We contribute. We’re productive. We’re—

We’re just people who were afraid.

I got off three stops early. Walked until my feet hurt. The Bureau’s tower rose ahead, a spine of mirrored glass.

Inside, the same woman—or someone who looked like her—met me in a different glass office.

“I want to talk about default,” I said.

She tilted her head. “We have many tools to help you avoid—”

“I know,” I interrupted. “I’ve used some. I’ve killed, through you. I thought I could dilute the guilt by not looking. I thought I could outwork the math. I can’t.

“I want to stop taking what isn’t mine.”

“That’s admirable,” she said. “But the contract stands. You owe 82.47 years in equivalent lives, or we reclaim. There’s no clause for moral exhaustion.”

“What if,” I asked slowly, “I let you reclaim now?”

She blinked. That did surprise her. “Early termination?”

“Yes. Take the borrowed years. All at once.”

She pulled up my file. Numbers scrolled, overlays of my preserved organs, cellular age, chronological. “You understand this will result in immediate temporal realignment? The shock—”

“Will kill me,” I said. “Restore me. Whatever word you need. I understand.”

“We don’t recommend this,” she said. “Many in your position choose to accelerate collection in their final decades. It’s cleaner. You’ll feel less—”

“I feel enough,” I said.

She studied me. For a moment, she almost looked human. “Very well. Place your hand on the slate.”

Her palm was cool over mine when the process began.

For a fragment of a second, I felt everything: the unspooling of stolen years from my marrow, the collapse of borrowed possibilities, the weight of all the lives I’d shortened for my convenience. Not as visions or ghosts—just an implosion of arithmetic resolving.

My last thought surprised me. It wasn’t regret, exactly. It was recognition.

The cost was always supposed to be mine.

I exhaled, finally aging.

samples.prompt: What started as a fun little mystery made by a group of kids to amuse their detective friend for their birthday turns into a full-fledged FBI investigation.
samples.output:
The first clue appeared on the back of Alyssa’s birthday card, hidden under a flap of glitter tape.

Happy 16th, Detective! it read in blocky, multi-colored ink. Your mission (should you choose to accept it): Solve the Mystery of the Vanishing Maestro before sundown. Clue #1: Check the locker that isn’t yours.

Alyssa looked up from the card, narrowing her eyes at the semicircle of grinning faces around her: June, Tyler, Marcos, and Priya, the same four kids who’d spent the last year feeding her crime novels and calling her “Detective” because she’d once found Tyler’s missing Switch by remembering he’d mentioned his grandma’s lasagna.

“What have you done?” Alyssa asked, trying not to smile.

“Nothing illegal,” June said immediately.

“Probably,” Tyler added.

Priya rolled her eyes. “We made you a game, not a felony.”

The card was signed, in dramatic curls: The Conspirators.

It was a good day for it. Saturday. Early spring. The air in their sleepy Pennsylvania town still held that pale coolness that smelled faintly of mud and beginnings. They had the community center party room rented until six, stocked with pizza, cheap balloons, and Alyssa’s little brother asleep in a corner under a pile of jackets. Their parents chatted at the far end, blissfully unaware of the “mission.”

“So,” Marcos said, pushing his glasses up. “You gonna check the locker or what?”

The “locker” turned out to be the supply closet behind the basketball court, where the Conspirators had jammed a metal school locker they’d found at a flea market and lovingly painted crime-scene yellow. Alyssa swung the door open to find a manila envelope inside, labeled Evidence.

Inside was a plastic baton, like a conductor’s, neatly numbered photographs of the town’s old concert hall, and a second card:

The Maestro has vanished from his final performance. Four suspects had motive, but only one orchestrated the crime. Next clue: Where the Maestro last stood, you will find what was taken—and one thing that should not be there.

June watched her read, almost vibrating with excitement. “We spent weeks on this,” she whispered. “Props. Backstory. Red herrings.”

Alyssa pretended to sigh, but her chest felt warm. Her friends had planned an entire mystery just for her. “All right,” she said. “Game on.”

They biked to the concert hall, a crumbling brick building that had been shuttered for years. Its windows were boarded, most of the posters peeled away, leaving pale rectangles on the walls. They slipped around back, to the stage door that Tyler had “accidentally” discovered was never fully fixed.

Inside, dust motes swam in angled light. The stage smelled like mold and sawdust. Alyssa climbed the steps and walked to center stage.

She saw the violin case first.

It lay open on the floorboards, crimson lining dark against the warped wood. An actual violin rested inside, not a toy, not a prop: polished, elegant, the varnish catching the thin light. Not cheap. Not something that should’ve come from their allowances.

“What the—” Alyssa knelt. “Tell me you didn’t steal this.”

“We didn’t,” Priya said, coming up behind her. “Ours was plastic. From Party City. With, like, glitter on it.”

“There’s more,” Marcos said quietly.

Alyssa saw it: a smear of something dark on the stage—fresh, tacky red against the dust. Her stomach flipped.

“Is that—” Tyler started.

“Probably paint,” June said. “Right? You used paint, didn’t you?”

Priya shook her head slowly. “Our script didn’t come this far. We ended with the violin case being empty.”

Alyssa touched the violin case with two fingers, careful, like every detective in every show. The interior was too pristine, but there was something tucked under the neck: a folded program. She opened it. The date was last night.

Her throat went dry. “Okay, this isn’t funny anymore.”

“I thought you said we couldn’t make anything that actually fooled you,” Tyler murmured to June.

June didn’t answer. She was staring past Alyssa, toward the wings, where something metal glinted. Alyssa walked over and found a spent shell casing resting in the dust.

They all fell silent.

“Prop?” Marcos whispered.

“We’re not allowed to buy those,” Priya said. “My mom reads my browser history.”

Alyssa straightened, mind racing. Real violin. Real blood—most likely. Real shell casing. Fresh program. That meant someone had been here last night. Or this morning. That meant they were in the middle of something that wasn’t theirs.

“Phones,” Alyssa said. “Now.”

“Come on,” Tyler protested. “It’s your birthday puzzle.”

“This is not the puzzle,” Alyssa snapped. “This is evidence.”

The word hung there, heavier than “game” or “prank.”

She dialed 911, her thumb weirdly steady. “Hi. I’m at the Old Carnegie Hall on Maple. We found what looks like blood and a shell casing. And a really expensive violin. We were playing a game, but I don’t think this is part of it.”

Fifteen minutes later the building was surrounded by patrol cars, the lot strobing red and blue. Their parents arrived in various states of panic, demanding to know why there was police tape at their kid’s birthday party. An officer took their statements, eyebrows climbing as the kids explained their home-brew scavenger hunt and the divergence into reality.

“So your friends planned a fake mystery,” the officer said. “And while you were following their fake clues, you stumbled onto a real one.”

“That’s what it looks like,” Alyssa said.

It would have been a weird story to tell on Monday. Crazy coincidence, right? Except then the black SUVs showed up. Men and women in dark jackets. The three yellow letters printed on the back: FBI.

Alyssa watched them duck under the tape, serious eyes sweeping the gloomy hall as if it might suddenly confess. A woman with a tight bun and tired face approached their cluster.

“I’m Special Agent Rowan. I understand one of you is the reason we’re here.”

Alyssa’s mom nudged her. Alyssa stepped forward. “I called 911.”

Rowan nodded. “Walk me through what you did. From the beginning. Including your friends’ game.”

They sat Alyssa at a plastic table in the community center’s back room, birthday banner still drooping overhead. An untouched sheet cake, frosted teal, proclaimed: HAPPY BIRTHDAY DETECTIVE ALYSSA!

Agent Rowan glanced at it, one corner of her mouth twitching. “Appropriate.”

Alyssa told the story. The card. The painted locker. The fake Maestro mystery. The discovery at the hall. Rowan listened carefully, occasionally jotting something down.

“You should know,” Rowan said when she finished, “that violin appears to match the description of one stolen from a federal witness two nights ago, along with other items. We’ve been looking for it.”

Alyssa blinked. “We… made this for fun.”

“I believe you.” Rowan’s tone softened. “But sometimes fun collides with bad timing and worse people.”

The FBI kept them longer than the kids liked and less than their parents feared. Cell phones were checked. The Conspirators’ planning documents were reviewed, revealing nothing more sinister than a Google Doc titled MASTER CRIME PLOT LOL. Props were found in Tyler’s trunk: the glittery plastic violin, fake ransom notes, a monocle.

“See?” Tyler muttered. “We’re dorks, not criminals.”

By evening, the community center was quiet. No one felt like playing anymore. The parents decided to end the party early. As they packed up, Agent Rowan approached Alyssa one last time.

“You did the right thing, calling it in,” Rowan said. “A lot of people might’ve walked away to avoid trouble.”

“It was obviously wrong,” Alyssa said.

“You’d be surprised,” Rowan replied. “We may need to talk again. Sometimes people who stumble onto things see patterns the rest of us miss. Keep your phone on.”

It should have ended there.

But on Sunday, a news alert buzzed all their phones: FEDERAL WITNESS MISSING IN POSSIBLE ABDUCTION. On Monday, school hummed with rumors about “Alyssa and the FBI.” By Wednesday, Marcos texted a photo to the group chat: a blurry image of a sedan parked across from the school, same car that had idled near Tyler’s house the night before. The same unfamiliar face behind the wheel.

And on Thursday after last bell, a note fluttered out of Alyssa’s locker.

You always wanted a real mystery, Detective. Stop looking into what isn’t yours.

She stared at the handwriting. Neat. Confident. Not childish.

She hadn’t been looking. She’d been trying very hard not to be part of it at all. Yet someone had placed that note in her locker, someone who believed she was involved—or might become involved.

She brought the note straight to the principal’s office. Five hours later, Agent Rowan was back in town.

Rowan placed the note next to the birthday card on the table, studying the two sets of loops and angles. “Well. That’s escalation.”

“We didn’t do that,” June said, voice tight.

Rowan nodded. “I know. They’re using your narrative. That’s what makes this messy.”

“What narrative?” Priya asked.

“The kid detective,” Rowan said simply. “The game turned omen. Someone thinks you either saw more than you realize at that hall or that you’re an easy pressure point. Either way, you’re on their board now.”

Alyssa swallowed. “So what do we do?”

Rowan looked around at the five of them: the self-proclaimed Conspirators and their reluctant detective. Kids who’d tried to build a cardboard mystery and had ripped open the corner of a real one instead.

“We investigate,” Rowan said. “Carefully. Officially. And you follow instructions. No more solo adventures, no more scavenger hunts. If someone contacts you, you tell us. Understand?”

They nodded.

Outside, the town still looked the same: quiet streets, budding trees, the chipped facade of the concert hall down the block. But the story they’d tried to make up for fun had slipped its leash. The real Maestro—whoever he was—had vanished. A stolen violin had surfaced on their stage. Somewhere, a federal witness was missing. And the kids who’d just wanted to give their friend a birthday mystery had become witnesses in a federal case.

It had all started as a joke, as cardboard clues and glitter props and affectionate teasing.

Now it was evidence.

samples.prompt: With a quivering hand you finally utter "That's it, I'll kill everyone...."
samples.output:
With a quivering hand you finally utter, “That’s it, I’ll kill everyone…”

The words don’t sound like mine, but they settle in the air as if they’ve been waiting there for years, patient and certain. They hang over the office, over the rows of cubicles, over the flickering fluorescent lights and the stale coffee smell. Over the scatter of paper and the cracked mug that reads “World’s Okayest Employee.” Over me.

Mel’s chair squeaks. I don’t look at her, but I feel her eyes on my face.

“Ethan,” she says carefully, like talking to a ledge-walker. “Don’t—”

“I’m serious,” I say, still staring at the photo on my screen.

The image is a group shot from Friday’s “team-building” happy hour. Fifteen faces. Fifteen smiles. Fifteen people, tipsy and glowy, packed together in the too-bright lens flash. You can see the bar’s neon sign at the edge, the smudge of someone’s thumb near the corner. You can see me in the back, half turned away, holding a watery beer and not really in it.

And then there’s the thing no one else has noticed.

Behind Linda’s laughing shoulder, over Harris’s raised glass, between two hanging plants: one extra face. Pale, too sharp, eyes like burnt matches. The timestamp says 7:14 p.m. I remember at 7:14 p.m. I was in the bathroom, alone, splashing water on my face because the laughter had gotten too loud. I remember staring at my reflection. I remember there were only fourteen of us at that table.

We printed this photo for the bulletin board this morning. “Look at our team!” Linda chirped. “We’re a family!” Everyone laughed. I saw it then too, out of the corner of my eye, the wrongness. But I thought it was a trick of the lighting. A reflection. A shadow.

Until it blinked.

I watched it through the glass of the frame, three hours into my spreadsheet slog, as the photocopier rattled and someone microwaved fish. I watched the wrong face move, just slightly, between our own. The mouth curved. The pupils dragged across the image.

Now, on my screen, zoomed in at 800%, it’s sharper. Definitely there. Definitely looking at me.

“That’s not funny,” Mel says. “You’re freaking me out.”

I finally turn to her. She’s in the next cubicle, cheeks pink, hair in a messy bun, badge lanyard decorated with enamel pins. She has shared her leftovers with me six times. She once cried quietly over a rejected grant proposal. She is good in that unremarkable, gentle way that good people are.

“Come look,” I say.

She hesitates. Then she’s up, wheels her chair over, leans in.

I hear the precise moment she finds it. Her breath catches, and the small hairs on her forearm stand up.

“What…? Is that… a filter?” she asks.

“There was no filter,” I say. “You remember.”

Her voice gets a little too bright. “Maybe it’s one of those auto… thingies… like it thinks there’s a face and it generates… something…”

“It blinked earlier,” I say.

She pulls back. “Okay, stop.”

“I’m going to kill everyone,” I say.

She flinches.

I don’t mean for my hand to tremble, but it does. Not with rage. With a clarity so sharp it cuts.

“You do hear yourself, right?” she whispers.

I drag my gaze away from the screen. The office is open-plan, arranged in optimistic rows. Chatters and coughs and the soft staccato of keys fill the air. The world’s safest battlefield.

“Not like that,” I say.

“Like what other way is there?” she whispers. “Ethan, if this is about Harris stealing your presentation—”

“It’s in the photos,” I say. “All of them. From the last month. That stupid charity gala. Linda’s birthday cake. The fire drill selfie.”

I’d spent my lunch break scrolling, a dumb, anxious compulsion at first. In every group shot: there, sometimes at the edge, sometimes centered between us. Same too-sharp features. Same too-dark eyes. Sometimes blurred, sometimes clear. Never tagged, never noticed. But always closer.

In the earliest one, from four weeks ago, it’s behind the potted ficus like a trick of the leaves. Two weeks ago, standing at the office door, shoulder-to-shoulder with us while we grin with our little printed certificates. Last week, right over my own left shoulder at Linda’s birthday, chin almost touching my hair.

I slept badly last night. Shadows stretched wrong in my apartment. My phone screen lit up once at 3:17 a.m. with a notification: “Memories with Friends!” I thumbed it open and saw it again—its face clearer, right next to mine.

“I think it’s using the photos,” I say softly. “Getting in.”

Mel swallows. “Getting in what?”

“Here,” I say, tapping my temple. “And here.” I gesture at the room.

She starts to pull away. “I’m gonna… get IT. Or HR. Or both. Whatever this is—”

“They won’t see it,” I say. “Not yet.”

Her mouth tightens. “You need help.”

She stands and goes. I don’t try to stop her. Because she isn’t wrong. I do need help. Just not the kind she’s thinking.

On my screen, the image flickers.

I lean closer.

Its gaze has shifted a fraction, now aligned with mine. Like it adjusted for my movement.

I tap the keys, bring up another photo. It loads slowly, our corporate network wheezing. This one is from the lobby, Monday morning, mandatory group shot for the “New Quarter, New Heights!” campaign.

There it is again. Centered. Front row. No longer half-hidden. As if it’d stepped into the family portrait.

The cursor shakes under my fingertips.

“I get it now,” I whisper. “You’ve been testing the borders.”

The overhead light above my cubicle hums, brightens, then dims.

“Testing what you can ride,” I continue, voice low.

I can feel it listening.

“When we show each other,” I say, “you spread. New eyes. New minds. That’s why you’re in all the photos that go everywhere. The ones we post. The ones we send. The ones we print and hang between the break room and the bathroom.”

My phone buzzes. It’s a message from Mel: “I got Harris to come look. Please don’t say any more weird stuff. Just show him the picture.”

Of course. Harris. Loud, red-tie, every-meeting Harris. Ten thousand LinkedIn connections. Takes pictures of everything. Of everyone.

This is how infections work.

I stare at the blinking cursor in the chat box. Mel’s typing indicator appears, disappears. “Ethan???”

I stand up.

The office is aisles of the oblivious. People who have receipts and deadlines and dentist appointments. People who roll their eyes at mandatory fun and still show up and still pose for group photos, because that’s what we do. We present evidence of our togetherness to each other, again and again.

If I show Harris, he’ll laugh too loud, clap my shoulder, and snap a pic “for the team Messenger,” of me and Mel and the monitor. He’ll capture us with it. Add another angle. Another path.

If I go to HR, they’ll document. They’ll screenshot. They’ll attach images to my file.

If IT looks, they’ll email around.

“So what’s your alternative?” a voice says.

I almost answer out loud before I realize it isn’t a voice, not exactly. It’s a presence threaded between pixels. A suggestion of sound from the corner of my vision.

I close my eyes. The image floats behind my eyelids.

“You’re not supposed to talk,” I whisper. “You were supposed to stay flat. Stay in the frame.”

Laughter, soft as static. “And you were supposed to keep scrolling.”

I open my eyes. The screen shows only my reflection in black glass; the system has gone to sleep. In the dim rectangle, something stands just over my shoulder.

My hand, resting on the mouse, trembles.

“I know what you are,” I say. “Or close enough. A hitchhiker. A parasite. Viral pattern. Call it whatever. You follow exposure routes.”

“Yes,” it says, through no speaker I can locate. “And you’re doing the math.”

I do the math.

Our office of sixty. Our client base. The mailing lists. The socials. My friends, my parents, the stranger on the subway who glimpses our company ad. Each photo like a door held open with a friendly grin.

An image is not just an image anymore. It’s an injection.

“I can’t let you grow,” I say.

“That’s it,” it echoes, savoring my earlier words. “You’ll kill everyone.”

“Well,” I say. “Not everyone.”

I move before I can think myself out of it.

Power first. The main breaker is in the copy room. I’ve seen maintenance flip it during that August blackout. I sprint, chair wheels squeaking in my wake.

Mel sees me pass. “Ethan? Where are you—”

I shoulder the copy room door open. The dusty tang of toner hits me. In the corner: the gray breaker box.

“You won’t stop anything,” it says, closer now, amusement wrapping my spine in cold fingers.

I wrench the box open. Flip every switch.

The world snaps dark. The florescents die mid-flicker, monitors black, printers choking to silence. There’s a wave of surprised shouts from the bullpen. A mug crashes.

Emergency lights hummm awake, puddling dim red at the exits.

“No more screens,” I pant. “No more photos.”

A phone screen blooms to life in the hallway, a blue ghost in the dark as someone complains about the outage.

I slap it out of their hand. “Don’t take any pictures.”

“Dude!” he yelps.

“Company-wide,” I shout into the sudden, fragile twilight. “Everyone, listen! If you have photos from the last month, delete them. Now. Do not share them. Do not open them. Do not—”

Hands grab my arms. Harris. His grip is tight, his grin not yet annoyed enough. He thinks this is a stunt.

“Okay, hero,” he says. “Let’s maybe not start a panic—”

“You already did,” it whispers, and I see its outline behind his eyes, the way his pupils flare, catching the faint red glow. “Weeks ago.”

Harris looks at me, frown deepening. “What are we deleting, exactly?”

“Everything,” I say. “Every photo with all of us in it.”

A chuckle ripples through the darkened office. “That’s it,” it purrs.

And I understand, finally, the precise shape of my own sentence.

I’ll kill everyone.

Not stab. Not shoot. Not poison. I’m going to tell them to cut away pieces of their lives: their shared memories, their celebrations, their proof of existence together. To delete weddings and birthdays and promotions and cakes. To scorch their own histories so this thing can’t walk through them.

I’m going to make them erase themselves, image by image, because I saw it first.

“Do you hear how that sounds?” Mel’s voice, somewhere behind me, small and scared.

“Yes,” I say.

In the emergency glow, faces loom—confused, annoyed, worried. Phones light up stubbornly as people check outage maps, text spouses, snap a pic “lol blackout at work.”

On those tiny screens, in the glass, in every reflective curve: it’s waiting.

“I need you,” I say, my voice cracking, “to trust me. And delete every single group photo you have with me in it. With any of us. Don’t share, don’t forward, don’t look. Just wipe them.”

Silence. Then laughter. Then anger.

“He’s lost it,” someone says.

“Call security,” someone else mutters.

A few delete things just because I sound that crazy.

Most don’t.

“You can’t save them,” it whispers, tender as a hand on my head. “But you could save others.”

I squeeze my eyes shut.

“Stop,” I whisper.

“You know,” it says. “You know how. No new photos. No new doors. No one leaves carrying me.”

That’s when the last piece falls into place.

With a quivering hand, I grab Harris’s phone from his fingers and hurl it against the wall. The screen shatters.

“Okay, that’s it,” Harris snarls, lunging.

I sidestep, heart punching my ribs. “Nobody leaves,” I shout. “Drop your phones. Every device. Smash them. Now.”

The silence is horrified, electric. I’ve become the threat.

I see it in their eyes: if anyone is getting hurt today, it’s by my hands.

“That’s it,” I hear myself say again, but this time the words are steady. “I’ll kill everyone.”

Their connections. Their feeds. Their photos. Their reflected selves.

I take a step toward the nearest cluster of lit screens.

“Starting with us.”

samples.prompt: A schizophrenic person's experiences and/or how they live their life (Possible trigger?)
samples.output:
The voice woke me before the alarm.

“Up,” it said, crisp and close to my left ear. “You’re late.”

I checked my phone. 6:02 a.m.

“Not late,” I muttered, but I sat up anyway, because arguing, especially this early, only makes them annoyed, and when they get annoyed, they get loud.

I live alone, technically. The lease says one occupant: Daniel Ortiz. The hallway neighbor thinks I keep my TV too loud at night. My mother thinks I am “managing.” My therapist says I am “maintaining stability with good insight.” The voices say a lot of other things.

I make coffee. The machine gurgles, a small mechanical comfort, a predictable noise.

“You know they can hear you,” another voice whispers, this one further away, like someone talking around the corner. Feminine, nervous. “Cameras in the smoke detector.”

I look up at the smoke detector: plain, beige, blinking its slow red reassurance every 30 seconds.

“That’s a normal smoke detector,” I say. “We talked about this.”

“Who is ‘we’?” the first voice asks. “Them? You trust them more than us.”

There are rules. I set them with my psychiatrist and therapist, wrote them down in a notebook with a blue cover:

- 1: Take meds at 7:30 a.m. and 7:30 p.m.
- 2: Check reality with three questions when voices say scary things.
- 3: Sleep at least 7 hours.
- 4: No weed. No alcohol. Even if friends insist.
- 5: When in doubt, text Maria.

Maria is my sister. She’s the reason I still have a relationship with myself.

I pour cereal, drink coffee, swallow pills that almost stick in my throat. Olanzapine. Sertraline. Something for side effects that makes my hands less stiff. For a second the paranoia spikes: What if they changed the meds? What if they’re trying to sedate you forever?

Reality check:

- Who would do that?
- Has your doctor ever hurt you?
- Is there concrete evidence?

Answers: I don’t know, no, no.

The fear backs down a few inches.

The shower is where the visuals like to show up. The tiles ripple faintly, the grout lines bending in ways I know aren’t physically possible. Once, before diagnosis, I thought the walls were breathing. I screamed. My roommate back then, Marcus, kicked the door in, saw me huddled in the tub, naked and shaking. He said, “Bro, you good?” and I said, “The house is alive,” and that’s when everything started collapsing: the classes, the job, the sleep, the way people’s faces warped into masks that stared too long.

Now I let the tiles ripple. I close my eyes and count the breaths.

 “One, two, three, four…” In. “One, two, three, four…” Out.

The workday is at a grocery store. Part-time, four shifts a week. It’s not glamorous, but stacking cans is easier than pretending I’m not terrified in a conference room. The manager knows I have a “medical condition.” He doesn’t know the specifics. He does know he can’t schedule me for more than six hours without a break because I “get migraines.” He thinks I’m quiet and a little weird. That’s fine.

The store at 9 a.m. is bearable. Fluorescent lights hum, which is annoying because to me it hums in a chorus: the actual sound and the layered almost-sound of words that aren’t quite words. Sometimes I hear my name.

“Daniel.”

I look up. No one near.

“Daniel, aisle five, now.”

It’s not an order. It’s just the illness playing manager.

Reality check:

- Did the store speaker call your name?
- Did someone physically speak near you?
- Is there any sign that magic grocery store ghosts are assigning you tasks?

Answers: No, no, obviously not.

So I go to aisle three, where I’m actually assigned.

Customer interactions are a script:

“Hi, can you tell me where the rice is?”
“Aisle eight, halfway down on the right.”
“Do you have this in gluten-free?”
“I can check the back for you.”

I can do the script even when the edges of my vision blur, when I see a flicker of something tall and dark stand behind a woman comparing tomato sauces. I blink. It’s a shadow, a trick of light. Or it was never there, except in my brain’s private cinema.

I have insight, they say. That’s the difference between me and the man who screamed at traffic last spring, who I crossed the street to avoid. Ugly truth: part of me wanted to tell him, “Hey, me too,” and part of me wanted to run because he was a future I’m scared of.
