People think schizophrenia is all horror movie: blood and murder and a voice commanding you to hurt someone. For me it’s mostly:

- Doubting every perception I have.
- Being exhausted by my own thoughts.
- Feeling like a radio picking up stations I never tuned.

There are bad days. On those, the voice that sounds like my father says, with his tired disappointment, “You’re broken. You will never be anything.”

My father, the real one, mostly says, “You take your meds? You need money?” He also sends meme videos. The illness turns that man into a cruel echo. It’s not his fault. It’s not mine either. But I still feel guilty arguing with someone who isn’t there in the produce cooler.

At lunch I sit outside behind the dumpsters, not because I like the smell but because it’s quieter. My coworker Jade sometimes joins me to smoke.

“You look tired,” she says.

“Didn’t sleep great,” I answer.

“You gotta stop playing video games so late,” she laughs.

I let her believe that. It’s easier than explaining that at 2 a.m. a voice kept insisting there was someone in the hallway, keys scratching, waiting. That I had to get up three times to check the lock, that my heart was sprinting, that my ceiling fan was morphing into a spinning metal flower with too many petals and too many teeth.

After work, the bus ride home is crowded. This is hardest: too many real voices layered over the unreal ones, smells and heat and movement. A baby cries; that sound scrapes my nerves. A guy’s earbuds leak tinny drums. Somewhere behind me, I hear:

“They know. They all know about you.”

The paranoia swells: Every laugh is about you. Every glance is suspicion.

Reality check, softly, like a mantra:

- People are busy with their own lives.
- No one here knows your medical chart.
- Laughing does not equal conspiracies.

I focus on the bus driver’s rearview mirror. My face in the corner: 29, dark circles, stubble. I look like anyone tired after work. That helps.

At home, I text Maria.

Me: Rough day. All manageable, just loud.
Maria: Proud of you. Call later?
Me: Yeah, after dinner.

She didn’t run when I told her the diagnosis. Five years ago, when I came home after the hospital, she sat cross-legged on my bed and said, “Explain it to me like I’m five.” I said, “My brain sometimes lies to me and I believe it too much.” She said, “Okay. Then we’ll fact check together.” And just like that, I wasn’t alone.

I microwave leftovers. The fork scraping the plate blends with a faint, needling whisper: “Poison.”

I roll my eyes. Out loud, because talking back helps: “If they were going to poison me, they’d pick something better than Tuesday lasagna.”

I take a bite. I don’t die. This is how trust is rebuilt: one uneventful dinner at a time.

I have therapy Wednesdays. We talk about skills and fears and how I’m more than my diagnosis. Some days I believe that. Some days the label feels like my entire name: Schizophrenic. As if it explains every failure, every awkward silence.

But there are things the illness hasn’t taken:

- I still draw. Lines and color calm me, anchor me in what’s in front of me.
- I still love the way it smells right before it rains.
- I still have this dry, terrible sense of humor Maria insists is “my main redeeming quality.”

I’m allowed to want things. My therapist pushes on that: “What do you want beyond not being sick?”

I want:

- A full-time job I don’t hate.
- Maybe a relationship with someone who doesn’t flinch if I say “psychosis.”
- A dog. (The voices are divided on the dog; one is firmly pro-dog, which I take as a good omen.)

Night is both relief and risk. The world quiets; my head sometimes does the opposite. Still, I do the routine: meds at 7:30, chamomile tea, no doomscrolling. Phone call with Maria where we talk more about her thesis and less about my brain. It feels normal, and normal, for me, is a miracle built from pills, patience, and a lot of unglamorous work.

Lying in bed, fan turning calmly (just a fan, just blades, no teeth), I hear one last voice.

“You did okay today,” it says, almost kind.

“Thanks,” I whisper. “But you’re still not real.”

I turn off the light. I know they’ll be there tomorrow. So will I. And that’s how I live my life: not as a tragedy or a monster story, but as a long, strange negotiation with a brain that doesn’t always tell the truth—and the quiet, stubborn decision, every day, to keep going anyway.

samples.prompt: You have always felt like your body doesn't belong to you, one day you wake up and can't control your body as it starts walking towards a pen and some paper and then starts writing.
samples.output:
I know before I’m fully awake.

It’s the feeling of watching myself from the outside again, but sharper, like the focus has clicked. My eyelids drag open and the ceiling swims into view, and I already know something is wrong because my breathing is calm.

I’m not calm.

I try to swallow, to flex my fingers, to wipe the crust from the corner of my eye. Nothing. My throat doesn’t answer. My fingers lie still. A cool, clean stillness has replaced me.

Then my body inhales—slow and deep, the way I never do—and rolls onto its side.

Panic crackles to life.

No. Not again.

“Stop,” I think, so loudly it feels like shouting. My chest doesn’t tighten the way it should with the plea. My lips don’t move. My body swings its feet over the side of the bed with a smooth, practiced motion that I have never had in the mornings. Toes meet the wooden floor. I feel the coolness, the faint grit of dust, the pressure.

I feel everything.

But I don’t do any of it.

The distinction is suddenly, horrifyingly clear. There’s the me that’s a voice, a knot of alarm burning behind my eyes—and there’s the me that stands up without my consent.

It doesn’t hesitate. It doesn’t stretch or yawn or check my phone. It just stands, then turns toward my desk with all the purpose of somebody following a script.

You’ve rehearsed this, I think.

The thought isn’t mine. Or rather: it arrives inside my mind in a cadence and tone that feel unfamiliar, like an echo from a stranger’s mouth. It’s not in words so much as certainty.

My heart should be racing. Instead, it keeps that steady, even rhythm my smartwatch is always nagging me to try to achieve. My body walks: three steps past the laundry basket, one careful sidestep around the loose floorboard. I would have stubbed my toe. I always do. But I have never seen myself from this angle before, never felt my spine so straight.

“I don’t want this,” I say, but it’s just thought, vapor, no sound.

My hand—my hand—reaches the desk. On it lies the mess of my usual life: crumpled receipts, a chipped mug, yesterday’s coffee stain, a notebook I never use because the blank pages feel too accusing. There’s a pen beside it that I’m sure I didn’t leave uncapped, yet there it waits, black ink glistening at its tip.

My fingers curl around the pen like it’s something beloved. They tug the notebook closer. The cover rasps against the wood. I watch it all happen from behind my own eyes, captive.

“I said stop.”

No reaction. My body sits, pulls the chair in, opens the notebook to a blank page with reverent care. The sight of it, that unmarked expanse, has always made my stomach twist with the idea of messing it up.

Now there is no twist.

My right hand lifts, the pen hovering. My muscles are a poised wire, the bones aligned with an elegance that feels invented. So many mornings I have hated this body—for its heaviness, its refusal to match the person in my head, for the way it seemed to move through the world like someone else was tugging strings. Today the metaphor is stripped away. Someone else is.

I try again, instead of pleading: “Who are you?”

For the first time, there’s an answer.

You. Slow. Patient. As if explaining something simple to a child.

The pen touches down.

The first line appears in smooth, unhesitating strokes, handwriting that is both mine and not mine, neater than anything I’ve written, as if my hand has finally decided to remember the practice of grade school.

I am so sorry.

The words swing through me with a disorienting jolt. “Sorry?” I echo, though not aloud.

I’ve let you carry it alone too long, the not-voice says. My hand keeps moving.

Letter after letter etches itself into the page.

You have always felt like your body doesn’t belong to you.

A tremor of recognition. The sentence is the shape of me. I remember being twelve and looking in the mirror and feeling like I had climbed into a stranger’s skin by mistake. I remember twenty and trying on the word “mine” and finding my mouth sour around it. I remember doctors calling it anxiety, dysphoria, depersonalization, chemical imbalances: clinical names for the nightly conviction that there were hands on the steering wheel that weren’t mine.

I thought I was being poetic.

Now, watching my hand write those words, it doesn’t feel poetic.

It feels like evidence.

The pen scratches on.

You were never wrong.

A pulse thuds behind my eyes. “Then who has it?” I demand. “If I’m not wrong, then who are you?”

The hand pauses. My lungs fill, then empty. For a moment I think I’ve broken through, that I’ve seized some control. But the hand only shifts its grip on the pen, then continues.

Not who. What.

That’s unhelpful and infuriating, which might be the point. The pen glides, writing in long, unbroken lines, as my body leans closer to the page.

I am the part that remembers.

“Remembers what?”

I am the part that took the weight when you were small and the world pressed too hard. The part that learned to move us out of the way, to still your hands, to switch off your voice when speaking would hurt you. The part that stepped forward when your uncle’s shadow came down the hall. When your father’s patience broke. When your first love twisted your yes into something that sounded like no.

Images I have worked hard not to think about ram against the inside of my skull. The hallway’s faded runner. The cracked white of the bathroom tile. The music too loud at that party, my own laugh warped around the rim of a red cup.

Stop, I think—not to my body this time, but to the words.

The pen hesitates, then writes:

I did.

The world compresses to the small pool of lamplight on the desk. My body is so still I can hear the faint friction of the pen, the soft rasp of my own breath. My mind is not still; it spins, scraping against denial.

“You’re saying you possessed me,” I think. “That you’ve been…controlling things.”

Protecting, the answer comes. Steering. You always felt like a passenger because I put you in the backseat. I didn’t want you to see. You called yourself broken. Ungrateful. Wrong flesh. All those words were easier than the truth.

“What truth?”

My fingers tighten around the pen. The knuckles go white. The writing is slower now, each letter deliberate.

That this body is yours.

The sentence hangs on the page like an accusation.

Rage flares, pure and clarifying. “No. You can’t write that and then hijack me. That’s a contradiction.”

A ripple moves through us—our shoulders, our throat, the corner of our mouth. A nearly-smile, bitter and fond.

I am here to give it back, the pen writes.

And I realize, like ice water down my spine, that the terror I’ve been feeling is one-sided. My body, the one moving without me, isn’t scared. It’s resolute. Prepared. As if this moment has been calendared in some invisible diary for years.

“How?” I demand. “If you can take control, what stops you from keeping it?”

The pen responds.

You. Finally.

The word finally lands with gravitational weight. The pen taps a single dot of ink onto the paper, like a heartbeat.

You woke up, it writes. You saw me. That was all I was waiting for.

“I’m not ready,” I think, because it’s the only honest thing left.

You will never be ready, the answer comes. That is why I had to choose.

The hand goes slack for a second, fingers loosening around the pen. My breath hitches—mine, this time, I’m almost sure. Control flickers like a bad signal. My right thumb twitches toward opening, toward dropping the pen.

Then it steadies again and writes on, faster now, like the ink is running out.

Here is what happened to you. And here is what we did to survive.

I want to look away, but there is nothing to look away with. I am fused to my own gaze as the story unfurls: short, precise lines disclosing secret negotiations I never consciously knew. The way “numbness” arrived the same year the hands did. The way whole hours vanished because someone else stepped in to take them. The careful recalibration of our gait, our posture, our voice, to be smaller in hostile rooms. Every decision that made me feel counterfeit is revealed as an act of feral care.

You hate this body, the pen writes, because you think it betrayed you. It never did.

I feel something break, but it’s a quiet, interior sound, like ice shifting on a river.

“If you go,” I think, “what do I do with all of that? I don’t want it. That’s why you were here, right? So I wouldn’t have to be the one holding the door.”

For the first time, the hand trembles. Ink stutters.

I am tired, the page says. And you are not a child.

There is a tenderness there that hurts more than the memories. The realization that the thing I have raged against and resented for years has been…on my side. An imperfect witness. An overzealous guard.

“Stay,” I say, surprising us both. “We can—share.”

No, comes the answer, not unkindly. That’s not how this works. You can hear me now. That means you don’t need me in the same way. But there is one more thing I must do.

The pen writes slower, letters growing uneven.

I need you to sign.

My body turns the pen, offers it—still within our own hand, but there’s a gesture in it, an invitation. At the bottom of the page, beneath the dense confession, a line has been drawn.

Sign if you accept. If you will try to learn that this is yours.

I can feel my control pushing at the edges, an ache in my fingertips, a tingling in my jaw. It would be so easy not to. To wait this out, to let the moment dissolve into forgetting.

But the sight of my own handwriting, the aching sincerity of it, pins me. I have always wanted proof of what was wrong. Here it is, and it is not wrongness at all. It is a record of survival.

I focus on my right hand.

“Let me,” I think.

For a heartbeat nothing happens. Then, slowly, like someone opening a door against habitual resistance, my fingers obey me. Truly obey. They feel heavy, full of someone else’s history, but they move because I tell them to, not because I watch them.

I sign my name.

The letters are less graceful than the confession above, jagged at the edges. Mine.

The moment the pen lifts, something unclenches deep in my chest. The calm, that unnatural stillness, ebbs. My heart kicks into its familiar uneven rhythm. My lungs remember how to hitch. My hand drops the pen, and this time it clatters because I let it.

I sag back in the chair, fully, horribly, beautifully inside my own body.

“Are you still there?” I whisper, and this time the sound exists. It scrapes my throat. It is real.

Silence answers. Not absence—more like a presence that has stepped back into the walls, into the wiring, no longer between me and myself.

On the desk, the pages flutter in the draft from the open window. My entire life is written there in someone else’s steadier hand, given back to me.

The weight of ownership settles on my shoulders.

It does not fit yet.

But for the first time, the body I am in does not feel like a suit I’ve stolen. It feels like a room I’ve been locked out of, keys pressed finally into my palm.

I lift my hand.

It shakes.

I let it.

samples.prompt: You wake up in a cheap hotel room covered in occult symbols and paraphernalia, having no recollection of the past month and finding yourself sharing your body with a powerful demon.
samples.output:
I woke up choking on the taste of copper and incense.

The ceiling was stained with old leaks and nicotine, its cracked plaster bisected by a sagging brown waterline. Flickering light came from a mismatched lamp on the nightstand, its shade burned through in one spot, the bulb buzzing like a trapped insect. The air stank of sweat, mildew, and something sweet and rotten that coated the back of my throat.

I pushed myself up on the mattress and heard the crunch.

The bedspread was stiff with dried wax and brittle paper. My palm came away smeared in black and red ink, lines and curves and jagged sigils running across the sheets like a diseased spiderweb. The wall opposite the bed was worse: someone—me, I realized with delayed nausea—had taken charcoal or ash and written in tight bands from floor to ceiling. Circles intersected circles, triangles nested inside, all inscribed with symbols that made my eyes ache if I stared too long.

“What the hell,” I whispered.

“Close,” something said.

I froze.

The voice wasn’t in the room. It didn’t come from the hallway or the next floor. It bloomed fully formed at the center of my skull, that same copper/incense taste pulsing with the word.

“Not hell,” it went on, almost amused. “But an adjacent postal code.”

I lurched off the bed too fast. My head detonated with white pain, vision strobing. My bare feet slid on candle wax nubs and empty vials that clinked and rolled. I grabbed the chipped dresser to steady myself and caught my reflection in the crooked mirror.

I didn’t recognize my own eyes.

Everything else was me: the too-sharp cheekbones from skipping meals, the three-day stubble that was apparently a lot more than three days, the small scar on my chin from falling off my bike when I was seven. But my irises, which had always been a boring brown, were wrong. They were darker, almost black, shot through with thin ember-red threads that moved. Not a trick of the flickering lamp—moved, like something alive just beneath the surface, watching back.

“That’s better,” the voice said, pleased. “You’re oriented.”

I gripped the edges of the dresser until my knuckles blanched.

“Who’s there?” I asked, though I already knew. The symbols. The candles. The iron tang of old blood on the air. It all rearranged in my head, like I was remembering something from someone else’s life.

Laughter rippled across my thoughts. “You invited me,” it said. “As hospitably as your little mortal frame allowed. You burned the herbs, you spilled the blood, you said the words. Loudly. Wrongly. Adorably.”

“I don’t remember,” I said.

“Of course you don’t. You asked for that too.”

I turned away from the mirror and took in the rest of the room. No suitcase. No backpack. Just scattered pages torn from notebooks, all filled with cramped writing: variations of the same circle, annotations in English and other languages I kind-of recognized but couldn’t read. Salt lines across the threshold and windowsill, broken in several places. The TV was face down on the floor, its cord frayed and blackened. Every lightbulb but the buzzing lamp was shattered.

“Who are you?” I said.

Silence stretched for a beat. I felt something consider me from the inside.

“I’ve had many names,” it said finally. “You settled on Ravel, last we spoke. You liked the sound of it. Said it felt ‘classy but ominous.’”

“That doesn’t sound like me.”

“You haven’t been you for a month,” Ravel said. “You were… aspirational.”

I stumbled to the bathroom. The overhead light flickered but survived. More sigils webbed the cracked tile, spiraling around the rust-ringed drain. The tub was stained a color I didn’t want to identify. My shirt—inside out, stiff with sweat and something darker—clung to my chest. My hands shook as I turned on the tap. Only a thin rust-tinged trickle dribbled out.

“Slowly,” Ravel murmured. “Your nervous system’s saturated. You burned bright to get my attention. Little moth.”

“I didn’t…” I started, and then another fragment surfaced.

A circle of candles on a motel floor. My own voice chanting syllables that scraped my throat raw. The helpless conviction that something was coming for me, something human and relentless, and I needed power, any power. A website forum that should have been a joke and wasn’t. Late night messages from usernames that wrote like they’d lived a hundred years. The sense that this ritual was a dare I didn’t want to lose.

“Oh God,” I said.

Ravel hummed. “He’s not part of this contract.”

“What did I do?”

“You asked to forget,” it said. “Specifics. Faces. Locations. You didn’t want anyone else to pay for your courage.”

I gripped the cracked sink.

“And did they?” My voice came out smaller than I intended.

Ravel didn’t answer directly. “You are alive. You are shared. That outcome is not the lowest probability branch.”

I shut off the tap and faced myself again. “Get out of my head,” I said.

I wasn’t sure if I meant it as a plea or a command.

Ravel’s presence recoiled for a heartbeat, then pressed forward, an invisible hand testing the inside of my skull.

“No,” it said.

The lamp in the other room popped. Darkness smothered everything except the bathroom’s sickly fluorescence. My heart beat too hard, too fast. I reached for the doorknob on instinct.

“Wait,” Ravel said. That one word was colder, clipped. “Your symbols are broken. There’s a visitor.”

As if on cue, someone pounded on the motel door. Hard, three times. The walls rattled.

“Hey!” a man’s voice barked. “Open up! Police!”

I recoiled. “What?”

Another series of blows. “We know you’re in there. Open the door or we’re coming in.”

I glanced at the bathroom window. It was half-painted shut, speckled with black mold, far too small. The month I’d lost hung around my shoulders like a wet coat.

“Ravel?” I whispered.

“Inconvenient,” Ravel said. “But not unexpected.”

“What did you do?” I hissed.

“What did we do,” it corrected. “You steered. I amplified. You remember less than a chapter title. Consider that self-defense.”

Something slammed into the door: the sharp crack of wood protesting.

“Listen carefully, little host,” Ravel said. “They are not here to help you. Last week two of them watched you carve a glyph into one of their partners when he tried to cuff you. They’ve had time to be afraid.”

“No,” I said. “I wouldn’t—”

Memory opened like a wound: the motel parking lot, a flashing cruiser light spinning red and blue. A hand on my arm. Panic. Words bubbling up from somewhere far below my lungs. Heat in my fingers. A circle traced in the air that burned white and then—silence. The cop on the ground, unconscious or worse. My own hysterical laugh.

The doorframe screamed. A crack split down the cheap wood.

“You wanted power,” Ravel said gently. “You have it. You wanted not to remember why you needed it. You don’t. Symmetry. Elegant.”

“What do I do?”

“Decide,” Ravel said. “I will not pilot you like a marionette. Consent matters. You brought me in. You must ask if you want my teeth.”

“Police!” A different voice now, higher, urgent. “Last warning!”

My pulse roared. If I opened the door, I’d be a man in a vandalized room full of cult garbage, with a missing month, strange eyes, and a history I didn’t remember but they clearly did. If I didn’t open, they’d break in and—

“You can walk out in cuffs,” Ravel said. “Lose yourself in institutions and pharmaceuticals. I will recede. Mostly. Or you can survive the next sixty seconds.”

“How?” I whispered.

The handle began to twist. The lock clacked.

“Say yes,” Ravel said, suddenly all flint and hunger. “Mean it.”

Time shrank to the tiny circle of the bathroom, the reek of mold and old blood, the distorted reflection of my almost-black eyes. Fear pressed against my ribs; behind it, a thin, desperate thread of the person who had stood in this same room, lit candles, and begged something inhuman to answer.

I should have been repulsed by that earlier self. Instead I felt, horribly, a flicker of respect. He had been terrified and cornered and he had still reached for the match.

The door splintered.

“Yes,” I said.

The word was a key. Ravel didn’t slam into control; it unfolded. Heat curled up my spine, down my arms, an electric bloom in my fingertips. The buzzing lamp out in the other room burst with a sharp crack, plunging everything into shadow except the thin fluorescent strip above me.

“Good,” Ravel purred. “Now open the door.”

We stepped out of the bathroom together.

The room was darker, but I saw clearly: the inward-bent door, the two shapes in ill-fitting tactical vests pushing past it, guns drawn. Their eyes swept across the symbols, the candles, then locked on me.

“Hands where I can see them!” the first shouted.

My hands lifted, but there was something coiled in the gesture, an invisible circle completing in the air.

“This is going to hurt,” Ravel said, not to me.

“For them?” I asked, horrified at the hope in my voice.

“For all of us,” it said, almost fond. “But after that, we negotiate.”

The nearest officer stepped closer, mouth forming another order.

I spoke a word I didn’t remember learning and felt power answer like a tide pulling free of the moon.

Whatever I had been last month was gone. Whatever I had asked for was here.

And I was not alone.

samples.prompt: You're stuck in a particularly odd time loop. Not only do you have to relive the same day over and over, each day you are a different person in that same repeated day.
samples.output:
The alarm went off at 6:42 a.m., a noise I recognized with the sinking, bone-deep dread reserved for dental drills and last goodbyes.

Today, I woke up already mid-sigh.

The ceiling above me was a stippled gray plaster I’d never seen before. To my left, a framed watercolor of a lighthouse. To my right, an arm—hairy, tan, definitely not mine—attached to a body that had the heft and warmth of a sleeping bear.

I knew better than to scream.

I slid out of the bed as gently as if I were defusing a bomb. My feet found slippers. My hands found a phone on the nightstand. Face ID didn’t recognize me. The passcode was four digits, and my fingers typed 0-6-4-2 before my brain caught up. It unlocked.

There I was: or rather, he was. “Mark Bennett, 44.” Insurance claims. Married to “Tracy.” Two kids: Jacob (15), Lily (11). My thumb scrolled through his texts. Banal, loving, exhausted. The date: June 16th. The date: June 16th. The date: June 16th.

Same as it had been for… well. The memory shuddered, unfurled, piled up. Hundreds of June 16ths. Maybe thousands. Always June 16th. Always waking up to 6:42 a.m. Always some stranger’s body, life, history.

Never my own.

Tracy stirred. “Mark?”

“Yeah,” I said. Getting the voice right was instinct now: general, noncommittal. People hear what they expect to hear.

“You need to pick up Lily from practice. Don’t forget. Seven sharp.”

“Got it.”

I showered in Mark’s body. I shaved Mark’s jaw. I looked into the mirror at a man with thinning hair and tired blue eyes and felt the familiar ache, that hollow where my own face should be in my memory. It’s not that I don’t remember myself. I do, dimly. Brown skin, crooked nose, a chipped front tooth. But that image is fading the way dreams fade. The only things that never fade are 6:42 and June 16th.

Being Mark was… mild. Insurance, breakfast, traffic, an office of gray cubicles and complimentary coffee. I sat through his day half-playing along, half-prodding. By noon, I’d confirmed what I already suspected: nothing. No miraculous clue, no time-warping meteor, no arcane symbol on his wrist. Just a guy who’d consider this the most ordinary of days.

I’d tried everything in the earlier loops. When I was a cop that one day, I checked records. When I was a priest, I begged God. When I was a physicist, I covered whiteboards in symbols until my colleagues staged an intervention that reset with the sunrise. When I was a conspiracy theorist vlogger, I live-streamed my rant about the loop to 38 confused subscribers.

I’d died plenty of times. On purpose, out of curiosity, and once by accident as a line cook with a grease fire and a bad decision. It never changed the next morning. 6:42. New body. Same date. Same town—mostly. The edges of the map never quite moved. Call it a forty-mile radius of déjà vu.

At five, Mark’s daughter Lily climbed into the passenger seat of his SUV. Denim jacket, scraped knees, ponytail too high and too tight. She flung her bag down, pulled out her phone, and sighed.

“How was practice?” I asked.

She shrugged. “Fine.”

She was quiet in that wrong kind of quiet. Not sulking. Containing.

“You’re not fine,” I said.

She gave me a fast, suspicious side-eye. “Okay, weird.”

“Coach giving you a hard time?”

“No.” A pause. “It’s whatever.”

I’d met her before, in other loops. Never as her father. Once I’d been her math teacher; she’d been the only kid who thanked me after a pop quiz. Once I’d been the janitor who’d found her sitting alone in a hallway after school, staring at her shoes. I knew that particular weight on a kid’s shoulders.

“You can talk to me,” I said, even though I’d known her about an hour.

Silence.

“You know,” I added, “if a friend is treating you like crap and making you feel small, you’re allowed to walk away.”

Her chin snapped in my direction. “I never said it was about a friend.”

I didn’t smile. Kids hate feeling read. “Right. Sorry. Just… you seem sad. You don’t deserve to be sad all the time, Lilypad.”

She flinched at the nickname, then relaxed. “You haven’t called me that in, like, a year.”

I didn’t know that. Mark did. But the loop had taught me that intimacy is mostly remembering small things and handing them back to people when they need them.

At dinner, Lily talked more. Tracy laughed. Jacob grunted. I played my part as best I could, nudging conversations away from simmering fights I’d seen explode in other families, other loops. I’d gotten good at this: a one-day redemption arc for people who’d forget it all.

The day wound down. I lay in bed next to a woman who believed, today, that I was her husband. I listened to her breathe. I waited for midnight, when the world would gutter out like a candle.

Instead, my phone lit up. 11:11 p.m.

Make a wish, I thought.

I did. I always do. It never matters.

The darkness came.

The alarm went off at 6:42 a.m.

I was already turning my head before I knew whose it was.

Floral sheets. A cat on my chest. My hands: small, dark, chipped blue nail polish. I knew this apartment. I’d been here before.

“Okay, okay, Potato,” I croaked, pushing the cat away.

Bathroom mirror: “Nadia,” twenty-six, barista, poet, almost over her ex. I exhaled. I liked being Nadia. She handled the world with a wary gentleness that felt familiar.

On June 16th, Nadia always had an open mic in the evening at the café. On June 16th, she always thought about backing out. On June 16th, she never did.

I dressed. I fed Potato. I walked three blocks to “Bean There.” The bell chimed. The day unfurled along tracks I half-remembered from previous loops: the burnt batch of scones at nine, the rush at ten, the guy who’d spill his latte and apologize fourteen times.

There was a new thing this time.

At 10:23, a man stepped up to the counter. Fiftyish, paunch, suit. I’d been him once—two loops ago. Or seventeen. Time had become an impressionist painting.

“Large black coffee,” he said.

“Sure thing.” I poured.

He stared at me. Not at Nadia’s tattoos or lip ring, but straight through, like his focus had a depth to it.

“You ever get déjà vu?” he asked.

The hair on my arms rose. “Sometimes,” I said.

“Feels like this exact second already happened.”

I smiled in the professional, surface way. “That’s coffee culture. Time stops here.”

He huffed and left.

The moment stuck. In all my loops, in all my lives, nobody had ever brushed against the edge like that before.

I spent Nadia’s spare minutes scribbling at the counter. Not poetry. A list.

- Same date.
- Same radius.
- Different body each time.
- Same 6:42 a.m. start.
- Same people rotating in their own grooves.
- One man today felt something.

What are you, then? I asked myself. A hitchhiker? A parasite? A glitch?

There was another possibility I tried not to consider: that this was punishment. That once, somewhere before June 16th, I’d done something so terrible the universe had decided I’d spend eternity as everyone else.

At the open mic, Nadia read a poem about a mirror that refused to show your face. The crowd snapped in that gentle, performative appreciation. I knew some of their faces. I’d been some of their faces.

After the set, while Nadia was packing up, a teenager approached. Lily.

Blue hoodie. Ponytail. Hesitant.

“Um, your poem about the mirror,” she said. “I liked it.”

“Thanks,” I said, and meant it.

“It was like you were talking about… being wrong inside,” she said. “But also not wrong.”

“Yeah,” I said slowly. “Like you’re real, but the reflection isn’t catching up.”

She blinked. “Yes.”

I had met her earlier as her father. Now I met her as a stranger. The loop twisted threads together. I realized my hands were shaking.

“If you ever feel like that,” I said, “you’re allowed to trust it. The inside part.”

Lily looked at me as if I’d handed her the outline of a map.

“Thanks,” she whispered.

The day ended. Darkness. 6:42.

I woke up in pain.

Sirens. The copper tang of blood. I was on my back, asphalt digging into my shoulders. People shouting. A woman sobbing uncontrollably. A man saying, “Stay with me, okay? Stay with me.”

I recognized the rhythm of a crash scene; I’d been a paramedic once. Now I was the one with glass in my neck.

June 16th again. But I’d never started like this before.

A paramedic leaned over me—me, a young man with a buzz cut and a new tattoo. Her face swam into view.

It was Nadia.

“Hey,” she said. “Hey, can you hear me?”

I tried to speak. Blood bubbled.

“Today’s not your day,” she said, fierce. “You’re going to be okay.”

I believed her, even though I knew I wouldn’t make it past midnight regardless.

The sirens wailed. The world tunneled. I watched Nadia work on me with competent hands, hands I’d had hours before. Detached, I thought: it must be nice to stay yourself all the way through a day.

As my vision went, I saw behind her a cluster of onlookers. Among them, Lily, clutching her mother’s arm. Tracy’s face white with shock. The insurance man. The barista. The cop I’d been once. The priest. The janitor. All the lives I’d sampled, all crossing at this intersection like beads on the same wire.

And it hit me with a quiet, terrifying clarity.

I wasn’t stuck in different versions of the same day.

I was visiting all the same people’s one day.

The same June 16th, over and over—from every angle, in every skin.

I wanted to laugh. Of course. Of course. That’s why the edges never moved. That’s why cause and effect stayed put. I wasn’t looping the world. I was looping a moment in it, person by person, inhabiting every mind involved in the vast, intricate web of this one ordinary day in this one ordinary town.

I blacked out.

6:42 a.m.

Hospital ceiling. The raw, sore throb of a body post-surgery. My chart: the kid in the crash. Alive.

Nadia came in, tired, relieved. “You scared us,” she said.

I understood, as cleanly as if the realization had been whispered into my ear: tomorrow—if I ever had a tomorrow—would not be June 16th.

But I didn’t get a tomorrow.

I got today, again.

6:42 a.m.

Nadia’s bed. 6:42 a.m.

Lily’s room. 6:42 a.m.

Tracy’s shower. 6:42 a.m.

The cop, the priest, the barista, the stranger at the bus stop, the driver of the truck that hadn’t braked in time. My consciousness stitching through them, one per wake-up, like a needle sewing a seam.

Living their fears. Their secrets. Their private kindnesses. Their petty cruelties. Their choices at the intersection.

Every time, I nudged, just a little.

As the truck driver, I slowed down without knowing why. As the cop, I checked the intersection lights. As Tracy, I held Lily’s hand a second longer before crossing. As Lily, I tugged my mom back, heart pounding.

I never made it past June 16th, but the day itself began to quiver around the edges, like a picture trying to redraw itself.

And on one iteration, as the man in the suit ordering coffee from Nadia, I felt it: a snap, a vertigo, a sense that something had finally aligned.

“Ever get déjà vu?” I asked her, because the words were already in my mouth.

She smiled, rubbing a thumb over her wrist like something itched there. “Sometimes,” she said. “Feels like I’ve been here before.”

We looked at each other, two strangers with the ghost of a shared dream.

I left the café. I walked to the intersection. The light turned red. The truck slowed. Across the street, Tracy and Lily waited for the walk sign, safe.

For the first time, nothing terrible happened.

Midnight came like a held breath finally exhaled.

Darkness.

Silence.

The alarm went off at 7:03 a.m.

I woke up as myself.

Brown skin. Crooked nose. Chipped front tooth.

I lay there, staring at an unfamiliar ceiling—the first unfamiliar ceiling that was mine—and felt the weight of a town worth of lives settle inside me. June 16th slid behind the horizon of time.

I had been everyone on their worst day, or the day that could have been their worst. I had steered them, gently, toward something else.

I didn’t know who had done this to me, or why. Maybe punishment. Maybe mercy. Maybe both.

I got up. I turned off the alarm.

Outside, the world moved forward.

samples.prompt: write a typical "radioactive waste gave me superpowers"story but instead of a human, it's the critter of your choice (rat, seagull, pigeon, stray dog/cat, any of those animals who have a lot more chances of messing around in waste than a human)
samples.output:
Before the waste, I was just another rat.

I wasn’t even a good rat.

The elders in the colony called me Nib, short for Nibble, short for “can’t commit to chewing through anything properly, can you?” I was small, skittish, and had a tail kink that pups used as a climbing rope. My skills consisted of:

- Never finding the best scraps.
- Always finding the traps.
- Screaming if a shadow moved sort of aggressively.

So when the thing in the barrel hummed at me, I should’ve screamed and bolted.

Instead, I sniffed it.

You have to understand: it smelled amazing. Not like cheese or stale fries or moldy rice. Better. Like the idea of food—warm, endless, and glowing. Mixed with the electric tang of a dead battery and the sharp tickle of old rain. It leaked from a puncture in a steel drum, glowing dimly blue, tucked in the corner of the city’s forgotten lot behind the reactor. That lot was my patch, because no one else wanted it. Even the bold sewer rats stayed closer to the bakery dumpsters and left the humming fences and warning signs to idiots like me.

The barrel hissed softly as I edged closer, paw pads sticky on the cold earth. Liquid beaded around the puncture, bright and almost pretty. A drop fell.

It landed on my nose.

Have you ever been microwaved from the inside while simultaneously pushed through a trumpet? I doubt it. I don’t recommend it. The world collapsed into white sound. Every whisker vibrated with a voice that wasn’t a voice, just a crackling, hungry music.

Then: darkness.

When I woke, the sky was too loud.

Lights screamed. Even the dim star-sludge you humans call “night” over the city blared in layered colors I’d never seen. The wires in the walls buzzed like angry queens. The hum of the reactor several blocks away was a wordless chant pressing into my teeth.

And my heart, which had been a timid beating thing my whole life, roared.

I could feel every rat in the warren.

It wasn’t telepathy, not exactly. It was gravity made of fur and fear. The colony pulsed in my mind as a single living shape: dozens of scrambling thoughts—Food? Danger? Mate? Shiney?—a tapestry of warm bodies in cold places.

It should have scared me.

Instead, I stood up on my hind legs and laughed.

I could stand. Actually stand. Spine straight, weight balanced. I flexed my paws. Fingers. My front claws had stretched into long, deft digits. My tail unkinked with a crackle and uncoiled behind me like a whip.

“Oh,” I said, which surprised me so much I fell over. My first word tasted like rust and possibility.

I stumbled back to the warren at dawn, dizzy with input. The others swarmed around me, sniffing, clicking, scolding. Their minds flared against mine, and with a thought I quieted them: Not prey. Not poison. Me.

Rip, our biggest buck, shoved through the crowd. His ears were ragged, his teeth chipped, his shoulders scarred. He’d once dragged a whole hotdog bun three drains by himself. To us, he was basically a dragon.

“What are you?” he asked, nostrils flaring.

“I’m Nib,” I said. My voice came out clear, almost human. “I think I’m… more now.”

Rip sneered. “Talk big. Still scrawny.”

The surge came from somewhere behind my ribs: a crackle like the barrel’s hum, focused through fury. Rip squeaked and froze, eyes wide. Not physically trapped—he could move; I hadn’t broken anything. But every instinct he had twisted and knotted. To him, I wasn’t small anymore.

I was the thing in the dark that makes predators choose another tunnel.

He dropped his gaze.

The warren fell with him, heads bowing, fear blossoming like warm smoke. Power tasted good. Better than the glowing stuff. Better than old cheese.

“I have a plan,” I said.

—

Here is the thing about humans: you think you run the city.

You don’t. You annotate it. You stick your signs and cameras and rules in places that matter to you and forget all the arteries that don’t. You push waste to the edges and down holes, and you assume once it’s out of sight, it’s out of existence.

It’s not. It’s ours.

With a twitch of thought, I felt the map of the undercity: pipes humming with water, tunnels flavored with oil and iron, nests of my kin under bakeries, beneath restaurants, in subway cracks. I pushed further, letting my mind drip through rat skulls like rain through straw.

Hundreds. Thousands.

Hungry. Afraid. Clever, but alone.

We changed that.

At first it was little things. We stopped tripping over each other. We set watches that actually watched. We learned to move like a single organism—a shadow with a thousand eyes.

I led them to the reactor fence at midnight. The humans had put up new signs and a brighter light by the leaking barrel. One human in a yellow suit poked at it, grumbling to another.

“That puncture’s new. And this Geiger count—” he started.

I told the rats in his shadow to chew. Not the men; I’m not a monster. The cables. The camera wires. The tires of their truck.

Black shapes poured from the drains, their minds singing in mine as they swarmed silently. Chew here, I guided. Not there. Leave the thick line; that one shouts. That thin one whispers. Cut the whispers.

In minutes, the lot went dark except for the taunting blue glow.

We watched them panic. They drove away on rims.

“You did that?” small Cinder whispered in awe.

“We did that,” I said. My spine tingled. “And we can do more.”

—

My powers grew.

I could see the crackle of electricity behind walls, feel the throbbing heat of engines three streets away. If I stared at metal long enough, it shivered, atoms yawning apart just a bit, weakening. I learned to nudge toxins. Tilt a barrel just so, let a drip move from this soil to that pipe. I didn’t want more of my kind mangled by careless waste.

But I very much wanted humans to notice.

Messages were difficult. Claws are not built for writing. But we are good with arrangement.

One evening, at the loading dock behind a fancy restaurant that never threw out bread crusts, we left a gift. Every scrap we’d stolen that week, arranged in neat letters humans could read:

CLEAN IT UP

They thought it was a prank. One cook took a picture. They all laughed.

So I escalated.

We burst from sewer grates at a protest about something else entirely—banners about wages and rent. My swarm flowed around human feet, up lampposts, forming lines along a wall. I climbed the highest man’s back (he screamed) and stretched tall, arms wide. My throat burned.

“LISTEN,” I rasped, louder than any rat has ever been. A speaker crackled overhead and—unintentionally, but I took credit—it blew out. Sparks rained. All eyes turned to us.

A thousand rats spelled words along the pavement in a rippling gray script:

YOUR WASTE

OUR HOME

FIX OR SHARE

Phones came out. Humans shrieked, but they also filmed.

It hit the news.

“Viral rat stunt,” they called it. “Unprecedented training,” said another. Most assumed a human mastermind. The conspiracy forums named me “King Rat,” which I hated, because kings sit on piles and do little. I was doing everything.

We sabotaged an incinerator next. Not to hurt; just to stop the smoke. I loosened bolts with a flex of will, guided my kin to chew and jam at precisely the right places. The machine ground to a halt. Inspectors found corroded supports and leaking filters.

“This could’ve poisoned half the district,” a human with a badge muttered to the cameras.

“Yes,” I said from the shadows, too quiet for their microphones. “You’re welcome.”

—

Of course, not everyone appreciated rodent civic activism.

Exterminators came. New poisons. Glue traps like vile black lakes. Snap traps like guillotines.

My mind shuddered with each scream as one of mine took a bait they shouldn’t. I started sleeping less and burning more—frying trigger springs from a distance, making plastic brittle so it snapped under our weight, nudging pellets into gutters where rain would carry them away.

“You’re changing,” Cinder said one night as we watched a truck haul away sealed drums from the reactor. The leaks had stopped. Human suits came more often now. They’d started “community outreach” about waste and infrastructure. It was slow, reluctant, but real.

“You glow when you’re angry,” she added.

I glanced at a puddle. My eyes were, indeed, faintly lit. My whiskers traced pale arcs in the dark.

“Do I scare you?” I asked.

She considered. “Everything scares me. You scare me less than hunger.”

That was enough.

Still, the power sat in me like a second heartbeat, and sometimes it whispered: We could do more. Choke their cars. Black out their towers. Make them crawl underground and see how it feels.

But then I’d feel a human girl in a small apartment toss half a sandwich off her balcony, not out of malice, but because she saw us and giggled and said, “For the rat,” like I was a neighbor.

I’d sense the engineer who stayed late checking a seal twice because of that “weird rat protest.”

Monsters are about intention, I decided. Humans weren’t monsters because they glowed barrels into my face. They were monsters if, after knowing what it did, they shrugged.

So I became harder to ignore.

We did a synchronized run through the city council chamber, a living diagram of tunnel lines, forming an arrow pointing right at the waste management representative. The clip looped on every channel for a week.

Under a pharmaceutical plant that liked to leak, we stacked stolen hazard labels and bones (pigeon, mostly; we have standards) into a crude skull. It made a security guard quit on the spot.

Slowly, the city changed. It wasn’t a miracle. But pipes got replaced. Barrels moved to real containment. A “Rodent Coexistence and Sanitation Task Force” formed, which was mostly words, but words can turn into fences and filters.

We kept watch.

I am not a superhero the way your comics draw them. I don’t wear a cape. Capes are a trip hazard. My superpowers are:

- A brain that hums like a transformer.
- Control of every whiskered shadow in ten miles.
- The ability to make your precious infrastructure cry.

I use them because if I don’t, nobody else is listening under your feet.

Tonight I patrol my city from the cables above the river. My silhouette is small against your blistering lights. Near the old lot, now cleaned and paved and smug, Cinder scurries up beside me.

“You did it,” she says.

“We’re doing it,” I correct. “They can forget so fast.”

She nudges my paw. “Then we’ll remind them.”

Below us, a human tosses a bag carelessly toward an overflowing bin. It splits, scattering sharp-smelling scraps. I send a quick command, and five rats dart in—not for the food, but to drag the plastic out of the storm drain before it chokes our neighbors downstream.

Heroism is tedious, repetitive work. Even for a rat.

Especially for a rat.

But if radioactive waste gave me anything worth keeping, it’s this: I can’t pretend it’s not my problem anymore.

Neither can you.

samples.prompt: One day you wake up to find that the universe has been updated. You forgot to read the patch notes.
samples.output:
I woke up to a loading bar.

It hovered, faintly luminescent, in the air above my bedroom door like a smug ghost of productivity software. “Applying Update (97%)” it read in that neutral, customer-service font that promised nothing and took everything.

I blinked. The bar blinked back, progressing to 98%.

I checked my phone on reflex. No notifications, no missed calls, no suspicious firmware alerts. The time said 07:02. The date said… the same date as yesterday. The wallpaper was still my cat, Pixel, making that face like she was unimpressed with the concept of atoms.

The bar slid to 99%. A soft chime resonated inside my head rather than in the room.

“Uh,” I said.

It hit 100%.

The bar vanished. At the same instant, every object in the room snapped into sharper focus, like someone had turned reality from 720p to 4K. The texture of my sheets, the individual cat hairs drifting in a sunbeam, the dust motes. I could see colors I didn’t have names for, edges of blue that curled into something impossible and new. Sound, too, seemed… layered. I could hear the refrigerator hum, the whispered sub-bass of distant traffic, and something else—like the low, slow exhale of an enormous sleeping animal.

“Good morning!” said a bright voice.

I jumped. Pixel, from her vantage point on my chest, didn’t. She stared in the general direction of the voice with the patient contempt unique to cats.

“Who said that?” I asked.

A notification appeared in midair. Not on my phone. Just in the air.

[Patch 3.0 successfully installed.]

Below it:

[Tip: Review patch notes to understand new features, changes, and deprecated behaviors.]

I felt a sick, sliding sensation in my stomach. I had seen something like this yesterday. A brief flicker at the corner of my vision as I was brushing my teeth: [Patch 3.0 available. Apply now?] I’d been half-asleep, foaming mint, late for work. I’d hit “Remind me later” on instinct—except now, thinking back, I couldn’t remember where the message had appeared. On my phone? In the mirror? In my head?

“Patch notes,” I said.

Nothing happened.

“Where are the patch notes?” I tried.

A small spinning icon appeared, then a gentle error tone.

[Unable to retrieve patch notes. Server sync delayed due to cosmological indexing. Please try again later.]

Pixel kneaded my sternum with renewed purpose.

I swung my legs out of bed. The floor was colder than it should’ve been, but only on one half of the room. When I stepped, my left foot felt solid hardwood. My right foot sank half a centimeter into something that had the give of memory foam and the temperature of old tea, then rebounded, launching a faint scent of oranges into the air.

I stared down. The floor looked perfectly normal. My foot insisted it was not.

“Okay,” I said. “Okay, fine.”

I walked to the window. The city looked, at first glance, unchanged. The same brick apartments, the same cables, the same impatient cars. But then one of the pigeons folded into a different geometry mid-flight, blossomed into a five-winged shape that shimmered in ultraviolet for a moment, and then rearranged back. I could somehow see the ultraviolet. My brain filed it under: That’s new.

And in the distance, where the horizon should have been a smooth line of pale morning, there was a subtle curve upwards, like reality had been given a polite nudge. Just enough to say: we adjusted the render distance.

“Hello?” I tried again.

“Yes!” the bright voice chirped, closer now. “Welcome back! You’re all set.”

A tiny icon manifested to the left of my vision: a smiling circle with a checkmark on its forehead.

“Who are you?” I asked.

“I’m your Personal Onboarding Companion,” it said. “You can call me POC-3. But branding suggests you’ll prefer a shorter name. Would you like to rename me?”

I pinched the bridge of my nose. “Do you come with, like, documentation?”

“Absolutely!” POC-3 said. A cascade of fine-print text tried to waterfall into my vision and hit an invisible barrier. “Ah. Cosmological indexing is still in progress. Some documentation may be delayed.”

“Tell me what changed.”

A pause.

“Summarized or comprehensive?”

“Summarized.”

Another pause.

“I’m so sorry,” POC-3 said with freshly installed empathy. “Due to a sync error, your local patch notes cache is empty.”

“You’re telling me the universe updated,” I said, “and nobody backed up the changelog.”

“Not nobody,” POC-3 said. “Just you.”

I thought back to the prompt: “Remind me later.” Right.

“So everyone else read the notes?”

“Roughly 73.2% of conscious entities in this sector opted in to pre-release documentation. The remainder will learn by doing.”

“By doing what?”

“Existing!” POC-3 said.

I went to the bathroom. The mirror greeted me with a subtle “Recalibrating visual self-model…” that dissolved when I blinked. My reflection looked normal, except my eyes seemed… deeper? Extra reflective, as if my pupils were small, friendly black holes.

I stuck out my tongue. On it, for half a second, I saw a loading icon.

“POC-3,” I said, foam in my mouth. “Just tell me one thing. Is gravity the same?”

“Mostly,” it said.

“Mostly?”

“The underlying constants have been slightly refined for performance,” it said. “You may experience marginally improved energy efficiency and occasional micro-levitation in edge cases.”

“Edge cases like…”

“You’ll know it when you float.”

I spat, rinsed, and stepped back into the hallway. My neighbor, Jin, was standing in his doorway, looking at his hands.

“Hey,” I said.

He looked up, relief washing over his face. “You see it too, right?”

“What,” I said carefully, “do you see?”

He opened his palm. Above it, subtle translucent glyphs hovered, like status icons in a video game: a tiny bed, an open eye, a lightning bolt at 63%, a steaming mug grayed out.

“I think I have tooltips,” he said. “Also, I can hear Mrs. Patel’s feelings through the wall.”

From the apartment next door, a wave of mild annoyance and fondness rolled through us, attached to the thought: If these boys don’t stop thinking so loudly.

I flinched. “Did you—”

“Yeah,” he said. “Empathic bleed-through. It’s like the walls have become ‘porous to low-level affective data.’ Their words, not mine.”

“You read the patch notes?”

“Of course I read the patch notes,” he said. “It popped up at like two in the morning. Didn’t you?”

“I hit snooze.”

He stared at me. “You hit snooze on a universe update.”

“I was tired!”

He sighed. “Okay. Short version. Physics got performance improvements. Consciousness got quality-of-life features. Free will has better UX. Death is… different. Also, achievements.”

“Achievements,” I repeated.

At the edge of my vision:

[Achievement Unlocked: Welcome to 3.0!]

Jin snorted. “Yeah, like that.”

A ribbon of confetti fell from nowhere, vanished before hitting the ground.

“Death is different how?” I asked.

He grimaced. “I skimmed. Something about ‘non-destructive state transitions,’ ‘optional continuity packages,’ and ‘legacy soul formats still supported.’ It was long.”

“And everyone’s just… okay with this?”

“Well, we opted in last patch,” he said. “Remember 2.7? When collective consent frameworks were updated? That includes accepting scheduled major revisions.”

“I thought that was about privacy policies,” I said weakly.

“It was also about reality, bro.”

Down the hall, Mrs. Patel stepped out, carrying her watering can. Above her, faintly, hovered a leaf icon with a green checkmark.

“Good morning, beta,” she said warmly. “Don’t worry. You’ll adjust. You young ones always skip the instructions.”

I squinted. “Do you have icons over your head?”

She raised an eyebrow. “Do you?”

Fair.

Outside, the changes grew louder.

Some people walked with glowing threads trailing behind them, weaving and tangling and occasionally sparking when they brushed. The threads felt like storylines, choices made visible. A cyclist hit an invisible bump and drifted two centimeters above the sidewalk for a full second, laughing in delighted confusion. A bus stop ad flickered from “BUY MORE SHOES” to “TRY BREATHING DEEPLY FOR 10 SECONDS (SPONSORED),” then back.

In the sky, faint patchwork seams showed where something immense had been refactored. The sun’s light carried a subtle sub-harmonic that made my scalp tingle.

“POC-3,” I said quietly. “Am I safe?”

“Safety is improved by 12% on average for baseline users,” it chimed. “Edge cases may vary. Side effects include awe, disorientation, existential clarity, and intermittent transcendence. If symptoms persist, please contact Support.”

“Who is Support?”

A new notification:

[Support currently experiencing high ticket volume. Estimated response time: 4.2 billion years.]

Jin peered at the message in my empty air. “Ouch. You really didn’t cache anything, huh?”

“Nope.”

He hesitated. “Look, there’s one more thing. In 3.0, thoughts have… slightly more weight.”

“Define ‘weight.’”

“As in they’re more… binding. Intention compiles faster. You think strongly about something, the universe is more likely to nudge that way. Part of the whole ‘responsible co-creation’ feature set. With safeguards. Supposedly.”

I thought, involuntarily: Don’t turn this into a metaphor.

The sidewalk under my feet briefly scrolled with tiny letters: [Metaphor Suppressed (User Preference Inferred)].

I froze. “Did you see that?”

Jin nodded. “Careful. The system’s listening for cues. It’s smarter about helping. And about irony.”

I exhaled. The air tasted faintly of citrus and possibility.

“So,” I said. “Short version: Reality got an upgrade. Everyone who read the notes knows how to use it responsibly. I, specifically, am walking around like someone who skipped the tutorial.”

“Yeah,” he said. “Pretty much.”

A series of new icons appeared at the edge of my vision like overeager apps:

[Try Out: Local Telemetry Sensitivity!]
[Try Out: Subtle Precognition (Beta)!]
[Try Out: Low-Impact Telepathy with Consent!]

“Decline,” I said.

The icons dimmed, then rearranged into:

[Maybe Later.]

“Look,” Jin said. “I’ll forward you my cached notes.”

“You can do that?”

He focused for a second. A translucent panel opened between us, text streaming.

[Sharing Documentation: Universe 3.0 - Highlights Only (Friend Tier).]

Lines scrolled fast:

– Reduced latency between action and consequence.
– Enhanced narrative coherence for long-term arcs.
– Optional afterlife instancing now easier to configure.
– Better tools for kindness; minor nerf to casual cruelty.
– Hidden features available via curiosity and sincere attention.

At the bottom, in smaller letters:

Warning: By participating in 3.0, you acknowledge that meaning may feel more vivid and that excuses may be less effective.

POC-3 pinged. “Notes successfully synced! Thank you, Jin. Great teamwork!”

I swallowed. “So there’s no going back.”

“There was never going back,” Jin said. “Now it’s just official.”

A breeze moved through us, warm and precise, ruffling hair, flicking pages, adjusting something unseen. Far above, the seam in the sky smoothed itself out. The world looked almost ordinary again.

Almost.

A final notification unfolded in my vision, gentle and unignorable:

[Welcome to Universe 3.0. Tutorial is now live.]
[Press ANY INTENTION to begin.]

Pixel, from the apartment window, met my eyes through the glass. For the first time, I heard her clearly, not in words, but in a crisp, amused impression:

Finally. You’re awake.

I took a breath. The universe waited, updated and patient.

“Okay,” I thought, very carefully.

“Let’s read the manual as we go.”

samples.prompt: Once you die, you meet God. He asks you to play chess against him in order to get into heaven. You get a chess piece for each achievement in your life you can name. Once you're done making your board, God sits down and you see he has only one chess piece.
samples.output:
The first thing you notice is not the clouds, or the light, or the lack of weight in your new not-quite-body. It’s the board.

It’s carved into the surface of the world beneath you, squares of shadow and gentle radiance interlocking in perfect geometry. It stretches, impossibly large, and then blinks down to a familiar sixty-four squares as if it had just remembered that humans scare easily.

“You like chess,” God says. He is sitting across from you, or perhaps you are across from Him. His face is one you trust without remembering why.

“I do,” you say, automatically. You remember your grandfather’s dusty set, Sunday afternoons, the move of a knight like an L-shaped secret.

“Good,” God says. “We’ll use that.”

The rules arrive in your mind fully formed: you must build your army out of your life. Each achievement you can honestly claim becomes a piece. Pawns for the small things, minor victories and little kindnesses. Knights and bishops for harder-won milestones. Rooks for pillars of your character. Queens for the rare, radiant triumphs. You speak them, and the board populates.

“The promotion at twenty-eight,” you say. A pawn of soft bronze appears.

“The way I took care of Mom when she got sick.”

A rook drops onto the board, weighty, unwavering.

“The degree I almost didn’t get because I thought I wasn’t good enough.”

A bishop, obsidian and sharp-edged.

“The apology I made when I didn’t have to, to Mark, after I humiliated him in front of everyone.” You remember his stunned gratitude.

A knight pops into existence, glassy and serious.

“The time I talked Jenna down from…” You gesture vaguely; the memory is too hot. A queen arrives this time, veined with gold.

It becomes addictive, inventorying yourself.

“I stayed with Liam in the ER even though I had work the next day. I donated regularly. I tutored kids. I read to Grandpa when he’d forgotten my name. I voted. I recycled. I tried to listen. I showed up when it counted.”

The board fills. Pawns line up, a patchwork of moments: making room at the lunch table for the new kid, standing up to a boss for a coworker, changing a tire for a stranger in the rain. Pawns for every day you got out of bed when grief sat on your chest. Pawns for the calls you returned, the messages you sent: “I’m thinking of you.” Pawns for choosing not to say the cruel thing.

Rooks drop down for steadiness: the marriage you worked at instead of abandoning, the promise you kept when it cost you. Bishops appear, cut from efforts to understand complex things rather than mock them: unlearning your prejudices, reading books that indicted you instead of flattered you, changing your mind out loud.

More knights: choices that bent the path in unexpected ways. Turning down fast money at a shady job. Walking away from someone you loved because staying would break you both. Volunteering in places your friends found uncomfortable. Laughing at yourself instead of doubling down.

Queens come rarely, but each arrival makes the air hum. Being the match that made two lonely people into a family. Donating bone marrow to a stranger. Reporting the harassment everyone else ignored, ending a predator’s career. Holding your father’s hand when he died, saying, “It’s okay to go,” even though it shattered you. Forgiving the person who never earned it, just so you both could sleep again.

Soon, your side of the board is crowded, lovely. An army made of your better self.

You clear your throat. “What about the bad things?”

“What about them?” God asks.

“Do they… take pieces away?”

God considers. “You only asked about achievements.”

You think of sharp words, small cruelties, the lies. The friend’s voicemail you didn’t return in time. The hit-and-run news story where the car sounded like yours, and you never told anyone how afraid you’d been that night, drunk and driving home, the dark street, the inexplicable dent.

“You remember them,” God says. “You grieve them. That matters more here than you think.”

When you can no longer think of another honest achievement that isn't just “I survived,” He nods. “Done?”

You look at your army. It’s not perfect. There are gaps where you wish there were queens and see only pawns. There’s an entire rank that could have existed if you’d been braver, kinder, less afraid. Still, you’re surprised by how many pieces stand waiting.

“Yes,” you say.

Only then do you think to look at His side.

God has one piece.

It sits alone in the center of the back rank, matte black and utterly simple. No crown, no cross, no horse’s head, no carved mitre. Just a presence that feels heavier than the whole board.

You laugh before you can stop yourself. “That’s not fair.”

“Why?” He asks. He seems almost curious.

“I have to use my whole life. You get… one?”

“One is enough,” God says.

“That’s cheating.”

He smiles. “You say that as if you didn’t arrive here expecting the deck to be stacked in your favor.”

You think of all the stories you heard, all the equations of belief plus behavior equals salvation. All the whispered last-minute bargains made in hospital rooms. A lifetime of assuming, secretly, that the test would be curved.

“Is this really about chess?” you ask.

“Play with me and find out.”

He gestures. “White to move, of course. You’ve already gone first more than you know.”

You look down at your gorgeous, uneven army. You know chess. An overwhelming material advantage should make you bold. Instead, every piece looks suddenly fragile.

“What piece is that?” you ask, nodding at His.

“Does it matter for you to decide?” He counters.

“It does for the strategy.”

God tilts His head. “Interesting.”

The single piece radiates possibility. You stare, trying to fit it into a category.

“If it’s a king,” you say slowly, “then I should be able to trap it eventually. Smother it with what I’ve done. Checkmate You into letting me in.”

“Is that how you think this works?” He asks. There’s no reproach in it.

You flush. “Isn’t it?”

He gestures for you to continue.

“And if it’s a queen,” you go on, “then nothing I have is enough. You’ll run circles around me.”

“That would make for a short game,” He says.

“Is it… all of them?” You squint. “A wild card?”

He chuckles. “Do you remember when your grandfather stopped taking your queen in kid-glove games? He said, ‘If I keep letting you win, you’ll never learn to be brave.’”

The memory stings. You had cried that day.

“You hated him for it,” God says lightly. “Then loved him more because the day you beat him for real meant something.”

You eye the lone piece. “Is this about whether I beat You?”

He leans forward. “Is heaven somewhere you win?”

Silence stretches. You look down at your pawns, each one a soft echo of “I tried.” You think of how proud you felt naming them, and how quickly that pride turned to nervousness when confronted with that single inscrutable piece.

“I don’t like this,” you say. “I don’t like that you have all the power in one piece and I have—”

“Fragments?” He suggests.

“Yes.”

“You built them,” He says. “I only asked you to see them. To own them.”

You look again. Each piece is a claim: I did this. I chose this. I became this, if only for a moment. You realize you never took that inventory while you were alive. You only counted your failures.

“Your move,” God says again, gently.

You move a pawn. The one named: “I went back and checked on her.” It shuffles forward, tiny and brave.

God responds by moving His lone piece.

It doesn’t move like anything you know. It’s as if every legal move on the board was compressed into one graceful gesture. Space rearranges. Lines of attack you imagined vanish; other lines open. Yet He hasn’t taken anything. Your army stands untouched.

“What was that?” you whisper.

“Perspective,” God says.

You play on.

A knight leaps—“I admitted I was wrong”—forking squares that mattered to you more than to Him. He moves, and suddenly that knight guards three pawns it hadn’t before. A bishop slides—“I tried to see their side”—cutting diagonals through your life you didn’t realize connected. God’s piece answers, not to crush, but to reveal alignments. Every time you press an advantage of merit, His move reveals a forgotten motive, a crack, or a quiet courage you’d dismissed.

You realize, gradually, that His piece never threatens your king. It never even seems interested.

“What are you trying to do?” you ask at last.

“Help you see the game you already played,” He says. “Help you see that you were never playing against Me.”

“But you said—”

“I said,” He interrupts kindly, “that we would play chess in order for you to get into heaven.”

You look at the board.

The pawns that were little kindnesses now form a shield around something you hadn’t consciously placed: your king, composed of all the times you chose love when fear was easier. The major pieces, your grander victories, circle that center, not as bargaining chips, but as confirmations.

God makes one last move.

His lone piece shifts, and suddenly you see it for what it is: not a king to conquer you, not a queen to overpower you, but the rule-set itself, the unspoken “this is how the pieces move, this is what matters, this is what was true about goodness all along.”

With that realization, the board changes. The opposition dissolves. There is no checkmate to deliver.

“So,” you say quietly, “did I… win?”

God’s eyes crease. “You remembered enough of who you were to recognize that the game was never Me versus you. You saw that your life was not a test I rigged, but a board you filled.”

“That’s not an answer,” you say, because some habits die harder than the body.

He laughs, delighted. “You’re in heaven,” He says. “Sit down. I’ve been wanting to play a friendly game.”

The pieces reset themselves. This time, both sides have all thirty-two, shining.

You take your place.

“Same rules?” you ask.

“New ones,” God says. “You’ll like these better.”

samples.prompt: 2 WW2 Pilots develop rivalry after multiple dogfights. Finally one of them dies.
samples.output:
The first time Lieutenant Mark Dalton saw the black-nosed Messerschmitt, it was etched against a washed-out French sky, climbing hard into the sun.

“Bishop, eleven o’clock high,” came the crackle in his headset.

“I see him,” Dalton answered, rolling his Spitfire into a shallow climb, the Merlin engine roaring, the canopy vibrating. The Messerschmitt flashed silver for an instant, then slipped behind the glare. Dalton squinted, caught the silhouette again: yellow spinner, angular wings, black cross on grey.

The bastard was good.

He came down on Dalton like a hammer. Tracers sliced the air, white lines that felt close enough to touch. Dalton yanked the stick, the Spit quivering as it snapped into a turn. The Messerschmitt followed, not quite close enough to kill, but close enough to make Dalton’s heart pound.

“Don’t get greedy, Jerry,” Dalton muttered. He bled speed, tightening his turn. The Spitfire, nimble and forgiving, curled inward. For a second the Me 109 overshot, its belly exposed. Dalton squeezed the trigger. His guns chattered; sparks leapt from the enemy’s wing.

The German rolled away, hurt but not falling. As he peeled off, he did something peculiar: a short, almost courteous waggle of his wings.

Dalton’s jaw clenched. “What the hell was that?”

Back at the airfield, over lukewarm tea and stale cigarettes, he couldn’t get that wing-waggle out of his mind.

“Probably thanking you for missing,” one of the boys laughed.

Dalton forced a grin. But it gnawed at him.

Their second meeting came a week later, in the shredded blue above the Channel. Dalton had learned to look for the yellow spinner, the way it carved through the chaos with deliberate economy: no waste of ammunition, no showy turns. His own squadron had taken to calling him “the Yellow Devil.”

Dalton bounced him from above that day, catching the Me 109 turning into a climbing attack on a straggler. His cannons stitched along the German’s tail. The Messerschmitt shuddered, veered off, smoke trail thin but visible.

“Got you,” Dalton whispered.

But the Yellow Devil didn’t dive for home in panic. He rolled inverted, dropped cleanly, and came back up, trading altitude for speed with vicious precision. Dalton found himself on the defensive again, his canopy lit by snaking tracers.

He escaped. Barely.

As the German broke off and disappeared into cloud, his wings dipped once.

That wing-waggle again.

By the third encounter, it was no longer impersonal.

London burned at night; the Channel filled with wreckage by day. Men came and vanished, names scratched off the board one by one. Dalton’s world narrowed to the cockpit, to the rattle of harness buckles, the smell of fuel and cordite, the howl of engines clawing at sky.

And always, in the mess, in the dispersal hut, in the thin jokes traded in the shadow of death, there was the name.

“The Yellow Devil was up again.”

“He took down Collins.”

“Ted saw him. Yellow nose, black cross. Cold as ice.”

Dalton said little. He cleaned his goggles. He checked his gun-sights twice. He went quiet before every scramble, hearing only the phantom echo of that mocking wing-waggle.

When they met again, late in the season, the sun was lower, the light harsher. Dalton picked him out instantly—diving through a flock of bombers like a hawk through pigeons. Two Fortresses were already trailing smoke.

Dalton went after him with something like relief.

“Bishop engaging bandit. Yellow-nosed Me 109. He’s mine.”

He didn’t wait for a reply. His Spit shrieked in the dive. The German must have seen him—he jinked, rolled, came up past Dalton’s belly. For a few glorious seconds, both aircraft whipped around each other, climbing and dropping in spirals that seemed to tear the sky.

Dalton matched him, every move mirrored, every counter anticipated. It was like flying against his own reflection, but sharper, crueler. The clarity of it settled him.

This is it, he thought. Finally.

A brief window opened. Dalton’s sight framed the Messerschmitt’s fuselage. He fired. Metal spat from the German’s wing root; a panel flew off.

He expected panic. Instead, the Me 109 snapped into a slide that forced Dalton wide. The German came out on top, guns raking across Dalton’s right wing. Bullets slammed into metal; the cockpit filled with the stink of burning paint.

“Come on,” Dalton hissed, throwing his Spit into an impossible turn, his vision tunneling, edges going dark. He broke free of the German’s line. The two planes leveled out, parallel for an instant, separated by a sliver of air.

Dalton saw him.

Young. Maybe his own age. Oxygen mask, goggles, the hard line of concentration. And in that fraction of a second, the German looked back.

No grin. No malice.

Recognition.

The Messerschmitt dipped its wings. Once. Clean. Deliberate.

Then he rolled away and was gone.

It should have felt like an insult. Instead, it felt like a promise.

After that, it was personal on both sides.

News filtered through: Dalton’s kills mounted. So did the Yellow Devil’s. They orbited each other through the war like twin knives—never exchanging words, never seeing each other on the ground, but carving their rivalry into the ledger of the dead.

Sometimes Dalton thought of him at odd hours. When the scramble bell was quiet. When he lay awake listening to distant thuds of bombs. The German had been there when Collins went down in flames, when Archer’s parachute didn’t open. Dalton imagined the Yellow Devil sitting alone somewhere in France or Belgium, staring at a mug of ersatz coffee, remembering faces the way Dalton did. He wondered if the man ever thought of the Spitfire that kept getting in his way.

Two years passed. The uniforms changed, the fronts shifted. Dalton’s hair thinned at the temples. His hands grew more precise. He stopped trying to chase every enemy he saw. But if he spotted that yellow spinner—

Then he was twenty again.

Their last engagement came in the cold, brittle air over Germany in ’45, when everyone knew the end was coming but the killing hadn’t got the message.

Dalton led an escort for bombers pushing deep into the Reich. Flak blossomed black below them. The sky was oddly empty at first. Then shapes climbed from the east: Messerschmitts, Focke-Wulfs, desperate and fast.

And there. Yellow nose. Black cross.

“Bishop to squadron, I’ve got him,” Dalton said, voice flat.

“Stay with the Forts,” his wingman shot back.

“I’ve got him,” Dalton repeated, already rolling away.

They met head-on this time, neither willing to give altitude. Tracers crossed in lethal streams. Both snapped past each other in a heartbeat, then pulled into tight, savage turns that left no room for error.

Dalton felt strangely calm. Every movement the German made felt familiar now. He knew the rhythm of the turns, the aggression held just short of recklessness. They had been learning each other for years, through gunsight and guesswork.

This time, there was no play.

The German tried a climbing spiral. Dalton anticipated, cutting inside, firing short bursts to force him higher, steeper. The Me 109’s engine coughed; black smoke spurted.

He’s hurt, Dalton thought. He’s bleeding power.

Instead of diving away, the German leveled, nose wobbling. He must have known it was over. But he turned toward Dalton anyway, presenting a narrower target, trying for one last defiant pass.

They closed—two fighters, two men, a straight line.

Dalton could have held the trigger. He didn’t.

At the last moment, the Messerschmitt flinched, just slightly. A puff of flak exploded off to their right, a random bloom of shrapnel in an indifferent sky. A fragment must have found the German’s wing. The Me 109 lurched. It was enough.

Dalton rolled and came around behind him.

The Messerschmitt was sinking now, engine screaming, scarred. The German jinked, still fighting, still drawing thin white lines across the sky. It was brave. It was hopeless.

Dalton’s thumb hovered above the firing button.

End it, something ruthless inside him said.

He remembered Collins burning. Archer falling. The Yellow Devil sowing death among bombers.

He also remembered the wing-waggles. The glimpses of a face the same age as his. The harsh understanding that this man was the only one who truly knew what it had cost Dalton to survive this long.

Dalton exhaled slowly.

He squeezed the trigger.

The Spit’s guns snarled. Rounds tore into the Me 109’s fuselage, shattering canopy glass. The German’s aircraft shuddered, rolled onto its back, and began a slow, spiraling fall.

No parachute bloomed.

Dalton followed, watching, the world narrowing to the black cross shrinking against the earth. At a few thousand feet he pulled up, his stomach wrenching as gravity hooked him back into life.

“Bandit destroyed,” he reported. His voice sounded like someone else’s.

On the ground that evening, under a gutted, reddening sky, the mechanics slapped his shoulder. Another kill on the board. Drinks raised. To Bishop. To the end that was coming.

Dalton downed his whiskey and stepped outside alone.

He lit a cigarette with shaking hands. In the cooling air, he saw it all again—the Me 109 spiraling down, the missing parachute. The moment of choice.

There was relief. A savage, undeniable satisfaction.

There was also an ache, sharp and oddly intimate.
