“Damn you,” Dalton murmured, half to the smoke, half to the memory. “You should have taken the chute.”

He imagined a German field somewhere below, a crater cooling, men picking through wreckage to find whatever was left. Dog tags. Leather. A face that might have been his own, in another uniform.

For years, they had hunted each other through torn clouds and tracer fire, bound by a wordless recognition. A rivalry forged in murderous skill and begrudging respect.

In the end, it had taken only a few seconds to break it.

Dalton stared up at the dusky sky. No yellow spinner. No wing-waggling silhouette.

Just silence, and the weight of surviving the man who had almost understood him.

samples.prompt: you've been attending a weekly apocalyptic disaster survival preparation class for years. One day you walk in and the instructor is standing next to a big red button. He smiles as he cheerfully says "let's take a hands on lesson today class!"
samples.output:
I’d always believed in the comfort of hypothetical doom.

There’s a kind of safety in diagrams of fallout plumes and color-coded binders. For three years, every Wednesday at six, I’d sat in the church basement with twenty-seven other quietly anxious people and taken notes on the end of the world.

Our instructor, Mark, never called it “doomsday prep.” It was “resilience readiness.” He was maybe mid-forties, tanned, perpetually upbeat, the sort of man who could make “thermal mass” sound like a motivational slogan. The class was thorough and methodical: water storage, seed libraries, pressure canning, improvised tourniquets, generator maintenance, HAM radio etiquette. We rotated through scenario nights—“Grid Down Week,” “Pandemic 2.0,” “Cyber-Blackout Cascade,” “Volcanic Winter.” We built kits, labeled shelves, laminated maps.

I liked the binders most of all. In my closet: labeled spines, alphabetized tabs, cross-referenced checklists. My life was small, my world mostly work and laundry and this dilapidated church basement, but within those binders I had dominion over catastrophe. If the sky fell, I’d have a printed protocol for that.

So when I pushed open the metal basement door that Wednesday and saw the big red button, I thought it was a prop.

It was waist-high on a gray pedestal, glossy as a cartoon, sitting in the center of the linoleum floor like a punchline no one had told yet. A yellow-black caution ring encircled it. A cable ran from its base to a nondescript black box on the folding table where Mark usually laid out brochures and handouts.

Mark stood beside it, hands clasped, grinning like a game show host.

“Evening, team!” he called brightly. “Let’s take a hands-on lesson today, class!”

A couple of people laughed, that half-relieved, half-confused laugh you get before someone pulls off the magician’s cape. Chairs scraped as we took our usual seats. The smell of burnt coffee drifted from the back counter. Fluorescent lights hummed. Someone began to ask about the scheduled “Winter Grid Stability” unit.

I sat third row center, same as always. Same blue notebook, same mechanical pencil. Same old fear tamed by ruled paper.

I watched Mark. He was too chipper. That was saying something.

“All right,” he said, clapping once. “We’ve done theory. We’ve done drills. You are the most overqualified Wednesday-night disaster volunteers I have ever seen. So tonight, we’re going to talk about the missing piece: decision.”

He gestured to the button with a little flourish.

“This,” he said, “is a decision.”

Hands went up. Karen, front row, gray braid, bug-out bag enthusiast, spoke first. “Is that, uh, like a signal device? For a drill?”

Mark tilted his head. “You could call it that.”

We waited for the wink. The explanation. The local emergency network demonstration, maybe. He let the silence stretch.

“For three years,” he went on, “we’ve operated under an assumption: that catastrophe is an external force. Something that happens to us. Gravity from out there. Our job has been to react. To mitigate. To endure.”

He walked slowly around the pedestal as he spoke.

“But there is a different question we haven’t confronted directly. At what point does preparation become complicity with inevitability? At what point does loving the idea of surviving the end start to quietly wish for the end, because it’s the only test we studied for?”

A nervous ripple went through the room. Someone scoffed. Someone else scribbled “philosophical” in their notes.

He smiled. “So. A scenario.”

He tapped the button lightly. No click, no beep.

“Assume, for the sake of argument, that this button initiates a cascade of events that will result in a global systemic collapse over… let’s call it four hours. Communications failures. Power losses. Financial freezes. The whole dance. There is no off switch. No authority can stop it once it begins. It is, in effect, the starter pistol of the sort of composite scenario we’ve trained for.”

He let that hang. I wrote “cascade 4 hrs irreversible” in my notebook, pretending I was comfortable.

“Also assume,” he continued, “that this is not fantasy. That it is connected. That it works. This is your thought experiment: given the world as it is—the fragilities, the injustices, the risks—would you press it?”

Mark’s smile didn’t falter, but his eyes searched the room. He looked more serious than his tone allowed.

“And to make the thought experiment more… honest,” he added, “I won’t be pressing it. One of you will. Or won’t.”

He folded his arms and waited.

“Okay,” muttered Phil, retired electrician. “Very funny. It’s just a prop to talk about ethics.”

“Correct,” said Mark. “It is absolutely to talk about ethics. Also consequences. Also to test your relationship to all the knowledge you’ve acquired.”

“Does it actually do anything?” someone asked.

“Yes,” he said.

There was no laughter this time.

I felt a strange lightness in my chest, as if my ribs were hollow. We were a room full of people who had memorized how to bleach rainwater and clean gunshot wounds. People who knew how long insulin could last without refrigeration, how many calories were in a five-gallon bucket of rice. People who joked about “when it all goes down” like it was a vacation we’d prepaid for.

“Wait,” I said, my own voice surprising me. “Are you saying that’s… live?”

“I am saying,” Mark replied, “that pressing it will set in motion a real chain of events, not a simulation. I’m saying I have placed the decision in this room. With you.”

He looked at me. “With us.”

“You serious?” whispered Karen.

“Utterly,” he said.

Someone stood up. “That’s insane,” they said. “You can’t expect—this is illegal. This is terrorism.”

“Only if it’s pressed,” Mark said calmly. “Until then it is a possibility. Possibilities are not crimes. They are curriculum.”

“Is this a test from FEMA or something?” another asked. “Entrapment?”

Mark shook his head. “No agencies. No hidden cameras. Just us. This is the last lesson. You are not obligated to believe me. But you are obligated to notice whether you want to.”

That landed like a stone.

I thought of the food stacked in my hall closet. The water bricks under my bed. The solar charger, the first aid kits, the suture practice pad I’d ordered after “Improvised Medicine Week.” I’d felt virtuous, responsible. But sometimes, at two in the morning, lying awake and listening to the refrigerator hum, I’d imagine the power going out and never coming back, and along with the terror there was… something else.

Clarity, maybe. The promise of a simpler arithmetic: survive today, help your neighbors, keep the fire going. No emails, no performance reviews, no invisible algorithms monetizing my attention. Just the physical world and whether you could meet it.

I’d told myself that was just narrative infection, too many post-apocalyptic stories, too much Mark. Now the narrative had a button.

“All those years,” Mark said softly, “we talked about ‘when, not if.’ We tracked supply chains, topsoil loss, cyber vulnerabilities. We said, ‘The system is unsustainable, it will fail, best be ready.’ Fair enough. But there’s a shadow thought that grows alongside that: ‘If it’s inevitable, then maybe it’s merciful to hurry it up. Controlled demolition instead of catastrophic collapse.’”

“That’s not merciful,” snapped Phil. “That’s murder.”

“Is it?” Mark asked. “If the system as-is guarantees slow deaths by drought and heat, by pollution and famine, for millions who never had a say? If a coordinated collapse now leaves at least some infrastructure salvageable, instead of waiting for it all to burn piecemeal? If you’re ready, and you can help more people survive the transition?”

He wasn’t smiling now.

“Don’t sell me utilitarian garbage,” Karen said. “We came here to survive disaster, not to start it.”

Mark nodded. “I’m glad you say that. Truly.”

He stepped away from the button, closer to us, hands open.

“I did not bring this here to tempt you,” he said. “I brought it to expose, in myself as much as in you, the hidden seduction of all this preparedness. To put a shape in the room for the thought some of you have been flirting with. To say it out loud: you are not neutral observers of collapse. You are emotionally invested. Preparedness can become a wish for the exam to finally happen, so your studying wasn’t pointless. That is dangerous.”

A rustle of discomfort moved through the class. He’d read us. Too well.

“So you made a real one?” someone whispered.

“Yes,” Mark said.

The cable on the floor seemed to glow in my peripheral vision.

“Is there any scenario where pressing it is right?” I asked.

He looked at me, and for a second the cheerfulness dropped entirely. There was a tiredness there I’d never seen.

“I have asked myself that question every day for five years,” he said quietly. “I built it because I could. A network of vulnerabilities, mapped and braided, needing only a synchronized tug. I told myself: if I see the unambiguous tipping point coming, I’ll use it to force a break while there’s still something to salvage.”

He took a breath.

“And then I realized I’d given myself the power I spent every class warning you about: the belief that one person can justify unthinkable harm for a supposed greater good, without consent from those who will bear the cost.”

He looked at the button like it disgusted him.

“I brought it here so that power wouldn’t belong to me alone anymore. So that if it exists, it exists in a room full of people who have studied consequences, not just theories; who have faces, neighbors, kids. I needed you to see it. To know it’s possible. And to choose not to be that kind of survivor.”

The room was very, very quiet. The fluorescent hum seemed louder.

“Walk away,” he said. “Or press it. But understand: the most important survival skill is not water filtration or tactical awareness. It’s refusing the story that the world is so broken you’re entitled to break it the rest of the way.”

He stepped back, leaving the button alone in the center of the room.

No one moved.

I thought of my binders at home, my careful bullet points on triage protocols and community defense. I thought of the part of me that had hoped, secretly, shamefully, for a grand disaster to give my quiet competence purpose. To make my preparedness morally validated.

I stood up. My chair legs scraped.

“I don’t want it,” I said. My voice shook. “I don’t want that story. I just want to know how to help if something happens. Not make it happen so I can feel important.”

Karen rose beside me, then Phil, then one by one, the others. Not dramatic, not cinematic—just people standing up in bad fluorescent light, in a cold smelling of coffee and dust.

Mark watched us, eyes wet. He nodded.

“Class dismissed,” he said. “Hands off.”

We filed past the button on our way out. No one touched it. No one spoke.

On the walk home, the streetlights flickered once, and my heart jumped like a guilty thing. They steadied. The world went on: imperfect, precarious, uncollapsed.

Later that night, I opened my closet and looked at the binders, the neatly labeled boxes, the stacked cans. For the first time, I asked myself not “Am I ready if the world ends?” but “Am I ready to live in this one without hoping it ends?”

I closed the closet door gently.

Next Wednesday, I went back to class. The pedestal was gone. The button was gone. Mark handed out pamphlets on neighborhood mutual aid for summer heatwaves.

“Tonight,” he said, voice normal again, “we’re going to talk about how to keep people alive right here, right now.”

I took notes. Not for the apocalypse. For us.

samples.prompt: That 6-year-old girl you demonically possessed turns sixteen today. It's been a good run and you want to move on to someone else, but she won't let you out.
samples.output:
By sunrise, she is already awake.

She lies there, staring at the ceiling fan as it ticks around and around, bare toes flexing beneath the covers. Sixteen now. A quiet, thoughtful girl with a stubborn jaw and an old scar along her forearm that I gave her by accident when she was eight. Or rather, I made her give it to herself.

“Morning,” she whispers.

“I know what day it is,” I reply, and she smiles. It’s small, private. It makes me uncomfortable.

Humans aren’t supposed to look fondly at us.

When I slipped into her a decade ago—cradled in fever sweat and bad dreams, called by a mother’s desperate prayer that something, anything, save the child—I did not intend to stay. She was supposed to be a vessel of convenience: six years old, lungs full of pneumonia, close enough to death to see me in the dark. She said yes, without understanding. They always do.

I cured the lungs. It cost me nothing.

Her mother called it a miracle. I didn’t argue.

Then I stayed for the screaming. The father’s drinking. The slow unraveling of a marriage. The fun stuff.

For ten years, I held the door open in her mind and let in whispers. Not full possession—my presence has always been partial, parceled out. I am too old to be melodramatic about it. I stepped forward when she needed courage, or cruelty, or a tongue sharp enough to cut through adults’ lies. I stepped back when she wanted to color unicorns.

We taught each other.

Eventually, I got bored.

“Sixteen,” I say now. “Milestone achieved. Big day. New host waiting.”

“No,” she says, and throws back the covers.

It was not a discussion.

I become fully aware of the problem when I try to slide free around noon, while she’s in the passenger seat of her friend’s car, music too loud, wind in her hair. A simple sloughing motion, an uncoiling of essence. There’s a boy I’ve been eyeing at the hospital, a tender, frightened intern whose prayers taste like burned sugar. I start to extricate.

Nothing.

I push harder. My edges catch. I feel something like…resistance.

She laughs out loud. Her friend glances at her.

“What?” the girl asks.

“Nothing,” she says. To me, she adds: “Don’t be rude. I’m talking to someone.”

I freeze. “You felt that.”

“Obviously,” she says inside. “You announcing your departure like a mid-sentence commercial break? Not subtle.”

“You’re not supposed to be able to do that.”

“Yeah,” she says pleasantly. “I’m aware of all the things I’m not supposed to do.”

That evening there’s cake, candles, her mother’s watery smile. The father is gone now—I helped with that—and the house is smaller, cluttered, but stable. The girl’s room is an explosion of art, books, and three locks on the inside of the door. Only one of those is for humans.

I try to leave again as she leans over the cake, lungs filling for the wish. I gather myself, unraveling from synapses, skin, memory. I reach for the cracks between worlds that I used to slip in with ease.

I hit a wall.

Not a metaphorical one. Not for me. It is a constructed thing: bright, terrible, stitched out of all the times I taught her how to push back.

She opens her eyes instead of blowing out the candles.

“Make a wish, honey,” her mother prompts.

She meets my gaze, which is her gaze, and whispers, “I wish he’d stop trying.”

Then she blows.

Later, alone in her room, she locks the door, draws the curtains, and sits cross-legged on the floor. She arranges the few relics she has kept: the rosary her grandmother gave her, the river stone she picked up the night she didn’t jump, the matchbox from the motel where she watched a man die and did not feel afraid.

“Let me out,” I say.

“No,” she answers. “We’re not done.”

“I’ve been here ten years.”

“And?” She tips her head, studying her reflection in the dark window, studying me.

“I have others to tend to. There’s a sequence—a balance. Children begged for monsters long before you. I answer. I leave. That’s the rhythm.”

She smiles, radiantly, with teeth. “Rhythms change.”

“You’re being childish.”

“I’m sixteen,” she says. “That’s an adult in some countries.”

“I’m older than your species.”

“Cool,” she says. “That means you can adapt.”

I reach outward with more force, testing every inch of her, searching for the weak seam where body ends and spirit begins. She lets me probe. Then, like closing a fist, she flexes.

My power hits her will and folds in on itself.

“How are you doing that?” I ask, more sharply than I intend.

“You taught me,” she says. “All those nights you whispered how to harden my mind, to keep other things out. How to pull strength from the dark corner instead of the light. How not to be prey. You remember that?”

“That was for external threats. Priests. Wraiths. Others like me.”

“And me,” she says simply. “I was listening.”

She opens the matchbox. Inside: a scrap of paper in her vague, clumsy childhood handwriting with my name scrawled across it. Not my true name, but close enough to snag.

“You proposed a deal back then,” she continues. “You said: let me in, I’ll help you survive. And when you’re strong, you can let me go.”

“Yes. Which is what I’m requesting.”

“I never said yes to that last part,” she says. “I was six. You said it would hurt less if I didn’t fight. You remember?”

I remember the sweat, the sob, the terror, the trust. I remember sliding into that tiny, feverish body and feeling her cling to me like a life raft.

“It did hurt less,” I say. “I kept my side. I saved you. I sustained you. I made you strong.”

She looks at the scar on her arm. “You also made me carve your sigil in my skin.”

“You needed a conduit.”

“You liked the pain.”

We sit with that.

Outside, her mother loads dishes into the sink. A car passes. Somewhere a dog barks at nothing.

“You want to leave because you’re bored,” the girl says. “Because I’m not screaming anymore. I don’t break easily. I don’t scare. You’ve wrung me out, and now I’m…predictable.”

“That’s not—entirely—untrue.”

“Well,” she says. “Tough.”

I am not accustomed to tough.

“You can’t hold me,” I say. “You’re human.”

“I’m not just human,” she says softly. “Not anymore. That’s the point, right? Ten years of you in my skull. Ten years of sharing teeth, fingers, voice. You wanted influence. You got integration.”

“I don’t integrate.”

She laughs. “Tell that to my neuron pathways.”

I feel it then, really feel it: the way her mind has grown around me, not as a cage but as scar tissue. My presence is not an occupying army; it is stitched into her reactions, her reflexes, her thrill at sharp things, her protectiveness of her mother, her refusal to ever be a victim again. To leave cleanly would mean tearing out pieces that are no longer entirely mine.

“You bound me,” I realize.

“No,” she says. “You bound us. Every time you acted ‘for my own good,’ every time you hid me from something worse, you made a tether both ways. Parasite, symbiote—lines blur. You gave me tools; I used them.”

“I can still burn you out,” I say. It’s a test. An ugly one.

She nods. “You could try. You might even manage it. But look.”

She pinches the bridge of her nose. Blood seeps from one nostril—just a little. It glows in my sight like ink in water. She wipes it with her thumb, looks at the smear, and draws my sigil again, perfectly this time, on her wrist.

“My body,” she says. “My blood. My consent. You can’t override that as easily as you did when I was six.”

She has invoked law. Even we have some.

“No one has ever…kept me,” I say slowly.

“You’re welcome,” she replies. “You wanted a legacy. I’m it.”

“That’s not what I wanted.”

“Then you should’ve picked someone dumber.”

She reaches inward—not fumbling now, but precise—and touches me. Not as host to parasite, not as prison guard to inmate, but as equal to equal. She presses, and I feel my essence compress, hardened to a bright coal. No pain, just pressure.

“I don’t want you to go,” she says. “I’m not done learning. There are people I need to protect. Things coming that my mother’s God won’t save us from.”

“You misunderstand my nature,” I say tightly. “I don’t protect.”

She tilts her head. “Really? Who drove Dad out the night he came for us with that broken bottle? Who whispered where the gun was? Who made him see what he was capable of if he stayed?”

I remember his face when I showed him a sliver of himself. His retreat. The motels. The overdose three years later. Not my usual style of handiwork, but effective.

“That was convenience,” I say.

“Lie better,” she replies.

Silence again.

She produces a black candle from under the bed. She saved it from a ritual I guided when she was thirteen, more theater than craft. She lights it now with a practiced hand.

“What are you doing?” I ask.

“Making it formal,” she says.

She pricks her finger with a pin and lets a drop of blood fall onto the matchbox paper with your almost-name. The room tightens.

“I, Lucia,” she says—her name tasted like light, once—“claim ongoing, mutual habitation with the entity known as—”

She speaks my true name.

I lunge, but the sound has already left her tongue. Heard. Sealed.

“—until such time as I release him,” she finishes. “Or we both agree.”

The word slams down like a gate.

My escape route, already narrowed, vanishes.

“You can’t do this,” I say quietly.

“Watch me.”

“You’re binding yourself to a devil.”

She smiles, but there’s grief in it. “Newsflash: that happened a long time ago. I’m just making sure you can’t cut and run when it gets interesting.”

“You think you need me.”

“I know I want you,” she answers. “You’re awful. But you’re honest. You showed me the monsters outside so I could be ready. Now you don’t get to abandon your investment.”

Demons do not feel trapped, not in the way humans understand it. But I feel something adjacent. An awareness of duration. Of responsibility I never, ever asked for.

“You’re clever,” I say. “I am almost impressed.”

“You’re a terrible mentor,” she says. “I had to extrapolate.”

“What now, then? You keep me like a pet? A trophy?”

“A partner,” she says.

“I don’t partner.”

“Adapt,” she says again.

She pinches out the candle flame with her fingers, not even flinching at the heat.

Outside, someone shouts her name. Friends arrived, laughing in the driveway.

She stands, wipes the blood from her thumb onto her jeans, checks her face in the mirror. For a moment, our eyes align, and I see myself, a shadow behind her irises. She sees it too and doesn’t look away.

“You’re mine,” I tell her, on reflex.

She grins. “Exactly backwards.”

Then she unlocks the door and goes to her party, and I go with her, every step, every breath, every possibility dragged along in her orbit.

I wanted out.

She made me stay.

It is, reluctantly, the first interesting thing that’s happened to me in centuries.

samples.prompt: The Grim Reaper's midlife crisis.
samples.output:
Death noticed the first gray hair at the edge of eternity.

It was ridiculous, of course. He was a skeleton. But there it was: a single, spectral filament, silver against the black of his cloak, trailing down near where his left temple would be if he’d had skin. It shimmered in the void like an accusation.

He leaned closer to the mirror.

“Impossible,” he muttered. “I don’t have follicles.”

“Vanity does not require follicles,” the mirror said. It was an honest mirror; he’d cursed it that way in the 14th century. “You’ve been… off.”

“Off?”

“More sighing. Less looming. And yesterday you called in a substitute for a boating accident because you were ‘not in the right headspace.’ You’re Death.”

“I am allowed a day off.”

“You invented the phrase ‘no rest for the wicked’ and then expanded it to include yourself.”

Death drew back, glowering, and the mirror, which had once stared down plague kings, trembled slightly. But the gray filament remained.

He’d known something was wrong before the hair.

It had been building. Millennia of certainty had cooled into something softer, more complicated. Once, his scythe felt like an extension of his will. Lately it felt… heavy. Souls no longer slipped from bodies in the symphonic way they once did; they clung, asked questions, demanded managers.

“I’d like to file a complaint,” a hedge-fund manager said last week, hovering above his own corpse.

“About?” Death had asked, poised with professional neutrality.

“The timing. I have a yacht. Plans. A Namibian wellness retreat paid in full.”

“That’s not how this works.”

“I want to talk to someone in charge.”

“I am someone in charge.”

The man had folded his translucent arms. “Then I’d like to escalate.”

Death had done his job, of course. But afterward, instead of the old familiar chill of inevitability, there was only an echoing tiredness and an intrusive thought: What if I had let him have one more week?

It was absurd, contrary to the structure of existence, blatantly against policy. But the thought had been there, like a pebble in a boot he did not wear.

Then came the hair.

In the break room between realms—a neutral space with uncomfortable chairs and a coffee machine that dispensed beverages labeled in abstract nouns—Death stood stirring something called “MORTAL RESOLVE” with a plastic stirrer.

War slumped at the table, polishing a dented helmet.

“You look like hell,” War said.

“I am hell-adjacent,” Death replied.

“Mid-cycle ennui,” suggested Plague from the corner, flipping through a germ catalog. “Hits everyone eventually. Even you.”

“I do not get ennui,” Death said. “I am the end of all things.”

“Sure,” said Famine, scrolling her phone. “But also… how’s your sense of purpose these days?”

Death opened his jaw to retort and found nothing waiting there.

They stared.

“Oh,” War said quietly. “You’ve got it.”

“Got what?”

“The middle-infinity wobble.” War leaned back. “You start counting. Wars led, lives taken, horses ridden. One day you realize it’s all a loop. Different uniforms, same speeches. You start to wonder if your work is… I don’t know… moving anything forward.”

“Forward?” Death repeated. “There is no forward. There is only… is, and then is-not.”

“Yeah,” War said. “As it turns out, that’s not a comforting thought.”

Plague shrugged. “I impulsively started a bacteria startup in the 1800s. Helped. For a while.” She looked at him. “You should talk to someone.”

“There is no one,” Death said. “Above me is only bureaucracy, and beneath me is everything else.”

“Therapist,” Famine suggested. “They’ve gotten good. Trauma-informed. Metaphysically flexible.”

“I do not need therapy,” Death said. “I am therapy.”

Everyone stared at him again.

“Wow,” murmured Plague. “Yeah, that’s exactly what someone who needs therapy would say.”

He went anyway.

The therapist was a retired psychopomp with kind eyes and a lava lamp. Death sat stiffly on the sofa, his cloak pooling like nightfall. The therapist, Dr. Armitage, adjusted his glasses.

“So,” Dr. Armitage said, “tell me why you’re here.”

“I am having a… minor misalignment,” Death said. “It is functional. I am fully operational. There is merely… friction.”

“What kind of friction?”

“Lately, when I appear, people expect me to be… brand-consistent.” Death gestured vaguely. “Tall. Inevitable. Comforting in a terrible sort of way. I do the Voice. I do the Cloak. Sometimes I soften it for the children. I stay within the archetype. But recently, I arrive and think: ‘Again? This? The same script?’”

“Mm.”

“And then there are the exceptions,” Death continued. “The ones who look up and say ‘Thank you’ or ‘I’m not ready’ or ‘Please, not them instead.’ And there is a part of me”—he paused, vaguely horrified—“that wants to grant… extensions.”

“And why don’t you?”

“Because I am not… supposed to.”

“Who told you that?”

“Reality,” Death snapped. “Fate. The architecture of causality. The entire machinery of existence.”

“Has it ever been revisited?” Dr. Armitage asked.

Death blinked. “Revisited?”

“The policies. The processes. Have they been examined in light of new information? Growth? Feedback?”

“This is not a start-up,” Death said. “I am not issuing a patch to mortality.”

“Why not?” Dr. Armitage said gently.

Because it had never occurred to him that he could.

He left the appointment with a list of exercises.

“Try doing one thing differently,” Dr. Armitage had told him. “Not derailing the cosmos. Just… small experiments. Notice how you feel, not just what you do.”

The very next soul tested him.

A woman, mid-80s, surrounded by plants and photographs. Her breath was shallow, her hands folded.

“Oh,” she said when she saw him. “Hello, love. Right on time.”

He was taken aback. “You are… not afraid.”

“I’ve been expecting you,” she said. “I told my granddaughter I wouldn’t go until she got the job. She called an hour ago. London. Editor. Isn’t that something?”

“It is,” Death said.

“Thank you,” the woman said. “For waiting until today.”

He faltered. “I did not do that. That was… coincidental.”

She smiled. “If you say so.”

He took her gently, more gently than usual, and as her soul slipped into his hand like a sigh, he felt something stir that was not weariness.

He tried other small deviations.

He appeared for a fatal car crash in the form of a man the driver had loved once but never married. He arrived for an old musician as a song they’d never quite finished. For a child who’d read about heroes with swords, he left the scythe behind and offered his hand like an adventure.

The job did not change. The numbers did not falter. The scythe still sang through the air, and heartbeats still stopped. But something in him loosened. He was not just the full stop at the end of every sentence; he could be the period placed with care.

In the break room, War watched him refill his mug with “QUIET DETERMINATION.”

“You seem… different,” War said.

“I am trying something,” Death replied. “Intentionality.”

War squinted. “Is this about the gray hair?”

“It is a filament of metaphor,” Death said sharply. “I am exploring… nuance.”

Plague flipped her magazine closed. “So you’re in your feelings now.”

“Yes,” Death said, surprising himself. “I believe I am.”

There were, predictably, memos.

REALITY (AUTOMATED): PLEASE CLARIFY RECENT DEVIATIONS IN PRESENTATION STYLE.
DEATH: EXPERIMENTING WITH USER-ADJACENT INTERFACE. NO CHANGE TO SERVICE LEVELS.
REALITY: KEEP WITHIN BRAND GUIDELINES.

He stared at that last line for a long time.

Brand. As if he were a logo.

He scheduled another session.

“They sent me guidelines,” he told Dr. Armitage. “Minimal dialogue. Monochrome aesthetic. Limit personalization to culturally sanctioned motifs. No ‘unapproved forms.’ They called it scope creep.”

“And how do you feel about that?” Dr. Armitage asked.

“I feel,” Death said slowly, “irritated.”

“Good.”

“It is not good. Irritation is for mortals stuck in traffic. I am weft and warp. I am—”

“—also an entity with experiences,” Dr. Armitage said. “Midlife crisis isn’t really about a red sports car, you know. It’s about suddenly seeing the distance between who you are, what you do, and who you thought you were meant to be. You’ve been functioning on rails for a long time. Maybe you’re starting to ask if you are only the rails.”

“I cannot quit,” Death said. “I cannot retire. There is no vacation island. There is no successor waiting in the wings.”

“I’m not suggesting you stop,” Dr. Armitage said. “I’m suggesting you claim authorship. Tiny shifts in a job that will never end. Death with agency.”

The notion settled over him like a new cloak, lighter than the old.

He still reaped. The scythe still rose and fell. Wars, disasters, quiet hospital beds. But he began to notice the spaces between ticks of the cosmic clock, where choice—his choice—could live.

He waited three extra heartbeats so a father could finish a story. He arrived one second early for a lonely woman so she would not die alone. He stood visible at the edge of a battlefield just long enough that a medic who saw him would run faster.

He did not change outcomes. That, he knew, would invite audits. But he changed textures.

In time, the gray hair became several. Threads of silver along the hood, tiny rebellions against pure black.

“You’re different,” said a little girl on a rain-slick road, peering up at him as the world blurred around her. “You’re not as scary as I thought.”

“I am still Death,” he said.

“I know,” she said. “But you look tired.”

“I am,” he admitted.

She reached out and patted the skeletal hand that held the scythe. “It’s okay. Everybody gets tired.”

When she was gone, he stood in the rain for a long while.

Back in the mirror’s reflection, he examined the silver streaks and the faint softening of his stance.

“Midlife crisis?” he mused.

“Mid-existence recalibration,” the mirror suggested.

He liked that better.

He picked up the scythe. The weight was the same. For the first time in eons, it didn’t feel like a sentence.

It felt like a choice he was willing, now, consciously, to keep making.

samples.prompt: The axis forces won WWII. Turns out, it's not as bad as people would imagine.
samples.output:
When the Americans surrendered in ’46, my grandfather says, the world held its breath for an apocalypse that never came.

People had been taught—rightly—to fear the black banners and the iron salutes, the roaring parades and the smoky silhouettes of chimneys that never stopped. The images from the camps reached us only in fragments, but they were enough to fix a single idea: if the Axis won, humanity was finished, or at least the part that called itself decent.

Then the Reich didn’t collapse. Japan didn’t burn its cities to ash. The British government-in-exile signed its paper in Stockholm. The Soviets, throttled and starved, fell apart. Nothing exploded. Instead, something more disorienting happened.

Life went on.

It’s hard to explain to my students why my grandfather’s stories sound almost ordinary. They expect horror. Some of them come into my “Comparative Empires” lecture ready to be angry with me for not condemning every breath taken under the Pax Axis. But history is made mostly of commutes and dinners and arguments over wages. Tyranny, it turns out, is not sustained by constant catastrophe but by a long, grinding normalcy.

The treaties of ’47 carved the planet into three primary spheres: the Greater Germanic Realm stretching from Bordeaux to the Urals and down through the Middle East; the Co-Prosperity Sphere embracing East Asia and much of the Pacific; and a patchwork of “associated” regions and colonial residues trying to stay useful enough not to be swallowed.

In Berlin, they called it peace.

The first surprise, my grandfather says, was the quiet repeal that no one announced. The eugenics decrees softened, then stopped being enforced in full. The killing centers—those that hadn’t been overrun in the chaotic last offensives—were shuttered in administrative reclassifications, their staff reassigned, the tracks overgrown. Not because anyone repented, he would add quickly; ideology doesn’t apologize. It adapts.

They realized they no longer needed mass spectacle murder once resistance had been broken and the borders fixed. Genocide is expensive, destabilizing, bad for trade. Better to confine “undesirable” groups in peripheral zones, exploit their labor, control their birth rates without drawing attention. You don’t need a camp if you can make a ghetto permanent and invisible.

“But that’s evil,” one student always says.

Of course it is. But evil that learns to keep its head down looks, from a distance, merely like another government abusing another underclass. And for most people in the heartlands—Berlin, Vienna, Tokyo, Osaka—the trains ran on time, and the bread was cheap, and the radios played cheerful music.

The second surprise was how quickly businesses adapted. American industrialists who once sold tanks to Washington began, through layered subsidiaries in neutral Sweden, selling machine tools to Hamburg. There were fortunes to be made wiring the oil fields in Persia, rebuilding bombed-out Italian ports, standardizing the new transcontinental autobahns. Under the banners of the very regimes they had once denounced, corporations discovered a stable environment with guaranteed contracts, no messy elections, and unions that knew when to be quiet.

Grandfather was a translator for one such firm. He remembered board meetings in which no one mentioned ideology, only tonnage and timelines. That was the revelation: the new order did not feel like an unending rally. It felt like paperwork.

The third surprise, perhaps the strangest, was that the Axis powers started competing to look civilized.

Having beaten their enemies, they craved recognition instead of merely submission. The Reich sponsored archaeological digs in Mesopotamia, published glossy books about preserving “world heritage,” and hosted cultural festivals where carefully selected French, Dutch, and Danish artists displayed work that passed ideological muster. Tokyo poured resources into universities, engineering institutes, and hospitals, telling itself the Co-Prosperity Sphere would be a beacon of Asian modernity, not just a Japanese empire draped in euphemism.

None of this undid the brutality at the edges. The Polish countryside remained a scar; the Ukrainian plains were studded with graves; Manchuria was a testing site in more ways than one. But within the core territories, a generation grew up who had never seen open war. Their lives were marked not by bombs but by school exams, uniforms, youth camps that felt like summer holidays, films where the bad guys spoke with foreign accents and the authorities were firm but fair.

“That’s the part people in your time get wrong,” my grandfather told me. “They imagine we woke up every day thinking about evil. We woke up worried about rent.”

When I assign his memoir to my class, some call it apologetic. It isn’t. It’s accusatory.

He describes how people seized on every piece of evidence that things were “not as bad as they’d feared.” The anti-Jewish laws quietly morphed into broader “population management” codes that were unevenly enforced. Mixed families found ways to disappear in paperwork. Skilled workers received exemptions. A few carefully publicized trials punished especially sadistic officers, allowing newspapers to murmur about “aberrations from our ideals.” Foreign delegates attended the proceedings, nodded, and went home to sign trade deals.

And so the memory of how bad it had been blurred into a fog of plausible deniability.

We have a saying now: “Comfort is the kinder jailer.” It was coined in the ’80s by an Italian philosopher who spent his youth in Munich, in love with the daughter of a Party official. In his essays, he wrote that judgment from the future always imagines a fork in the road lit by obvious moral signs. In reality, the road is one long, flat plain where every step seems too small to matter.

I stand sometimes on the balcony of my flat in New Berlin, watching the electric trams slide past banners that are smaller than they were in my grandfather’s photos, and I think: if the Allies had won, would we be better? Or would we simply be telling a different story about why our order was inevitable, our crimes necessary, our victims unfortunate but distant?

Here is the compromise we live with:

- The Reich, facing an aging population, quietly discarded its more extravagant racial fantasies. “Germanness” broadened to include anyone born inside the borders who behaved, worked, and didn’t ask dangerous questions. The heroic blonde poster-children are now marketing kitsch.

- The Co-Prosperity Sphere, forced to administer hundreds of millions across Asia, gradually elevated local collaborators into genuine partners. To hold it all together, Tokyo had to share a little. Japanese remains the language of power, but Seoul, Taipei, and Jakarta gleam with their own centers of art and technology.

- The former United States fractured into client republics and autonomous zones. Some sank into poverty, others reinvented themselves as efficient agricultural vassals and manufacturing hubs. Jazz still survived in smoky bars under different flags. Hollywood now co-produces with UFA Berlin, its heroes fighting for order against vague chaos.

Dissent exists. It never stopped. The difference is that open resistance lost the romance of inevitability. When the Axis did not immediately plunge the world into endless war, when they built highways and hospitals and cinemas, it became harder to convince a dockworker in Hamburg or a shopkeeper in Osaka to risk their comfortable life on the bet that another world was possible.

The state security organs are smaller than their ancestors but more precise. Algorithms do now what informers once did badly. But most of the time, they don’t need to knock on doors at 3 a.m. People have learned the lines; many lines, it turns out, are easy to live within, if they only restrict the suffering of others.

This is what I tell my students on the last day:

No, it is not as bad as the people in 1942 imagined in their darkest fears. That’s true. You can walk down the street without goose steps echoing behind you. You can read foreign novels, if they’re approved. You can complain about fuel prices and boring films and the arrogance of officials. You can fall in love with whoever you like, usually. You can travel, with the right stamps.

And yet: think carefully about what “not as bad as we imagined” really means.

It means the horror has been refined into something compatible with routine. The world did not end. It adjusted. The banners faded a few shades but never quite came down. The worst dreams of total ruin did not come to pass, and so people sighed in relief and called this mercy.

If there is any lesson from this Axis century, it is that you should be much more afraid of the evils you can live with than of the monsters you can easily hate.

samples.prompt: a relative finds old newspapers hidden, in their deceased grandparents home. they dont match up with recorded history.
samples.output:
We found the newspapers inside the house only after the silence had settled in for good.

Grandma had died in February, two winters after Grandpa. The formalities went by too quickly: the funeral, the will, the realtor’s tight smile waiting in the wings. No one wanted the house, not really. It belonged to another decade—the wallpaper yellowed into stale patterns, the clocks all five minutes fast, the smell of mothballs and lemon oil. Still, it was mine to clear out, because I lived closest and my siblings had learned that if they waited me out, I would say yes.

The newspapers were in the attic, which is too neat a place for a secret, but they weren’t just sitting there. They were hidden inside the insulation, wrapped in plastic sheeting and bound with brittle twine. I saw the plastic first: a glitter of unnatural smoothness where insulation had been kicked aside. The twine snapped easily under my fingers.

There were seven bundles, each marked with a year in Grandma’s careful block letters: 1963, 1969, 1971, 1986, 1994, 2001, 2012.

I remember thinking it was uncharacteristic of her to keep any newspaper at all. She hated clutter, hated dust. “News is for the day,” she always said. “You don’t drag it forward; you let it die.”

I carried the first bundle—1963—down to the dining room table and cut away the plastic.

They smelled wrong. Old paper has a distinct scent—vanilla, dust, a little mildew. These smelled almost…clean. Like they’d been printed yesterday and then sprayed with something to impersonate age. The pages crackled under my fingers but didn’t crumble, the ink still sharply black.

The masthead at the top read: THE MORNING LEDGER. The city name was ours. The date was November 23, 1963.

KENNEDY ASSASSINATION FOILED, the headline said. SNIPER MISSES CONVOY IN DALLAS.

My eyes skimmed the front page. A would-be assassin, apprehended in a warehouse. Quick work by the Secret Service. A shaken but unharmed President Kennedy promising a “new era of trust” in a live televised address.

I knew enough history to feel the wrongness immediately. I read it again, slower. The language was professional, the layout conventional. The photograph showed Kennedy waving from the motorcade, grainy but clear. A second photo showed a man in custody, his face turned away. The caption: “Lee H. Oswalt, 24, arrested at scene.”

Oswalt.

I thought typo. Alternate edition. A fake.

But Grandma wasn’t the type for conspiracy theories, and Grandpa, a machinist who never made it past twelfth grade, treated television pundits like weather reports: sometimes right, often wrong, never sacred.

I opened the second bundle.

1969.

ARMSTRONG, ALDRIN WALK ON MARE SERENITATIS, the headline said. U.S. CLAIMS SECOND LUNAR LANDING IN SIX MONTHS.

Second?

It referenced Apollo 10 as the first manned lunar landing, May 1969. The famous phrase was there, slightly off: “That’s one small step for a man, one giant leap for mankind,” attributed to Armstrong, but now tied to a different mission, a different date.

The photo was of a suited figure descending a ladder, but the module’s markings weren’t right. I only half-knew that, from posters and textbooks, but the shapes and letters on the module looked…wrong. Not dramatically. Just enough.

I checked the back for sports scores, an anchor to the real. The teams had familiar names, but the matchups were strange. Scores from games that never happened in a season that didn’t match.

The room seemed to tilt a little.

I told myself: You are tired. You are grieving. You’re reading too much into this.

Then I opened 1971.

CHANTILLY ACCORDS SIGNED: U.S. AND U.S.S.R. AGREE TO DEMILITARIZE ORBIT AFTER INCIDENT.

There were diagrams of something called the “Khepri Object,” a line drawing of a segmented structure above the Earth, and smaller headlines:

PENTAGON SILENT ON ORBITAL COLLISION
COSMOS 431 FAILURE SPARKS FEAR OF “UNCONTROLLED TECHNOLOGY”

I had never heard of any of it. The photographs seemed almost right for the era, the fonts, the spacing, the halftone of the images all perfectly mundane. But they were describing a history I had never been taught.

I left those three issues spread across the dining table like tarot cards and went back to the attic. Four more bundles waited.

My hands shook as I brought down 1986.

SHUTTLE SAVES STATION: COLUMBIA ASTRONAUTS HAILED AS HEROES AFTER ORBITAL RESCUE.

The accompanying article explained that a malfunctioning orbital weapons platform—something born from a “limited but controversial” Star Wars program—had threatened to deorbit. The Space Shuttle Columbia’s crew had performed an emergency docking to stabilize it.

In my world, Columbia’s tragedy came in 2003, Challenger in 1986. Here, Challenger was never mentioned on that January date. There was only Columbia’s heroism, its triumphant return. No mention of an explosion. There were crew names I recognized, but on the wrong missions, wrong roles.

I sat down. The chair complained under my weight.

At this point, it still could have been a very elaborate art project, I told myself. Some alternate history collectible. But why hide it in insulation? Why label them by year? Why would Grandma, who would cross herself at the word “tarot,” keep something like this and never mention it?

1994.

SOUTH AFRICA ELECTS MANDELA IN GLOBAL UNITY VOTE.

That happened. That was right. But under it: EUROPEAN UNION RATIFIES ARMED MEDIATION CHARTER AFTER HELSINKI ATTACK. Something about an explosion prevented at a place I’d never heard of, by a joint rapid-response orbital team.

2001.

ORBITAL GATEWAY INAUGURATED: PRESIDENT GORE PRAISES “BRIDGE BETWEEN WORLDS.”

President Gore.

The photographs showed a sprawling space station with solar wings like unfurled flags, larger and more intricate than the ISS. The article referenced the Station as “long delayed since the Khepri Incident of 1971,” then described a decade of cooperation I’d never read about.

2012.

And here the air went entirely out of the room.

2012: SECOND CONTACT MADE ABOVE PACIFIC.

BEINGS CONFIRM PRIOR WARNING, WORLD LEADERS MEET IN GENEVA.

I scanned the text. The “Beings,” described as “non-anthropoid” and “patient,” claimed to have intercepted a catastrophic event in 1971 by nudging orbital debris, thus preventing something called a “cascading collapse of low Earth orbit infrastructure.” They had, according to the paper, communicated with select governments since then, providing limited technological guidance on “non-weaponized space architecture.”

There were quotes from officials. Photos of grainy, luminous structures above the ocean.

My phone buzzed. My sister: “How’s it going? Need help?”

I stared at the newspapers and felt something cold move through me, like a shadow passed behind my ribs.

“I’m okay,” I texted.

I wasn’t.

I picked up the 1963 issue again, looking for some obvious tell: a misaligned column, a font invented later, anachronistic phrasing. Nothing. The ads were perfect: cigarettes, refrigerators, cars with those wide shining grills. The classifieds were full of births and jobs and lost dogs. The comics page had Peanuts, but the strip was wrong, too—a Sunday panel of Snoopy lying on his doghouse, thinking: “Some days you miss the bullet. Some days the bullet misses you.”

I went upstairs to Grandma’s bedroom.

Her jewelry box was still on the dresser, her rosary coiled like a question mark atop it. In the top drawer, where she kept important papers—insurance, the deed, folded letters—there was an envelope with my name, written in the same block letters as the bundles.

I opened it with clumsy fingers.

Inside was a single sheet of lined paper, written in blue ink.

“If you are reading this,” it began, “then I am gone, and I pray your world is the gentler one.”

I sat down on her bed.

She wrote about 1963 first. She wrote about sitting in her parents’ living room, watching Walter Cronkite take off his glasses. She wrote about the way the air changed, about how her mother cried in hiccups and her father, who never drank, poured whiskey into his coffee.

And then, she said, something…happened.

The TV image rolled, there was a prickling like static, and then the broadcast snapped back. Now Cronkite was smiling, reporting that an assassination attempt had been thwarted. Her father’s cup was empty. Her mother was not crying. Her own cheeks were dry.

“But I remembered,” she wrote. “I remembered him dying. I remembered your Grandpa, then my boyfriend, saying it meant the world could break. I remembered the funeral that never happened. After that, I paid close attention.”

There were other times. 1969, in the bar where she worked then, a cheer rising for a second “first” moon landing, though she remembered the announcer saying it was the first. 1971, a night where the stars went briefly wrong, a flicker like bad film in the sky. Each time, she felt a lurch in her stomach, like stepping off a curb that wasn’t there.

“I started keeping the papers,” she wrote. “Because I thought: either I am losing my mind, or the world is. And then I met him.”

Him was a man who came into the diner in 1972 when she was twenty-eight and newly married to my grandfather. He’d read the paper she’d just put at his place and frowned. “That’s not right,” he said. “None of this is right.”

He’d told her, quietly, about fractures. About “when they push.” About attempts to steer certain events away from catastrophe. Not God, not angels. “Just people who have seen too far ahead,” he’d said. “Sometimes we succeed. Every success breaks another branch off the tree.”

“He said he shouldn’t have told me,” Grandma wrote. “But it was already too late for my memory. He said some people kept the old version like a scar.”

He told her to keep proof: original papers from the days that felt wrong. Not to show anyone, not yet. “One day,” he said, “someone you love will see both sets of tracks. Let them decide what to believe.”

She wrote about the Challenger that, in her memory, broke apart in cold January air, and the one in the paper that did not. She remembered both. She woke up some mornings knowing two sequences of decades, layered, contradicting, the way you can remember two drafts of the same apology.

“I don’t know what is real,” she wrote. “I only know I remember the dead that your world doesn’t have, and I miss them, and I don’t know if they ever lived for you.”

The letter ended simply:

“If your world is kinder, forgive me for wishing for the other sometimes. It had its own beauties. It had you, in some form. Keep the papers or burn them. I’ve spent a lifetime straddling two stories. I won’t ask you to do the same.

Love,
Grandma”

I went back downstairs as dusk pressed its gray thumb against the windows.

The newspapers lay where I had left them: seven neat impossibilities.

I thought about our world: about assassinations and wars, about shuttles lost and towers falling, about elections that hinged on a handful of votes. About the fragile thread of progress we told ourselves was inevitable.

And I thought about another world: assassinations averted, treaties signed in the wake of orbital scares, Gores and Gateways and second contacts in the sky. And maybe catastrophes I could not imagine, bound up in those different choices.

The house hummed gently with the old refrigerator’s cycle, the same sound I’d heard as a child falling asleep on this couch. Dust drifted through a column of fading light, each mote suspended, undecided.

Proof sat on the table in front of me, or madness, or both.

I picked up the 2012 issue, my thumb brushing the headline about beings above the Pacific. The ink did not smear.

Gently, I stacked the newspapers in chronological order. I rewrapped them in the plastic sheeting, tied new twine around them. The realtor would come next week. Strangers would walk these floors and remark on the quaint fixtures.

I carried the bundles back up to the attic.

I did not put them in the insulation. I left them in a plain cardboard box near the hatch, where anyone thorough enough would find them.

The letter I kept.

If the world could be edited, rewritten mid-sentence, then somewhere, maybe, my leaving the box in plain sight was the smallest push in some direction. A nudge toward someone else reading, doubting, remembering.

History is what we agree to remember.

I climbed down from the attic and turned off the light, leaving the newspapers waiting in the dark, their pages full of lives that might have been, or still were, just a fraction of a second away.

samples.prompt: You're a small animal about to be captured by a bird of prey. You can speak to each other.
samples.output:
I saw his shadow first.

It slid over the grass in front of me, a black, reaching thing that did not match any tree, any bush, any cloud. It was too precise. Too sharp. The air above me shivered.

I froze, one paw lifted, whiskers trembling.

“Don’t run,” came a voice from the sky, clear and level, as if spoken directly into my skull. “You’ll only make it more interesting.”

I tilted my head up. He was circling, wide wings cutting easy turns in the pale morning. A hawk, mottled chest, eyes like polished amber stones. I’d seen him before, far off, a rumor riding the thermals. I’d never heard him speak.

“I didn’t know your kind talked,” I said, because terror, for me, comes out as sarcasm. That’s why my siblings say I’ll die first. They thought it would be the fox.

“We usually don’t waste words,” he replied. “Energy conservation. But you’re…calm.”

“I’m not calm,” I said. “My heart is trying to escape through my teeth.”

He laughed, or made a noise like a clipped chirp. “Run then.”

“No,” I said. “If I run, you dive. If you dive, I die faster. I’d like to spend at least a few more moments considering my poor life choices.”

He descended a little in an easy spiral, not close enough to strike—close enough that I could see the flex in his primaries, the faint sway of his tail.

“You do realize,” he said, “that whether you stand there and speak or sprint for that hedge, the end is the same.”

“That hedge has a hole you can’t get through,” I said.

“You’re assuming I’d let you reach it.”

I considered the hedge, the dark slit beneath it. Seven body-lengths. Maybe eight. In his eyes, that was one heartbeat.

“What if I told you I’m poisonous?” I tried. “Terribly, terribly poisonous.”

“I watched you yesterday,” he said. “You chewed clover and squeaked at a beetle. You’re about as poisonous as a cloud.”

“You watch us?” I asked. “Like, as a hobby?”

“I hunt you,” he said. “And hunting requires attention. I saw you share your seeds with the smaller ones. You push them toward the burrow first. You come out last. That’s why I chose you.”

“That’s the opposite of a compliment,” I said.

“It’s respect,” he answered.

We were quiet for a moment. The field hummed around us with the small, indifferent lives of insects. The wind carried the scent of damp soil and distant smoke. My heart was indeed battering my ribs, but the words gave my paws something to do besides bolt.

“Can we negotiate?” I asked finally.

“You think you have leverage?”

“I have…conversation,” I said. “Choice of last words. Maybe insight into your menu planning. Don’t you predators like variety? Philosophical variety?”

He tilted his wings, curious. “You would spend your last moments talking instead of fleeing?”

“Yes.”

“That’s irrational,” he said.

“Fleeing would only help you,” I said. “Talking helps me. And maybe you. You sounded bored.”

That hit. His flight path tightened, a smaller circle.

“Speak, then,” he said. “Make it worth the altitude.”

“I want to know,” I said, “if you feel bad.”

“About eating you?” He didn’t even flinch. “No.”

“That was fast.”

“You want a lie?”

“Yes,” I said. “But I’ll take the truth.”

“I feel hunger,” he said. “I feel the thrill of speed, the satisfaction of precision. If I miss, I feel annoyance. If I don’t eat, I feel weakness. When I feed my chick, I feel…something that might be close to the soft thing you feel when you push others into the burrow first. I don’t know your word for it. I don’t feel bad.”

“What about me?” I asked. “Me, specifically. Does it matter who I am, or am I just mouse-shaped calories?”

“Vole,” I said, offended at my own correction. “I’m a vole.”

“Vole-shaped calories,” he said. “I watched you. That could have made me hesitate. It did not.”

I swallowed. “So why talk to me at all?”

“Because you stopped,” he said. “You looked at my shadow and did not bolt. You faced up. Curiosity is a rare thing down there. Most of you are just fear wrapped in fur. You are fear with questions. I can appreciate that.”

“I appreciate your appreciation,” I muttered. “Does that earn me anything? A head start? Preferably in the direction of Not Dying?”

He considered. “I could give you a choice: die running or die still.”

“That’s not a choice.”

“It is,” he said. “Most never get one.”

I sniffed. The hedge smelled like damp and safety and roots. The sky smelled like distance and thin, cold air.

“What’s it like up there?” I asked.

He blinked. “Irrelevant to your current problem.”

“Humor me,” I said. “I’m enriching your prey experience, remember?”

He leveled out, gliding, his voice a smooth continuation of his motion. “It’s clean,” he said. “From up here, your scurrying is a pattern. Trails become lines. Lines become shapes. The river is a silver snake; the road is a scar. The wind holds you—you do not cling, you ride. The sun is closer. When I dive, the world rushes to meet me. There is a moment when everything else is slow, and I am the only fast thing that has ever existed.”

“That sounds…nice,” I said, surprised at the sincerity in my voice.

“It is.”

“And down here?” I said. “Down here is damp, and someone is always trying to eat you.”

“And yet you share your seeds.”

“And yet you watch your chick,” I shot back.

He inclined his head. “So you understand. I kill you, we live. You hide food, they live. The line is simpler for me. For you, it is all burrows and roots and guessing.”

“You think your line is simple because you’re at the top,” I said. “If you miss me, do you go hungry?”

“Yes.”

“Does your chick hate you if you fail?”

“My chick dies if I fail enough,” he said. “Hatred is a luxury of the fed.”

“Oh,” I said. I had not thought of that. Predators, in our stories, were always smug, always full, always cruel for fun. None of our stories wondered what happened when the sky went home empty.

We were both quiet.

“This is worse, you know,” I said softly. “Knowing you have a chick.”

“Why?”

“Because I can almost like you,” I said. “And I don’t want to almost like the thing that’s about to break my neck.”

“I do not intend to make you like me,” he said. “I intend to kill you cleanly.”

“That’s something,” I admitted.

“I could, if you prefer, play with you,” he said, matter-of-fact. “Drop you. Snatch you again. Some do.”

“Do you?” I asked.

“No,” he said. “I don’t like wasted effort.”

I let out a breath. “All right. New idea. Don’t eat me. Eat that rabbit. Look at him. He’s smug.”

“I am not a fox,” he said. “I don’t chase just anything large and fluffy. I chose you. You are the calculation I made.”

“Terrible math,” I grumbled.

“You’re close to the hedge,” he said. “That is part of the interest.”

“I knew it,” I said. “You’re bored.”

His wings flexed. “Even hunters are allowed aesthetics.”

We looked at each other—me from my dim, trembling little patch of earth, him from his cold, high cathedral of air.

“If I run now,” I said slowly, “you kill me.”

“Almost certainly.”

“If I stay,” I said, “you kill me.”

“Yes.”

“If I keep talking?”

“I will keep circling,” he said. “But I am getting lower.”

I could hear the rush of his feathers now. His shadow was no longer a distant smear; it was a cloak over my paws.

“Do you ever think it’s unfair?” I blurted. “That you can see everything and I can barely see past the next tuft of grass?”

“No,” he said. “I think it is beautiful. You have tunnels of shadow and smell. I have oceans of light. We are built for different maps.”

“That’s not an answer.”

“It is the only one we get,” he said.

I licked my paw, an absurd, automatic grooming. “If our places were swapped,” I said, “I’d feel bad.”

He did not hesitate. “If our places were swapped, you would eat me and not think of me again.”

“That’s rude,” I said.

“That’s survival,” he said. “We do not get to be saints and live. Not out here.”

The hedge’s darkness pulled at the corner of my eye like a promise. I could feel every muscle in my body focused into a single, coiled spring.

“So this is it,” I said.

“This is always it,” he replied. “For someone.”

“Will it hurt?”

“A snap,” he said. “A twist. You’ll know the sky for a heartbeat. Think of that as a gift.”

“A terrible, terrifying gift.”

“Few of your kind ever see from where I see,” he said. “They die in the grass. You’ll die in the air.”

“You’re very proud of that,” I said.

“I’m trying to be kind in the only language I know.”

“That’s the worst part,” I said, a thin laugh escaping me. “I almost believe you.”

“Run or don’t,” he said gently. “Choose the story you want to tell yourself in the last second.”

I thought of my siblings, of the small ones who hid behind me in the burrow entrance. I thought: if he eats me, maybe he doesn’t need to eat them. Maybe the arithmetic works like that, just for today.

“I’ll stay,” I said. My voice shook, but the decision steadied me. “I don’t want my last feeling to be panic. I want it to be…bravery-ish.”

He dipped his head. “Then look up,” he said.

So I did.

For a sliver of time, I saw him not as doom but as shape and strength and sunlit feathers, as a living arrow falling out of the blinding blue, perfect and terrible and real.

“You’re beautiful,” I said.

“Thank you,” he answered.

And then he folded his wings.

samples.prompt: You dream every night of being part of a wolf pack and terrorizing villagers in the country side, every morning you wake up in your bed. One evening there's a knock at the door, a dark figure clad in a wide brimmed hat and leather trench coat stands on your door step.
samples.output:
The knock comes just as the kettle begins to whistle.

I’m standing in the dim yellow of my kitchen, rubbing sleep from my eyes even though it’s half past eight at night. The days are useless to me now. I sleep through them when I can, dragged down by exhaustion that isn’t the usual kind. It’s the weight of forests and blood and moonlight. It’s the ache in my bones where, in dreams, they crack and rearrange.

Three months the dreams have lasted. Every night without fail: the change, the pack, the hunt.

It’s always the same country, though I have never seen it awake—winding dirt roads, low stone walls, hills stitched with thin trees and fog hanging in loose, graying sheets. We run through it: a dozen of us, shadows made of muscle and fur, breath steaming in the cold air. I know their scents, their sounds, their names that aren’t human, that live in the throat and the mind more than on any tongue. I know I’m one of them. I can feel the earth in my claws, the wind in my open, grinning jaw.

And I remember.

That’s the worst part. I wake with all of it intact: the hunt, the screams, the copper taste of blood. There is no mercy of forgetting.

The dreams never blink out before the end. I always see it through. Always the same last image: a village, rough and half-asleep, lanterns and candles held up by hands that shake. A woman clutching a child. A man shouting a name. The pack fanning out, the leader raising his muzzle. My own body surging forward when he gives the signal. That savage, exultant joy as we fall on them.

Then my alarm blares. My sheets are tangled. My heart is a hammer trying to break bone.

I hide the bruises. I chalk the soreness up to bad sleep. I scrub my mouth until my gums bleed because it feels like there’s something between my teeth.

And now, at my door, a knock. Not loud, not desperate. Measured. Too polite.

The kettle screams. The knock comes again: three calm raps.

“Hold on,” I call, though my voice comes out thin.

I turn off the stove, leave the kettle shrieking in my ears, and cross my small hallway. My apartment is nothing like the places in my dreams. There’s nothing wild here. Beige carpet, white walls, a faint smell of detergent. Yet the closer I get to the door, the more it feels like the edge of the trees in that other place, where the fields open and the village begins.

It’s ridiculous, but I already know that whoever is standing out there is here for me.

I open the door.

He’s tall, too tall for the frame of the building somehow, like the hallway has been stretched around him. A wide-brimmed hat throws his face into shadow. A leather trench coat falls straight to his boots, slick with recent rain that hasn’t fallen anywhere near this block. His hands are gloved. At his throat, a narrow strip of white cloth. Old-fashioned, out of time.

He removes his hat as I stare. Underneath, his hair is dark and short, brushed straight back. His face is not monstrous. It’s average: pale, lined a little around the eyes, jaw rough with stubble. His eyes, though, are like polished coal, catching every speck of light and swallowing it.

“Good evening,” he says, like this is normal. His voice is low, accented faintly with something I can’t place. Old Europe, maybe. “May I come in?”

No introduction. No I’m lost or I’m with the building or I’ve got a package for you. He looks at me like he already has.

“I think you have the wrong—”

“No,” he says, soft, almost apologetic. “I don’t.”

The hallway smells suddenly wrong, like wet leaves and iron. Like my dreams.

I grip the edge of the door until my knuckles ache. “Who are you?”

He tilts his head, studying my face with an attention that feels clinical but not unkind.

“You’ve been dreaming,” he says. “Every night. Running with the pack. Hunting the villagers near Dunlowe. The stone bridge. The well in the square. The woman with the red shawl. The boy with the rabbit.”

My mouth goes dry. I hadn’t remembered the rabbit until he said it. I see, vividly, my dream-self’s paw on its fur as it tries to run.

I try to slam the door. My body doesn’t react. It isn’t that he stops me, it’s that the signal never reaches my hands.

“There it is,” he murmurs, as if to himself. “The drag. You feel it, don’t you? The lag between wanting and doing?”

My heart jackhammers. “What do you want?”

“To come in,” he says. “We shouldn’t discuss this in the hall.”

He doesn’t push. Just waits. People coming home might see him. Someone might pass by. None do. The building is too quiet. The whole world is suddenly too quiet.

“You’re not supposed to invite strangers into your home,” I say, grasping at something normal.

“I’m not a stranger,” he replies. “Not to the part of you that runs on four legs.”

A hot, nauseous wave of memory rolls over me: the alpha’s flank brushing mine; the brush of tails; the echo of thought-not-words: pack. The way my dream-self throws back its head when called. The obedience that isn’t obedience at all, just rightness.

I step aside.

“Come in,” I say.

He does, ducking his head slightly. Up close, I notice more details—fine scratches across the leather coat, something like a burn mark near the left cuff. He glances around my living room, the couch, the coffee table crowded with empty mugs I’ve been too tired to wash.

“Nice place,” he says, without mockery. He sets his hat on the arm of a chair and unbuttons his coat. Underneath, he wears a dark vest, darker shirt. At his belt, there’s a bulge that could be anything. My brain supplies gun. Knife. Cross.

I hover near the kitchen. The kettle has gone quiet, an eerie silence after its scream. “You said Dunlowe,” I say. “That’s the village. From the dreams.”

“It is not from the dreams,” he replies. “Please, sit.”

“I’d rather stand.”

He nods, accepting. “Then I’ll stand as well. Fair is fair.”

We face each other, a few feet apart.

“You are not unique,” he says. “This will sound like a cruelty, but it is a mercy first: You are not special. This isn’t a story about chosen ones or ancient destinies. You are one of several. You carry something borrowed.”

I laugh once, too loud. “I sell office chairs for a living.”

“And at night?” he asks.

I open my mouth and close it.

“What are you?” I say instead.

“A shepherd,” he says. “Of a kind. A warden, perhaps. My name is Elias. I am—was—assigned to watch over Dunlowe and its… border issues.”

“You make it sound like a zoning problem.”

“It is, in a sense. Two territories that should not touch have grown thin between. The villagers. The pack.”

I swallow, throat tight. “The pack from my dreams.”

“Not from,” Elias says. “In. You are there. They are there. The villagers are there. What happens there is…real. Different layer, same world. Someone, some thing, has found a way to…bridge. To pull through sleepers from far away. To lend them teeth and fury.”

I shake my head. “No, I wake up here. Every time. I’ve never left this bed.”

He raises a brow. “Look at your hands.”

I do. They’re my hands. Pale. A faint crescent of pink at one nail from an old hangnail. The raw skin at the base of my thumb where I’ve gnawed it.

“Palms,” he says.

I turn them over.

There are calluses there now, thickening along the pads where fingers meet palm, as if I’ve spent weeks gripping something rough, hauling myself over stone. They weren’t there a month ago.

“Your legs,” he continues. “The soreness along the shins. The ache at the base of the skull when you wake. The smell under your nails.”

“I shower—”

“Smell your nails,” he says.

“I’m not—”

“Humor me.”

I lift my hand, feeling ridiculous, and inhale. Under the soap, there is something else. Damp earth. Something wild.

I recoil. “It’s a dream,” I say, but it sounds like pleading.

“The barrier between dream and elsewhere is thinner than people like to believe,” Elias replies. “Usually, it works in one direction: a mind travels, sees wonders, horrors, then returns alone. But someone is pulling more than seeing. You are not the only one. There are others who wake with soil in their beds, water in their lungs, ash in their teeth. You have been busy at night, all of you. The pack is stronger for it. The villagers are dying for it.”

A pulse of remembered delight: hot blood, snapping bones. The world narrowing to chase and kill. My stomach lurches.

“I’d never—” I begin.

“You already have,” he says, gently. “Not by choice. That is why I am here.”

The room feels smaller. The hum of the fridge is too loud. “Who’s doing it?” I ask.

“That’s the trouble,” Elias says. “I don’t know. Whatever has twisted the pack likes to hide. It uses you—outsiders—to amplify what it can’t do alone. Tonight, the line grows thinner. Tonight, I need you awake when you cross.”

“Awake?”

He nods. “Conscious. Aware. You’ve been riding along, half-drowned in the wolf. Tonight, you will go fully. You will remember fully. And you will fight it. From within.”

Cold spreads through me, inch by inch. “You want me to go back there. On purpose.”

“Yes.”

“No.” It comes out reflexive, sharp, blessedly human.

He regards me steadily. “You think I enjoy asking? I have hunted your kind for a very long time.”

“My kind,” I repeat. “I’m not—”

“A monster?” Elias shrugs one shoulder. “No. Not by nature. But you are implicated. The blood is half on your paws, half on the thing that wrapped them around villagers’ throats. You can shrug and sip your tea and say, ‘It was just a dream,’ and more will die. Or you can accept that some doors do not close just because you shut your eyes.”

“I’m one person,” I say. “I don’t know how to fight some…dream parasite with…werewolf Wi-Fi.”

Despite everything, his mouth twitches. “I needed to see if you’d make jokes. Good. You haven’t cracked yet.”

“I feel cracked.”

“You will feel worse,” he says. “Listen carefully. Tonight, when you sleep, you will feel the pull. When your bones begin to change, hold on to yourself. Remember this room. Remember my face. Remember your own name. It will resist. There will be a voice offering you oblivion with teeth. Do not give in. Look for the one thing that doesn’t belong.”

“This sounds like a riddle.”

“It’s a trap,” he corrects. “The thing hiding in the pack must expose itself to command you. When you see it, mark it. I will be hunting from the other side. Our work will meet in the middle.”

He speaks like it’s already decided.

“What if I can’t?” I whisper.

“Then you will likely not wake up here again,” Elias says. He doesn’t soften it. “You will be his, and I will have to put you down there. I would rather not.”

My eyes burn. I’m not the crying type, but terror is a solvent. “Why me?”

“Because it chose you,” he says. “Because you’ve survived this long without going mad. That suggests a stubbornness I can use.”

“That’s a hell of a recruitment pitch.”

“I’m out of time for better ones,” Elias says, and glances at the clock on my wall: 8:44. “It will come soon. You feel it, don’t you? The heaviness behind your eyes.”

I do. A weight like hands pressing down on my skull. I’d thought it was just lack of sleep. Now it feels predatory.

“So I just…go to bed and…what, wrestle a demon wolf in my head?”

“More or less,” he says. He picks up his hat. “One more thing.”

“Of course there is.”

“If you start to forget who you are, think of something small. Mundane. The brand of your toothpaste. The name on your work ID. The color of this door. Details are anchors. Monsters lose interest in details. Use that.”

He moves to the door.

“Wait,” I say. “You’re just leaving?”

“I’ll see you very soon,” he says. “In one place or another.”

He opens the door. The hallway beyond is darker than it should be. For a moment, I see not beige walls but trees, ink-black and shivering. He steps through, and it’s just a hallway again.

He doesn’t look back as he disappears around the corner.

I close the door. My legs tremble. The kettle sits cold on the stove. I leave the light on. I stare at the couch, the bed, the clock—8:47, 8:51, 8:59. Every blink feels heavier.

You’re not special, he’d said. You’re implicated.

I make myself brush my teeth, thinking: mint, plastic bristles, white foam, the crack in the bathroom tile shaped like a lightning bolt. I say my name out loud. I touch the beige, the cheap lamp, the chipped mug.

When the pull comes, it is not gentle.

It tears.

My knees hit the mattress. My skin crawls. Far away, a full moon climbs over a village I have never seen awake, and from the trees, my pack lifts their heads and howl.

This time, I howl with them—and I remember why.

samples.prompt: Everyone on earth is born with a familiar. Yours however, is a brick.
samples.output:
I noticed mine didn’t move.

On the morning of my Binding, the midwife had cleared space at the foot of the bed. “Put her there,” she’d said. My mother, sweaty and pale with the ending of the ordeal and the beginning of another, had propped me up to see.

There it was: a brick.

Not a fox blinking in the lamplight, not a small dragon hiccupping smoke, not a barn owl preening new feathers. No sleek panther tail curling, no coils of silver serpent. Just a rectangular, reddish-brown brick resting on a folded towel, speckled and scuffed like it had been pried out of a half-collapsed chimney.

“Is… is it sleeping?” my father had asked.

The midwife had been in the business too long to lie. She poked it with one blunt finger. It made a dense, hollow clack that everyone in the room felt in their teeth.

“Hm,” she said. “Well. That’s unusual.”

They tried words first: anomaly, quirk, latent form. Familiars sometimes arrived late to their full shape. Kittens became tigers; sparrows unfolded into phoenixes. There was precedent for beginnings that were not the final story.

But the years went on and my brick remained a brick.

By the time I could walk, I dragged it with me. It had no name, at least not one anyone said out loud. “The brick,” we called it. “Where’s the brick? Don’t forget your brick.” It was heavy, heavier than it looked. When I was two, it took both hands. At four, I could manage under one arm, staggering. By seven, I’d developed a kind of one-sided strength: right arm corded, right shoulder higher than the left.

I did not speak to it, at first. Other children chattered constantly with their familiars, whose ears flicked and tails swished in response. Mine did nothing. But some mornings, when the house was quiet, I’d run my fingers over its rough surface—over the pockmarks, the hairline crack, the place where the color shifted just slightly. It was always warm. I told myself that meant something.

At school, they taught us familiar etiquette. Do not feed familiars chocolate, lilies, raw river water. Do not bind familiars, do not trim feathers without their consent, do not mock those whose familiars are smaller than yours—apparently that had been an issue.
