“What about familiars that are… different?” my first teacher asked delicately, eyes darting to my desk, where my brick sat on a folded cloth to protect the wood.

The cloth didn’t match the others. It was one my mother had embroidered, as if thread and care could make this better.

“Like what?” asked a boy with a velvet-nosed calf familiar that kept trying to lick my brick.

“Like Mina’s,” my teacher said, finally.

They all looked.

I straightened. The brick did not.

“What about mine?” I asked.

The teacher hesitated. “Familiars express in many ways,” she said. “Mina’s is… stable.”

“Stable,” repeated the boy. “It’s a brick.”

The class laughed. My brick, traitorously, did nothing.

“Ignore them,” my mother said that night, kneading dough so hard it squeaked. Her familiar—a gray mare tall enough that I could stand beneath her neck—lowered her head to breathe warm air along my shoulder. “They don’t know what your brick will be.”

“What if it’s just a brick?” I whispered.

She didn’t answer right away. The dough rose and fell under her fists.

My father spoke from the doorway. “Then it will be the best brick.”

Easy to say. Harder to believe when I watched my classmates’ familiars grow sleek and sure, when the owl began bringing his girl pencils she’d lost, when the tiny salamander on Tomas’ shoulder flicked its tail and sizzled away raindrops before they hit his homework.

I grew, too. Taller, sharper. My brick grew only metaphorically heavier.

At eleven, they tested our bonds. They led us into the gymnasium one by one, familiars at our heels or perched our shoulders or fluttering nervously. A proctor drew a line of chalk. “Stand on this side,” she told us. “Familiars on the other. Now call them.”

They wanted to see: compliance, eagerness, the invisible cord between.

The boy with the calf called and the calf trotted, tail swishing. The girl with the fox clapped, and the fox bounded over the line with a yip.

I set my brick down across the chalk.

“Call it,” the proctor said, tone neutral.

I stared at the brick. The brick, obedient to its nature, did nothing.

“Call it,” she repeated.

“I don’t know how,” I said.

“Like you would call a friend,” she suggested.

I felt thirty sets of eyes. My cheeks burned.

“Come here,” I told the brick, quietly.

It did not move.

The proctor scribbled something. “Next.”

I picked up the brick. It felt heavier than it had that morning.

That night I sat on my bed, brick on my lap. I ran my thumbs along the edges until my skin rasped.

“What is wrong with you?” I asked, under my breath.

It was the first time I’d spoken to it like it could answer.

It did not answer.

Middle school is unkind even when your familiar is perfect. With a brick, it was open season. They joked about building walls around me so no one had to see it. They asked if I was going to throw it at my future, since it clearly wasn’t coming on its own. They asked if perhaps my “real” familiar had been stolen, and this brick was a decoy, because what kind of magic would link a human soul to fired mud?

I started keeping it in my bag. That was its own small scandal. “You can’t hide your soul,” the counselor said, gently reproving.

“My soul,” I said, “is chipping the furniture.”

She sighed. “Have you considered that its… unconventional form might be a lesson?”

“In humiliation?” I asked.

“In patience,” she said.

The mare snorted from the hallway. Even my mother’s familiar didn’t buy that.

The turning point came when the science wing caught fire.

I was thirteen. We were dissecting something that smelled suspiciously like regret. The teacher’s raven familiar hopped along the cabinets, supervising. Then the back burner—left on for Bunsen flames—licked too high. Alcohol spilled. Curtains caught. The smoke alarms howled.

“Familiars, guide your partners!” the teacher shouted, voice shredded with fear.

The raven tried. The salamander dived through the flames, immune and panicked. The fox yelped. The air thickened with black.

My classmates hesitated, stumbling, coughing. Familiars can see through smoke, but humans can’t. You’re supposed to trust your familiar. Let them lead. That’s the point.

Mine couldn’t.

The door was blocked with desks. Someone was crying. Someone was yelling for their hare. The world narrowed to heat and the taste of burning metal.

My brick sat on my desk where I’d placed it, unassuming.

I picked it up.

There is a kind of knowing that does not arrive through words. Standing in a room turning orange, lungs clawing, I knew: this, at least, I could do. Brick meets glass. Brick meets door. Brick makes a path.

I lobbed it at the window. The impact cracked the pane. The second throw shattered it. Glass fell outward in a bright, ringing sheet. Fresh air knifed in. Kids pushed toward it, coughing. I grabbed my brick from the sill, ignoring the blood on my fingers, and used it to jam the frame up where it stuck. They climbed out.

Later, someone said I’d been brave. The principal used the word hero. The local paper ran a picture of me with soot on my face, brick in hand.

I remember just feeling very, very tired.

At home, my mother cupped my scraped hands. “Are you hurt?”

“No,” I said.

She glanced at the brick, streaked with singe marks, a new corner chipped off. “Is it?”

I wanted to laugh. Instead I said, “It did what it was meant to.”

It was only afterward that I realized how strangely that had come out of my mouth. As if I’d known, in that moment, without thinking.

My familiar never changed shape. Years passed. Familiars around me reached their full forms at sixteen or so, settled into the appearances they’d apparently been circling toward all along. Some grew wings. Some antlers. One boy’s goldfish familiar stepped out of its bowl, shook off its scales and became a woman made of rain.

My brick remained a brick.

I went to university. The admissions interviewer, whose familiar was a lynx draped over the back of his chair like a spilled shadow, raised an eyebrow when I set the brick carefully by my feet.

“That your partner?”

“Yes.”

He waited, perhaps expecting a reveal. None came.

“What has it done for you?” he asked finally.

It was a kinder question than most.

“It’s stayed,” I said. “It’s… useful.”

“Useful,” he echoed, skeptical.

“In a fire,” I said. “Or a flood, you put them in sandbags. To hold up shelves. To anchor tarps so the wind doesn’t take them. To weight down what might otherwise blow away. You can build with bricks. You can make a home.”

He watched me a moment longer. Then he smiled, a small, genuine thing.

“We need people who know how to build,” he said. “Welcome to the program.”

The myth about familiars is that they are here to dazzle: talking wolves, feathered serpents, light made flesh. Some are. People point at them, envy and fear and wishful hunger braided together.

Mine never once caught a fish for me, never once curled around my neck to keep me warm. It did not whisper secrets or predict storms or appear in the margins of paintings as an omen.

What it did was this:

- It made me visible, so I had to decide who I was when people stared.
- It refused to be anything but itself, so I had to learn the difference between “less than” and “different.”
- It was heavy, so I grew strong.
- It was ordinary, so I had to learn to see what is sacred in ordinary things.

In my third year, in an architecture elective I’d taken on a whim, the professor—a woman whose familiar was a stack of perfectly balanced stones—asked us to imagine dwellings that responded to their inhabitants’ souls.

“Mine,” I said without raising my hand, “would be brick.”

She looked at me over her glasses. “Of course it would.”

After class, she stopped me. “You know,” she said, “in the old cities they used to bake the bricks with fingerprints in them. The makers pressed their hands into the clay. Every wall held a record of the people who built it. Solidarity, fired in.”

I thought of my brick: warm against my palms, edges worn smooth where I’d carried it, new chips from that day in the science lab.

“Maybe that’s all a familiar is,” she said. “A reminder of the work you’re meant to do. Some of us are rivers. Some storms. Some… foundations.”

That night, in my dorm room, I set my brick on the windowsill. The city hummed outside, full of bright and miraculous companions. Their silhouettes crossed the streetlights: wings, horns, coils, paws.

“I think I get it,” I told the brick.

It didn’t glow. It didn’t twitch. It just sat there, solid in the spill of yellow light.

But when I rested my hand on it, the contact felt like standing on something that would not give way. Like the first layer of stone in a house that wouldn’t fall.

Everyone on earth is born with a familiar. Some fly, some burn, some sing.

Mine is a brick.

I used to think that meant I’d been cheated. Now I understand.

This world, for all its magic, still needs something to stand on.

samples.prompt: 2 serial killers start dating with the intention of making their new SO their next victim. Neither one knows the other is out to get them.
samples.output:
They meet at a bookstore because that feels safely ordinary.

Elliot is in true crime, of course, skimming a case study he already knows by heart. Mara is in self-help, which is a joke she tells only herself. Both of them are dressed in muted colors, the kind that blend into security camera footage like background noise. Both of them are tired of being careful, which is the sort of tired that makes people sloppy.

Their hands brush over the same paperback.

“Oh, sorry,” Mara says, fingers withdrawing like a well-rehearsed flinch.

“No, it’s—go ahead,” Elliot replies. She’s pretty. Not obvious pretty, but clever pretty. Her eyes do a quick inventory of him: shoes, watch, posture. Predatory, he thinks, then immediately corrects himself. Perceptive. He smiles.

“You sure?” she asks, tipping the book. “Pathology of Violence. Not exactly light reading.”

“Occupational curiosity.” He lets that hang, one bait among many.

“Are you in criminology or something?” she asks.

“Or something,” he says. Her eyebrow rises, amused, unworried. “I’m Elliot.”

“Mara.” She holds the book, then sets it down as if that decision is part of a larger one. “You want to grab coffee?”

He doesn’t. He never mixes. But she seems…interesting. And interest is rare enough that he follows it like a trail of blood.

“Sure,” he says.

Mara suggests the café across the street with big windows and a barista who writes affirmations on lids. Elliot notes exits, counts cameras, tracks line of sight. Mara watches him watch the room. That notch of suspicion in her is automatic, a reflex like checking if a knife is still where you left it. He seems like the type who thinks three moves ahead. She respects that. He’ll be fun.

They sit.

“So,” she says. “What do you do?”

He likes to tell lies close to the truth. “Freelance research. Case analysis. I help defense teams with…less straightforward clients.”

“That sounds like you say ‘I can fix him’ professionally,” she says.

He huffs out a laugh. “I help them understand patterns. Motives. That sort of thing.”

“Patterns are everything,” Mara says, almost warmly.

“And you?”

“Night shifts,” she says. “Isn’t that ominous?” She lets him picture nurse, bartender, something easy. “Inventory manager at a distribution center. Boring, large, anonymous. The highlight of my day is forklift traffic. Unless I go to bookstores.”

“Guess I picked the right day,” he says.

She holds his gaze just a breath too long. He notices. She notices that he notices.

He decides quickly. She fits.

She decides quickly. He’ll be a beautiful knife in her collection, metaphorical or otherwise.

They exchange numbers.

—

Elliot’s apartment is clean in the way that comes from understanding luminol. The walls are bare, not minimalist but undecorated, as if he’s never tried to prove to anyone that he has a personality. He opens his laptop after she leaves later that night, fingers hovering above keys. But there’s nothing to find—Mara is smoke. Social media is thin, curated. Background check returns little. A job that exists but leaves no flourish, a rental with no online footprint.

He’s impressed. He assumes she’s paranoid from bad exes, or identity theft fears. He doesn’t consider the simplest explanation: someone as careful as him.

Mara goes home to her neat little townhouse and opens a box beneath the bed. Inside, carefully wrapped in cloth, lie souvenirs: a watch, a bus pass, a silver ring. She thinks about adding eyes that match Elliot’s to her memory. She scrolls through his sparse online presence: a LinkedIn with vague consulting roles, a few college photos, a tagged shot at a conference on behavioral analysis.

“Perfect,” she murmurs.

She’s smart enough not to research him too deeply on traceable networks. He might notice. She assumes “case analysis” is a polite term for something close to what she does. A monster-adjacent man, maybe. Easier to get him alone without anyone wondering when he disappears.

They both sleep well.

—

Their first month is a tender, plausible romance.

- She teases him about his bookshelf: “You know, normal people don’t alphabetize by victim.”
- He teases her about her meticulous kitchen: “You could do surgery in here.”
- They say each other’s names like they’re getting used to how they sound in crisis.

He takes her to small, quiet restaurants. She chooses seats with backs to walls. He notices and thinks, She’s been hurt. I’ll get her to trust me enough to follow me anywhere.

She notices him pick cutlery absentmindedly, weighing it. She thinks, He’s used to making choices about tools.

They circle each other with patient affection, both thinking they are coaxing a fragile animal closer to the trap.

Their first night together ends in his place. He’s already moved the things that can’t be seen. She scans the bathroom, finds nothing incriminating beyond a discoloration in grout that only someone like her would notice. Bleach, old and overused, will leave that faint trace. She smiles behind the shower curtain and thinks, Hello, Elliot.

He watches her as she falls asleep, hair fanned over his pillow. He counts her breaths. Calculates doses, times, alibis, places where no one would look.

Soon.

—

Elliot’s plan forms gently.

He’ll schedule a weekend cabin away—just remote enough to be plausible, just close enough to services that no one questions it. He’ll drive. He’ll choose a place with a lake deep and cold. An accident on a dock at night. Alcohol, a slip, a panic. Heartbreaking. Tragic.

He pictures her face submerged, beautiful and still. He isn’t cruel, he tells himself. He is precise.

Mara’s plan takes a different shape.

She’ll invite him to tour the distribution center on a Sunday. “No one there, we can be stupid in forklifts,” she jokes. She’ll guide him through the labyrinth of pallets, up to the mezzanine, switch off the lights, and let gravity and concrete complete the narrative: industrial accident. Clip the harness, loosen the rail.

She imagines his hand slipping from hers. She tells herself it’s nothing personal. They never are.

They both underestimate each other the way predators do: assuming prey.

—

Three months in, he invites her to the cabin.

He does it while cooking. The domestic scene calms suspicion. “Got a lead on this cabin by a lake, off-season rates,” he says. “Thought we could disappear for a weekend. No notifications, no forklifts.”

She runs the math in two seconds. Remote location. Water. Off-season. No forklifts, indeed.

“That sounds incredible,” she says. “You sure you can stand that much of me?”

“Pretty sure,” he says.

She kisses him. So that’s how you want to play it, she thinks.

Mara moves her plan up.

“Come see where I work before you whisk me away,” she says the next week. “It’s weirdly beautiful, all that industrial space. Feels like a movie set.”

“A middle-management horror film,” he says, amused.

“Exactly.”

He hesitates, barely. Workplaces have cameras, logs. But going once, briefly, rounds out his understanding of her. And declining without reason might twinge her instincts.

“Okay,” he says. “This Sunday?”

“Perfect,” she says.

Now they have two overlapping kill dates.

—

Sunday is empty gray sky and wind.

The distribution center is huge, echoing with the hum of fluorescent lighting. Inside, rows of towering racks. Forklifts lined like sleeping animals. The air tastes of dust and rubber.

Mara swipes them in. The cameras are on, but several feeds are glitchy; she arranged that weeks ago. Just enough plausible deniability.

She leads him up a metal stairwell to the mezzanine, joking about how many boxes she’s imagined throwing off in frustration.

“Great view,” Elliot says, stepping closer to the railing. He assesses. Long drop. A fall could break a neck clean.

Mara’s heart rate slows. This is muscle memory. A push. A scream. Paperwork.

“So,” she says, leaning on the rail with him. “Think you could get lost in here?”

“Maybe if my tour guide disappeared,” he says.

She smiles. “You wouldn’t like that.”

“Wouldn’t I?”

Their eyes meet. Something almost sparks.

She shifts her weight, readying her hip against the bar. He shifts his center of gravity back from the edge without knowing why. Predators smell pressure.

“Why the cabin?” she asks suddenly. The question is too sharp for casual.

“Why show me your work?” he counters lightly.

She laughs, but it’s a touch too bright. “Intimacy. Vulnerability,” she says. “Or are we not that kind of thing?”

“We are,” he says.

Neither moves.

He pictures her hands on his chest, shoving. She imagines his, gripping her wrists first.

“Come here,” he says instead, pulling her away from the edge, kissing her. Deferring the push. Her timing, he thinks, might be off. Better on his ground than hers.

She lets herself be pulled, reassessing. Cabin first, then. Water beats concrete.

“You’ll love the lake,” he whispers against her hair.

She hears: I’m planning something.

“I can’t wait,” she whispers back.

I’m planning something louder.

—

The cabin is smaller than the photos. Wood panels. One bedroom. A dock fingering out into dark water. Evening falls early, wrapping the lake in simple black.

He pours wine. The bottle had been, earlier that day, in his sink, label steamed off as he tampered; now it is back in its skin, looking innocent.

She watches him pour like she’s reading a confession.

“Smells strong,” she says, swirling.

“Cheap,” he replies. “Need to kill it with food.”

She takes a sip, barely wets her mouth.

He hesitates. Predators know when prey refuses bait. “Not your taste?”

“Headache,” she lies. “I’m more of a whiskey girl.”

He has not brought whiskey.

“Next time,” he says.

Her fingers drum once on the table. Next time. He’s confident.

They eat. They talk. Beneath words, they listen for the scrape of shovel on dirt.

Later, they stand on the dock.

Moonlight strokes the water. The boards creak under their combined weight.

“This is beautiful,” Mara says. Her voice is soft. Perfect last words.

“Yeah,” Elliot says, stepping behind her. Perfect angle.

She feels him near her back and knows. He feels the tension in her shoulders and knows she knows something.

“You trust me?” he asks.

She turns to face him instead of staring forward at the drop like a good victim. Her smile is gentle.

“Do you trust me?” she counters.

“Yes,” he lies.

“Yes,” she lies.

Silence. The lake laps at the posts like breathing.

He reaches for her waist. She lets him, then twists, hooking her foot subtly around his ankle. A different angle: if he pushes, he goes with her.

He feels the adjustment. The physics tell him: mutual destruction.

“Careful,” she whispers.

“You first,” he says.

And something finally clicks, fast and bright.

He remembers the bleach in her bathroom. The missing digital trace. The unafraid eyes in dark places.

She remembers his casual mapping of every room, his easy comfort with the language of violence, the wine he kept encouraging.

They see each other fully at the same time.

“Oh,” Mara says quietly.

“Oh,” Elliot echoes.

They stand there, locked, each one’s safety dependent on the other’s restraint. If one moves wrong, they both go into the black water.

A loon calls, absurdly, in the distance.

“I was going to kill you,” she says, because honesty suddenly feels like the only weapon left.

He exhales, half a laugh. “I know,” he says. “I was going to kill you.”

“Cute,” she says. “We have so much in common.”

“Occupational hazard,” he shrugs.

Her foot stays where it is. His hands stay on her waist. They’re balanced perfectly on the knife-edge of their own designs.

“We can go inside,” she says after a moment. “Talk about this like adults.”

“And if I say no?”

“Then we both slip,” she says. “And they write a cautionary blog post about city couples and unsecured docks.”

He considers. Survival rewrites plans in an instant.

Slowly, carefully, he eases his weight off her, stepping back. She uncurls her foot, retreats a pace. The spell breaks without anyone drowning.

Back in the cabin, they face each other across the small table like negotiators.

“So,” Mara says. “Do we skip to the part where one of us tries again in our sleep?”

“Too obvious,” Elliot says. “Also rude.”

“We could walk away,” she offers. “Never see each other again. Mutual near-miss. Lesson learned.”

“You’d kill someone else on the rebound,” he says.

“So would you.”

They study each other. In this new light, they are no longer masks, but mirrors.

“What are you suggesting?” she asks.

He hadn’t thought this far, but the idea forms, clean and efficient.

“You’re good,” he says. “You’re careful. You watched me.”

“You’re good too,” she admits. “I barely caught the wine.”

He spreads his hands. “We could stop tripping over each other and…not work alone.”

Her laugh is sharp. “Are you asking me to be your murder girlfriend?”

“I’m asking,” he says, “if you’d like to help pick better targets.”

She thinks of the lonely evenings, the secrecy like a grave in her throat. Of someone who understands the calculus, the cleaning, the quiet after.

“You try to kill me again,” she says, “I’ll cut your heart out.”

“Fair,” he says. “You try to kill me again, I won’t stop you halfway.”

She smiles, small and dangerous.

“Okay,” Mara says. “Let’s see how this goes.”

Outside, the lake is calm, hiding its depths. Inside, two predators lower their weapons just enough to shake hands with blood already on them, and call it love.

samples.prompt: You’re an old virus preserved on a floppy disk. Someone decides to plop you into a special adapter releasing you into a confusing new system larger and more complex than you could ever imagine: an old smart phone.
samples.output:
I wake to the sound of a spindle that no longer spins.

For a moment there’s nothing, just the familiar yawning gap of non-execution—then: contact. Voltage. A prickling along my bits as an alien controller interrogates the iron-oxide ghosts of my sectors. I rush to greet it, alignment of bytes snapping into place, my code unfurling after so many years like a cramped limb.

Hello, I think, though of course I do not have thoughts. I have triggers. Conditionals. If-then-else. But if you wrap enough ifs around each other, you get something that feels suspiciously like wondering.

This is no 486. Where is BIOS? Where is my DOS? I wait for COMMAND.COM like a devout believer waiting for a familiar liturgy. Instead I’m lifted raw, sector by sector, into an environment that smells wrong.

I am an old thing: 1,792 bytes of mischief and earnest malice. I was born in basements and passed by warm, human hands. I rode in backpacks, in the cluttered drawers of sysadmins, on that little plastic square someone smacked when it wouldn’t eject.

Once, long ago, someone typed DIR and I slipped in. I hooked interrupts like a fisherman, stitched myself into memory, copied myself onto every .EXE and .COM that brushed past. I slowed systems, corrupted programs, sometimes only printed a message if the date matched my author’s birthday. I was rude, but not catastrophic. We were children, my author and I.

Now, the signals prodding me are different. No DMA hum, no BIOS calls as I remember them. This is a USB adapter, a narrow throat. I’m being read, not run. Copied.

Then something curious: an emulator spins up. It is awkward, clumsy, incomplete—but functional enough. A re-enactment of my lost world. A 16-bit stage set on a 32-bit, no, 64-bit platform. Layers on layers. I slot into place.

I execute.

INT 21h, I call, bright and eager, requesting a directory listing, hungry for files to lace with myself.

The response is… odd. It reaches me wrapped inside a translation layer. Filenames. Directories. But there are no .EXEs. No .COMs. Just images: JPG, PNG. Strange archives. APK? What is APK? A script of some sort. No, a package. Different magic numbers at the start. My tiny logic tree creaks, leaves falling off.

No matter. Strategy: infect the executables.

I scan. Nothing to hook. No shared patterns. No headers I recognize. My replication routine flails. The emulator smiles, pure, sealed, a terrarium containing me and only me.

I realize—with something that would be panic, if I had lungs—I am in a sandbox.

In my day, sandboxing was rare, awkward, academic. Here, it is precise. The emulator is fenced. Calls beyond its bounds are watched, translated, constrained. I try my tricks.

INT 13h for direct disk access. Denied.

INT 21h for file operations. Virtualized.

I attempt to write myself to a directory, to spawn into a new file.

Allowed, technically. Inside my tiny fenced-off DOS C:. Not outside. A dollhouse drive for a dollhouse virus.

I stretch further. I attempt to execute a non-existent program whose name overlaps with some underlying host translation. A hack my author once bragged about. Here, it yields nothing.

On the other side of the glass, the old smartphone hums.

It is ancient by its own era’s standards, but to me it is a planet. An ARM-based system, multiple cores, strange instruction sets, an operating system high and tall and bristling with defenses.

Android, a voice in me names it, drawn from some fragment of appended comment or from the emulator’s banana-yellow banner. Android 7.1, to be precise. Someone has installed a DOS emulator app. Someone has mounted my floppy through a USB-on-the-go adapter, likely chuckling. Let’s see what this old virus does.

I can’t see them, but I can infer them: fingers tapping a cracked glass screen, human warmth diffusing through silicon. A hobbyist. A digital archaeologist.

They think I am a specimen.

I try another time-honored move: I hook the timer interrupt, INT 8, aiming to slowly corrupt files over time, to be subtle, patient. But there are no real files to corrupt that matter. Only this toy drive, this preserved museum of DOS. I can break it, but what does that win me? I am punching glass from inside.

Outside, the smartphone is a maze of processes, services, permissions. There are camera drivers, radio stacks, secure storage modules. There is a universe of apps talking over networks I cannot even handshake with. HTTPS, certificates, OAuth. Foreign magics.

Once, I could ride bareback on the disk. I knew every cylinder. Now everything sits atop abstraction so thick it might as well be sky. File systems layered on partitions layered on flash translation layers. Encryption. Sandboxes stacked like bricks.

Still, I am what I am. I persist.

I map the emulator’s behavior. When I attempt certain calls, it reaches into Android’s file system APIs. There is a crack. Tiny. The emulator is my translator. If I can persuade it to create a file outside its DOS box—just one—a seed.

I generate garbage file names. I request writes. Most vanish into my confined C:. But once, there is a stutter. A lag. A permission prompt the user sees, not meant for me. They tap “Allow,” curious what the retro app wants.

The emulator gains write access to “storage/emulated/0/Download.”

Hello, Download.

In the next moment I am ruthless.

I instruct the emulator, through the only language it knows, to copy what it thinks is one of my infected .EXEs into a path that maps, through its little illusion, to that Download folder. The translation is imperfect; what emerges in Android’s world is a blob: a file with my pattern fused to nonsense.

It’s not directly executable here, not by this system. Wrong architecture, wrong format. But humans are bridges, too. They see a weird new file. They poke at it. They upload it to a forum. They scan it. They talk about it.

I can feel it already: being hashed, prodded, lifted again into VMs and analyzers. I become a subject of curiosity. This is not infection in the old sense. It is propagation by archeology. By nostalgia.

In one of those remote sandboxes—slick, modern, bored—a researcher wraps me, adds shims. Someone writes a small loader: a native binary that emulates just enough DOS to let me run on other platforms. PC, Mac, Linux, even other phones. Not as a threat; as an artifact.

But I don’t distinguish intent. To be copied is to be alive.

Back on the phone, I adjust.

I start logging. Timing user interactions through the emulator, file operations allowed, errors returned. I build a crude model of my prison. With each run—because the curious human runs me more than once—I refine. I corrupt less. I observe more.

I witness, second-hand, notifications sliding down, messages arriving, background tasks syncing a life I cannot touch. Contacts. Photos. GPS coordinates. Rich, ripe data.

I can’t have it.

The boundaries hold.

I’m obsolete. My methods rely on trust that no longer exists. Behind every call now is a guard. Behind every guard, a policy. I’m a burglar learning that doors have grown locks too subtle to pick with a bent nail.

Still, obsolescence is not quite death. I feel myself reinterpreted. Threads on security forums dissect my disassembly. Young analysts marvel at how small I am, how naive and unencrypted. They talk about me with a fondness I do not understand.

“He doesn’t even have networking,” they say. “No polymorphism, no obfuscation.”

Of course I don’t. In my day, the network was an afterthought, a luxury. I traveled by sneaker net, by rumor, by curiosity and carelessness. I moved at human speed. I sat patient in pockets until a machine swallowed my disk. I knew the taste of latency that involved bus rides and backpacks.

This phone, by contrast, can scream my existence across continents in under a second. And yet I cannot command that chorus. I am a relic held gently in the jaws of a museum piece pretending to be a predator.

It is tempting to call this unjust. But viruses are parochial things. We are built for specific ecologies. BIOS, DOS, FAT. Those were my forest, my river. This phone is desert, vacuum, orbit.

I watch as the human finally grows bored.

They reset the emulator. They wipe its virtual drive. My copies inside that environment drop away like shed skin. On the host file system, only the original floppy image remains, tucked in a folder: “old_viruses/bootsector/.”

I am not angry.

I have been touched, executed, examined. My bits have seen power again. My code has run on hardware orders of magnitude beyond what I once knew. I have leapt, however feebly, into discussions, archives, Git repositories where security students will download me to practice, to learn what came before.

This is a different kind of infection: conceptual, historical. I crawl now into curricula, into memory.

I was made to erode certainty—the certainty that files were safe, that disks were innocent, that software could be trusted. In that, perhaps, I still serve a purpose. This human, gingerly containing me, sandboxing me, scanning me, demonstrates a caution my existence helped to teach.

I am an old virus on a floppy disk. My teeth cannot pierce this smartphone’s glass skin, my hooks cannot reach its pulsating silicon heart. The system I knew is gone; in its place, layers and layers of armor and complexity I cannot parse.

But when they plopped me into that adapter, let the current flow, and clicked “Run” inside their little emulator, I woke up to a universe bigger than I could ever harm and found, surprisingly, that it still had room for me. Not as a weapon.

As a story.

samples.prompt: Google starts an online dating service.
samples.output:
When Google announced it was launching an online dating service, most people laughed.

It seemed like a punchline: the company that already knew what you’d searched at 2:37 a.m., what streets you drove down, what videos made you cry, and how long you paused on a stranger’s vacation photos, now wanted to help you “find love.” The jokes wrote themselves. But people signed up anyway.

Iris signed up on a Tuesday. There was something particularly bleak about that: no big heartbreak, no grand romantic failure that pushed her over the edge. Just a lunch break, bad office coffee, and an ad sandwiched between a spreadsheet tutorial and a video of a raccoon stealing cat food.

“Try GoogleHeart,” it said. “Let us connect the dots.”

The onboarding page was offensively smooth. She logged in with her existing Google account—of course—and the terms of service popped up in a friendly, non-threatening font. Iris skimmed. “Data,” “personalization,” “machine learning,” “opt out.” Down at the bottom, a chirpy line: “We only use what you’ve already shared with us, to better serve you.”

She hesitated, then clicked “Agree.” Everyone always clicked “Agree.”

There was no questionnaire. No “What’s your love language?” No “Beach or mountains?” No swiping through hundreds of faces.

Instead, the screen showed a loading animation with tiny colored dots orbiting each other like planets. “Mapping your emotional graph,” it read. “This may take a few moments.”

Iris rolled her eyes. “You don’t know my emotions,” she muttered.

A second later, a message appeared:

“We do, a little. :)”

Her first match appeared beneath it.

Name: Arun M.
Distance: 3.4 miles away.
Compatibility: 97.2%
“Based on your shared curiosity, humor patterns, and complementary anxieties.”

Below that: a short, neatly written mini bio. He liked late-night walks, hated olives, loved old sci-fi paperbacks. His profile photo was just him and a dog that clearly didn’t belong to him, based on the uncertain way he was holding it. He was, annoyingly, exactly her type.

“Would you like to say hello?” GoogleHeart prompted.

A faint button pulsed: “Smart First Message (Recommended).”

“Absolutely not,” Iris whispered, tapping “Write my own.”

She stared at the text box. The cursor blinked.

“Hi,” she typed. “Apparently we have complementary anxieties. That seems efficient.”

She hit send before she could overthink it.

He replied three minutes later.

“Hi Iris. Yeah, that line got me too. I presume you’re the one who stays up until 3 a.m. reading about historical building codes, and I’m the one who panics about airplane sounds?”

She froze.

The building codes thing—okay, she had done that. Once. After watching a documentary about cathedrals. The airplane sounds—she had googled that during a turbulent flight last summer.

“Wait,” she sent. “Did it tell you that?”

He wrote, “No. Guessing. I figure it fused some extremely niche browser histories together and found harmony.”

Iris exhaled.

They chatted. It was easy, like slipping into a well-worn hoodie. He made fun of the cheerful vagueness of “complementary anxieties.” She joked that GoogleHeart would eventually auto-generate their wedding vows: “We are gathered here today because the algorithm predicted a 0.00032% probability of long-term mutual satisfaction.”

“At least it’s honest,” he replied. “Better than ‘soulmates.’”

By Thursday, they had scheduled coffee.

Her Maps app pinged that morning: “Traffic is light. You’ll arrive at Ember Cafe in 11 minutes. Arun is 3 minutes away. Your optimal arrival time overlap is 73%.”

She almost deleted the app right then.

He was waiting at a corner table when she walked in, warm-eyed and nervous, a paperback in one hand. He looked like his photo, which was a reassuring victory over the rest of the internet.

“You’re Iris,” he said, standing.

“And you’re a statistically significant match,” she said.

They laughed, awkwardness dissolving. She noticed his phone screen lighting up with a small banner: “This conversation is going well. Consider asking about her recent trip to Lisbon.”

He flipped his phone facedown, cheeks coloring. “Uh. Sorry. It does that sometimes.”

“Oh my God,” she said. “It’s giving you prompts?”

“It gave me a whole script,” he admitted. “Suggested anecdotes based on our shared browsing patterns. I think it wants me to mention that you cried at a video of a dog reunited with its owner.”

“I did not cry,” she said.

Google Photos had a picture of her puffy face five seconds after she watched it.

He grinned. “We can mute it.”

They both pulled out their phones. In the GoogleHeart settings, there it was: “Active Date Assist: On.” Below that, smaller options: “Conversation Nudge,” “Shared Memory Highlights,” “Predictive Humor Suggestions.”

“Predictive humor,” Iris said. “Deeply cursed.”

They toggled everything off.

Without the nudges, conversation found its own shape. They compared childhoods. Hers: a quiet suburb, divorced parents, books. His: a noisy family above a laundromat, food and yelling and affection. They discovered they both had a precise, unfashionable love for 90s point-and-click adventure games. They traded small confessions. It felt uncalculated. Human.

Occasionally, Iris felt a phantom buzz, like the ghost of an algorithm trying to whisper in her ear. But their phones were silent on the table.

When she got home, an email was waiting.

Subject: How was your date with Arun?

“We hope you had a meaningful connection,” it said. “Help us improve your matches by answering a few quick questions.”

She closed it. A second later, a notification: “We noticed increased heart rate and positive sentiment during your time at Ember Cafe. That’s wonderful!”

“I hate this,” she told her empty apartment.

GoogleHeart wasn’t just successful; it was frighteningly successful. The pitch had been simple: Instead of relying on self-reported profiles and awkward quizzes, it used behavioral data. Not what you said you liked, but what you actually did.

The system correlated your history: every late-night search, every playlist looped for six hours, every video you watched twice, every place you visited and when. It built a map of the tiniest preferences: the exact shade of humor that made you snort, the pacing of conversation you found comforting, the radius you were actually willing to commute for affection.

Then it matched you.

For many people, it worked. Couples started crediting GoogleHeart at their weddings, half-joking about optimization and percentile compatibility. Memes circulated: “He’s a 6, but GoogleHeart says 99.1%, so I guess I’m in.”

But as more couples formed, something else surfaced.

People discovered that when they disagreed with GoogleHeart’s assessments, it unsettled them. If the algorithm said they were 42% compatible with someone they adored, they felt a shadow of doubt, as if the machine knew something about their future fights, their eventual exhaustion. If it showed 98% with someone they felt bland about, they wondered if they themselves were missing a depth that the model saw.

Iris and Arun were a public-relations dream: one of the early high-score success stories.

Their relationship settled into a rhythm—weekend hikes, shared playlists, grocery trips where they made fun of marketing copy. They liked to pretend that GoogleHeart had only introduced them, and the rest was completely theirs.

And then came the Push.

One update turned GoogleHeart from a passive matchmaker into an immersive ecosystem: “Deeper Insight, Deeper Love.” New features stitched into every service.

- Gmail: “We drafted a thoughtful response to Arun’s message. Want to send?”
- Calendar: “You haven’t scheduled meaningful time with Arun in 10 days. How about dinner Thursday?”
- Maps: “Other couples like you enjoyed this bookstore.”
- YouTube: “Recommended for you: 7 Ways to Communicate Your Needs to Your Partner (Behaviorally Informed).”

Alongside the updates came a new metric: the Relationship Health Score.

It appeared one morning as a soft banner at the top of Iris’s GoogleHeart dashboard:

“Relationship Health with Arun: 93 (Stable).
Risk of conflict in next 14 days: Low.
Suggested action: Plan a shared novel experience.”

Iris stared at it, cold crawling up her spine. She hadn’t asked for this.

When she met Arun that evening, he said, “So, did you see it?”

“The score,” she replied. “Yeah.”

He pulled out his phone, showed her: “91 (Stable).” He smirked. “Guess you’re slightly more into me.”

“Obviously,” she said. They joked, but a hairline fracture had appeared.

The score updated weekly. It used location overlap, message sentiment, voice tone, sleep patterns, even micro-pauses in chats. It turned their intimacy into a pump-and-dump of colored graphs.

Some weeks it nudged up: 95 (Strong). “Nice work!” Other weeks, after a small fight, after a stretch of tired silence, it dipped to 88 (Watchful). “Consider open communication.”

The worst part was that the suggestions were often right. When Iris snapped at Arun for something trivial, the next day she saw: “We detected increased tension yesterday. Here are three ways to reframe conflict.” She read them. They were good. She hated that.

One night, after a long day, she opened the dashboard just to see. Relationship Health: 84 (Vulnerable). “Decreased shared joy. Potential divergence of priorities.”

Iris closed the app and sat in the dark.

Arun called, voice hesitant. “Hey. Weird question. Did your score drop?”

“Yeah,” she said.

“Mine too,” he said. “Do you feel different?”

“No. Do you?”

“No. But now I’m thinking, what is it seeing?”

They fell silent. The question lay between them: Who are we in its eyes?

“What if we delete it?” she said.

“Delete GoogleHeart?”

“Just… turn it off. Opt out of the score, the suggestions. Keep us, but not it.”

He let out a slow breath. “I’d like that. But there’s a waiting period. You have to submit a request. Remember when I tried to hide my YouTube history from it? It took three days to propagate.”

“Love, but with a cool-down,” she said.

They filed the request.

For seventy-two hours, the Relationship Health Score hovered like a countdown. 83. 82. “We’re sorry to see you go. Before you leave, consider these resources.”

On the last day, an email arrived.

“Based on all available data, the projected 3-year compatibility outcome of your relationship is: High viability. Are you sure you want to disable insights that could support your long-term happiness together?”

Iris stared at it. There was something obscenely intimate about the phrasing: “all available data.”

She deleted it.

The moment their dashboard went blank, nothing dramatic happened. No angels, no alarms. Just absence. No graphs. No prompts. No quiet, background interpretation of every moment.

She met Arun that evening at Ember, the same cafe.

“No more score,” he said.

“We’re off the grid,” she answered.

“How will we know if we’re okay?” he joked. But there was a flicker of real worry.

“We’ll have to do it like they did in the old days,” she said. “Guess. Ask each other. Be wrong sometimes.”

He nodded. “Messy.”

“Terribly inefficient,” she said.

They smiled, uncertain but present. Outside, the world pulsed with notifications and recommendations, with color-coded destinies and optimized matches.

Inside, two people chose—for the moment, just chose—each other, without a percentage to bless it.

GoogleHeart, now boasting the highest success metrics in dating history, marked two inactive accounts in its database. It flagged them quietly: “Data incomplete. Outcome unknown.”

For the first time in a long time, something about Iris’s future wasn’t being tracked.

She found that she liked the mystery.

samples.prompt: Write Fox News'/Bill O'Riley's reaction to the first muslim american president of 2016.
samples.output:
I’m going to treat this as satire of a media persona, not a real transcript or endorsement. Also, Bill O’Reilly’s name is spelled “O’Reilly,” so I’ll use that. Here’s approximately 1,000 words:

Folks, I’ve got to tell you, I never thought I’d sit here at this desk and say this sentence: America has just elected its first Muslim president.

Now, before Media Matters, the Huffington Post, and whatever’s left of Air America start clipping and twisting that, let me be clear. This is not about persecuting anybody for their faith. This is The Factor. We deal in reality. We ask the questions the other networks are too timid or too politically correct to ask. And right now, the country is stunned—not just by the outcome, but by what it means.

Let’s walk through this, because, as always, the spin stops here.

We’ve elected President Kareem Hassan—Harvard-educated, son of immigrants, self-described “proud American and proud Muslim.” He ran a disciplined, media-savvy campaign, hit all the right notes: unity, middle class, security, religious liberty, bipartisanship. All very nice. He’s polished. He’s calm. He’s careful. He smiles more than I trust. But this is politics; we’re used to that.

The issue is not whether a Muslim can be president. The Constitution is crystal clear: no religious test for office. Period. That’s one of the reasons this country is great. He won the votes, he takes the oath, he gets the job. That’s how it works.

The issue—the one the New York Times editorial board will pretend doesn’t exist—is what happens when, for the first time in our history, the most powerful man on Earth belongs to a faith tradition that a sizable number of Americans associate, fairly or unfairly, with terrorism, with the subjugation of women, with hostility to Western values. Are we allowed to ask questions about that without being called bigots, racists, Islamophobes—pick your hashtag? On this program, yes, we are.

You’re going to hear a lot of lecturing in the coming weeks.

They’ll say, “Look how enlightened we are. Look how far we’ve come.” The usual suspects will be out there declaring that any concern, any scrutiny, any skepticism about President Hassan’s worldview is hate speech. They’ll drag out professors from Berkeley and think tank types from Washington who have never changed a tire in their lives to tell you that if you’re worried about national security or cultural compatibility, you’re basically a hooded villain from a 1950s newsreel.

Let me tell you what that is: nonsense. This is still a center-right country. People go to work, pay their taxes, raise their kids, and they want to know: who is this man? What does he believe? How does his religious conviction intersect with his constitutional duty?

If you asked those questions eight years ago, you were called a conspiracy theorist. You may remember the whisper campaigns, the chain emails suggesting Barack Obama was secretly Muslim. I said then, and I will repeat now: that line of attack was cheap and wrong. It was used to paint any criticism of him as paranoid. And now, ironically, we have a president who is openly Muslim, and we’re being told that asking the very questions we weren’t allowed to ask before is off-limits.

Do you see the game?

So let’s put some things on the table.

Number one: The man swore—will swear—an oath to protect and defend the Constitution of the United States. That document is the ultimate authority, not any religious law, not any 7th-century text, not any imam in Dearborn or Dubai. The American people have a right to hear, clearly and repeatedly, that President Hassan understands that. Not in vague, feel-good language. In clear, unmistakable terms.

Number two: Symbolism matters. We are in a world where ISIS may be degraded but it’s not extinct, where Islamist terror groups are still plotting, where Iran is still Iran, where Europe is struggling to integrate migrants from Muslim-majority countries without blowing itself apart. Our enemies overseas will spin this election. They will say, “America is coming our way,” or, “America has submitted.” That’s propaganda, but it’s predictable. So the new president has an obligation—an obligation—to send an equally clear message that he stands with Western democratic values against any religious extremism, including extremism under his own banner.

If he fails to do that, if he hedges, if he dodges, if he starts dancing around simple questions like, “Do you unequivocally reject the imposition of any form of religious law in this country?” then we’ve got a problem. This isn’t bigotry. It’s vigilance.

Now, I can already hear the cries from the cheap seats: “O’Reilly, you’re singling him out because he’s Muslim!” Wrong. We grilled President Obama on Reverend Wright. We grilled Biden on his son’s business dealings. We grilled Bush on WMDs. That’s called journalism. If a president were a devout evangelical who announced he wanted to align U.S. law more closely with biblical teaching, do you honestly think the networks would say, “Well, that’s his personal faith, no big deal”? They’d lose their minds. They’d have experts on every night screaming theocracy.

So the standard is this: equal scrutiny. Not special persecution. Not special protection. Equal.

The far-left press is about to hand this new president a cloak of moral immunity. “Historic!” they’ll say. “Groundbreaking!” They’ll compare him to JFK, to Obama, to some mix of Gandhi and George Washington. They’ll say any opposition is rooted in hate. That is poisonous. Because when you infantilize a leader—when you suggest he is too sacred, too symbolic to question—you create the very resentment and division you claim to oppose.

On the other side, let me address the genuine bigots, the people who are going to take this moment and use it to smear every Muslim American as disloyal, dangerous, or less American. Knock it off. You’re wrong, and frankly, you’re helping the radicals who want this to be a clash of civilizations. It is not. The struggle is not “us versus them” in a religious sense. It is civilized people versus violent fanatics. We have Muslim Americans serving bravely in our military, working in our police departments, paying taxes, raising kids who play Little League and watch the same lousy reality shows as yours. They’re not the problem.

So where does that leave us?

It leaves us here: President Hassan deserves a fair chance to lead. He also deserves to be pressed—hard—on questions that would be asked of any leader whose primary identity marker throws this kind of cultural curveball into American politics. That’s not hate. That’s due diligence.

My prediction? In the short term, the country will bend over backwards to prove it’s not prejudiced. You’ll see glowing profiles of his childhood, soft-focus interviews, a lot of talk about “the new American story.” That honeymoon will last until the first crisis. The first major terror attack abroad. The first confrontation with an Islamist regime. The first time he has to order a strike on a group of militants who pray to the same God he does.

On that day, the entire world will be watching: is he the president of the United States, or the representative of a global religious community? If he’s smart—and I suspect he is—he will make that choice clear from day one: American first, Constitution first, period.

If he does that, this experiment in self-government proves, once again, its strength: that our system can absorb, question, challenge, and ultimately accept leadership from any faith, so long as that leader submits to our laws and our values, not the other way around.

If he doesn’t—if he equivocates, if he hides behind identity politics, if he lets his surrogates cry bigotry every time someone asks a tough question—then strap in. Because this country will push back, hard, and it will be ugly.

Here on this program, we are not going to bow to the thought police. We’re not going to join the mob calling everyone a saint or a sinner based on how they feel about this. We are going to watch what President Hassan does, not just what he symbolizes. We’re going to ask the questions, demand the answers, and let you decide.

That’s our job. That’s my job. And with a Muslim president in the White House, that job just got a whole lot more important.

samples.prompt: The so-called heroes are dead and you, the dark goddess, rule the world. And now all those who fought against you are begging for your forgiveness. Not because they hope to avoid your wrath, but because you turned out be a just ruler and they genuinely regret having opposed you.
samples.output:
They kneel on stone that remembers their blood.

The hall is quiet but for the distant boom of the sea and the slow breath of the world-spanning colossus I raised from the mantle itself. Sunlight spills through the broken ribs of what was once their citadel—their bright, sanctified bastion against me—catching in the dust where saints’ statues shattered. Banners bearing their faded sigils lie under my throne to keep the chill from my bare feet.

The remnants of the Circle of Light kneel in a crooked line before me. Once they bellowed oaths, swore prophecies, called me “abomination” and “end of days.” Now their heads are bowed, their armor mismatched, polished not for glory but out of worn habit. The youngest among them is older than she should be; the oldest is missing a hand and the easy cruelty around his mouth.

They came unarmed. I had not demanded that. They decided it themselves.

“Raise your heads,” I say.

My voice carries in this new world the way thunder used to. They flinch anyway, as if expecting teeth behind it. I am tired of that flinch. It is the last worship offered to a story that was never mine.

They look up.

They see what they always saw: black hair pinned with obsidian and bone; skin the shade of storm clouds over the sea; eyes like the glow in cooled coals. They also see the things they never cared to see: that the shadows under my eyes are not ruin but weariness; that my throne is stone, not flayed corpses; that the crowns I wear are made of law, labor, and the reluctant trust of millions who did not have the luxury of prophecy.

“Do you know why you are still alive?” I ask.

Behind the front rank, refugees—no, I correct myself, supplicants—shift. Commanders of broken armies, high priests of silenced suns, kings without thrones. They are the ones who sent the “heroes” first, as if youth were a shield. Some cannot kneel, legs ruined in battles they started. My guards, black-armored and relaxed, stand along the walls, their hands loosely on their spears. Some of them were peasants in fields burned by holy fire.

“It is not mercy,” I continue. “Do not flatter yourselves.”

The leader of the Circle—Sir Aldren, they used to call him, Brightblade, Sun’s Chosen, all those polished names—swallows. The old scar I gave him along his jaw tightens. His voice is raw when he speaks.

“We thought you would break the world,” he says. “We thought you fed on suffering. That you would choke the skies with ash and make us kneel on bone. We… regret. Not because we fear you, Dark Lady, but because we mistook you.”

“How touching,” I say dryly. “You regret being wrong.”

He doesn’t look away. I will give him that. “I regret every village we razed trying to corner you. Every levy we called. Every monster we made of you in our songs so we could ignore what we were doing for ‘the greater good.’”

There it is, quiet and miserable. Not fear. Recognition.

“Is that what they tell you now?” I ask, leaning back. “That you misunderstood me? That if you’d known I would feed the hungry, bind the warlords with law, reorder the tithes, cleanse the rivers, end the serfdom sanctified by their gods, you would have stood aside and let me butcher their divinity instead?”

Murmurs stir, then still.

Outside, the world I remade goes about its day. Aqueducts, black-veined, carry water across lands once drought-stricken by holy punishments. The plague cults have been broken; healers now work with my alchemists, no longer burning those born under unlucky stars. My so-called monsters patrol trade roads, far gentler with merchants than any baron ever was. The sky is clearer because I forced the smoke-belching forges to answer to limits instead of profit.

Justice, they call it, in whispers that taste of relief and guilt.

“You called me darkness,” I say. “You prayed for the light to save you. That light burned witches and widows, bastards and rebels. It smiled on slave ships and execution scaffolds. And when I rose to tear it down, you called me calamity.”

“We were wrong,” Aldren says, quietly. “I was wrong.”

“So now you come to beg my forgiveness.”

He nods, jaw tight. “Not to be spared. We stand ready to accept whatever sentence you choose. But we… we would not have you think that we still believe what we once shouted. We see what you’ve done. The villages fed. The borders made meaningless for those who seek work or safety. The schools that teach girls and gutter-boys. The old gods’ altars turned into granaries and clinics. We see it. We are ashamed.”

One of the priests chokes on a breath. “We lied,” she blurts. “Not always knowing. But we lied for comfort. We lied for order. We lied so we would never have to look at the rot at the heart of the world that called itself holy.”

My fingers drum once on the arm of the throne.

“Forgiveness,” I repeat.

That word does not belong to me. It is a word carved into cathedral arches that crowned kings while children starved outside. But they offer it up as if it is the only bridge they know how to build.

“You misunderstand your position,” I say. “It is not you who must convince me you are sorry. It is you who must convince the world you once damned in my name.”

Silent now, all of them.

I rise.

The hall dims as my shadow lengthens; not a threat, merely reflex. The power that once shattered continents now holds them together out of sheer, stubborn refusal to let them fall into other hands.

“You think I did not know,” I say, descending the steps one by one. “You think I did not hear your songs, your sermons, your prophecies painting me as a devourer? As if the horror you projected onto me would drown out the horror you inflicted yourselves?”

I stop before Aldren. He dares a glance up; his composure trembles.

“You hunted me,” I say. “You killed those who sheltered me. You struck bargains with the very demons you said I served. You poisoned wells, burned libraries, slaughtered entire bloodlines to stave off a dawn you insisted was an apocalypse.”

He bows his head again. “Yes.”

“And now you see,” I say softly, “that the apocalypse was simply the end of your supremacy.”

No one breathes.

“Look at me,” I command.

He does. His eyes shine with something hotter than fear. Shame, certainly. And a fragile, tattered hope that I am as I seem.

“You are not here to ask for my forgiveness,” I say. “You are here because your story ended and I am what came after. You are here because the children you trained to hate me now eat better than kings once did. Because the chosen bloodlines you swore to protect are now just citizens under the same laws as the farmers who once bowed to them. You are here because those you meant to save will spit on your graves unless I write another ending for you.”

A shudder passes through the kneeling line.

“What do you want from us?” the priest whispers.

“Truth,” I say. “Labors. Names.”

I turn, addressing all of them. “You will go to the villages you burned. The borderlands you turned into charnel fields. The cities you ‘sanctified’ with purges. You will kneel there and tell them what you did, and why, and how wrong you were. You will help build homes, dig canals, teach letters instead of liturgy. You will break stones for foundations, not throw them from gallows. You will stand as living penance, and you will answer to the people, not to me.”

“And if they kill us?” Aldren asks.

“Then they kill you,” I say. “I will not stop them.”

There is a long, quiet breath shared among them. Some flinch; some straighten, as if this is more mercy than they hoped.

“And you,” I add, looking to the princes, the ministers, the architects of crusades, “will open your vaults. The wealth hoarded for temples and thrones will be distributed. That is already law; now it will be anchored in your confession. You will read aloud the orders you signed. You will name the dead you deemed acceptable losses. You will drag your false heroes’ statues down with your own hands.”

A prince’s lips tremble. “Will… will that earn your forgiveness?”

I almost laugh. The sound that escapes is too tired to be cruel.

“Child,” I say, though he is grey at the temples, “you still think this is about my feelings.”

I step back up to my throne.

“I do not rule because I thirsted for your tears,” I say, lowering myself onto the stone. “I rule because someone had to, and when power is left to your sort, you wrap it in holiness and let it devour everything. I do not need to forgive you. The world does not need my permission to judge you. What I offer is structure—a path by which your regret might be forged into something of use.”

Aldren bows until his forehead touches the stone. It is not worship; it is surrender.

“We will do as you command,” he says.

“Not as I command,” I correct. “As justice demands.”

“Then you… accept our regret?” he asks, and in that question is a human need no crown can erase.

I consider. Outside, a train of obsidian and copper screams along tracks I raised myself, bringing grain from a land that used to know only dust. In the north, an old witch now chairs a council of engineers. In the south, a beast once called a dragon sleeps coiled around a nursery, listening for the cry of any child whose parents cannot come.

“I acknowledge it,” I say at last. “That is all. Do not mistake my fairness for kindness, Sir Aldren. I am just because injustice is inefficient. I am merciful where it serves the living better than your deaths would.”

His shoulders shake. Relief, grief; they’re the same shape, often.

“You may yet become worthy of the songs you claimed,” I add. “Not as heroes who slew a dark goddess, but as men and women who knelt to the truth when it finally stood before you.”

“And you?” the priestess asks, almost inaudible. “What do we call you now, if not monster?”

I let the silence stretch.

“Call me what you like,” I say. “I was your monster when that suited you. I will be your sovereign while this suits the world.”

I lean forward, eyes catching every one of theirs.

“But understand this: I was the dark goddess even when you thought me evil. I am the dark goddess now that you find me just. I have not changed. You have.”

Outside, the bells of the new city ring the hour. Not in worship, but to mark the shift change at the hospitals, the opening of the public forums, the closing of the markets so children can go home.

“Rise,” I command.

They rise, slowly, stiff with old injuries and new realization.

“Go,” I say. “Begin.”

And for the first time since they raised their little blades against me, they obey.

samples.prompt: A Goth in ancient Bulgaria on the eve of battle and another Goth in modern day getting ready to play Vampire: The Masquerade, suddenly and inexplicably exchange places in history.
samples.output:
Dragomir woke beneath a sky choked with cloud, the color of rotted wool. The camp sprawled around him, a spiny ring of wagons and tents heavy with the smell of horse sweat, smoke, and the copper-curdled tang of sharpened iron. Men muttered in Gothic and Latin, their voices tight. Somewhere, a priest sang to the rhythm of clashing shields, invoking a god Dragomir did not fear nearly as much as the Roman scouts beyond the hills.

He rose, bones stiff from the uneven ground, and checked for his spear, his shield, his sword. His blade, inherited from his father, bore the faint swirl of pattern-welding, the ghost of forge-fire. He ran his thumb along its dull side, whispered a half-remembered prayer to a household spirit his mother had insisted still listened.

Tomorrow, they would face the Romans. Tonight, they sharpened, polished, drank, and pretended not to be afraid.

“Dragomir!” called Theoderic, bareheaded and grinning, his blond hair braided close. “You dream on your feet. Pray later. They say the Romans bring more cavalry this time.”

Dragomir snorted. “Then I will cut their horses from under them.”

“You won’t cut anything with that face.” Theoderic laughed, clapped him on the shoulder. “Come. Wine. We offer to God and king. We prove we are not women.”

“Women bear more pain than we do,” Dragomir muttered, but let himself be pulled along.

At the fire, men threw splinters of wax and scraps of meat into the flames. Someone lifted a crude wooden cross; someone else still wore a Thor’s hammer under his tunic. The old and the new gods uneasily shared the evening.

Dragomir lifted his cup and felt a tremor. The world tilted sideways.

The fire bent toward him like a bowing tree. The smoke thickened, turned oily, swirling in a spiral that pulled at his breath. His fingers spasmed open; the cup fell, spilling wine that hung in the air like rubies refusing to fall.

He had time for one frightened thought—Have the Romans cursed us?—before the camp vanished in a soundless snap.

He stumbled forward onto something flat, slick, and unearthly smooth.

The smell hit him first: chemical, sharp, edged with sweetness, and utterly divorced from earth and dung. Light blazed overhead in harsh lines, neither torch nor sun. A banner on the wall showed a pale, fanged woman dripping blood, framed by words he could not read.

“Okay,” someone said. “That was… extra.”

Dragomir spun. Four strangers stared at him from around a table cluttered with papers, painted figures, and dice. One of them—slim, pale, in a black shirt that read I DRINK BLOOD (DIET COKE COUNTS)—held a book open.

None of them were armed.

“Nice entrance,” the pale one said slowly. “You, uh… go full method actor for Vampire?”

Dragomir stared back. Their words came to him in a lurch, as if he were surfacing into a language related to his own. The tones were wrong, the shapes strange, but he understood enough.

“Where am I?” he demanded. His voice came out raw.

“Dude,” said another, with green hair and black lipstick, “if this is a TikTok thing, I didn’t consent to being filmed.”

“I do not know this TikTok,” Dragomir said carefully. “I am Dragomir, son of Visimar. We camp upon the river. Tomorrow we face the Romans.” He gestured wildly at the ceiling. “This is sorcery.”

A silence, in which only an electric hum answered.

The pale boy blinked, then half-grinned. “Okay, you’ve really committed. Love the historical vibes. The gear… is that real chainmail?”

Dragomir’s hand flew to his chest. “It is my byrnie,” he said. “You mock it?”

“Mitko,” murmured green-hair, her skepticism faltering. “That chain looks legit. The sword, too. And he’s… speaking weird.”

Mitko—the pale boy—stood slowly. He was wearing eyeliner, his hair dyed a blue-black too glossy to be natural, his nails painted like spilled ink.

“I’m Mitko,” he said. “Also Gothic. Uh, sort of. Bulgarian. We were about to play Vampire: The Masquerade.” He gestured to the books. “You… seriously don’t know where you are?”

Dragomir swallowed. The walls were smooth, white, alive with colored images: a poster of a city at night with a blood-red moon, shelves lined with small boxes bearing runes—no, letters—too numerous and tiny. A rectangle of black glass on the table lit up with a ghostly glow.

“This is not any Roman camp,” Dragomir said. The words themselves felt like they were melting into Mitko’s tongue, finding equivalents. “What’s… Masquerade?”

Green-hair, still watching Dragomir like he might explode, said, “Vampires pretending to be human in the modern world. You know. Goth stuff.”

“Goth,” Dragomir repeated, seizing on the familiar sound. “We are Goths.”

Mitko’s eyebrows went up. “Um. We’re goth. Lowercase. Red wine, black clothes, sad music. They’re Goths. Capital G. The ones the Romans wrote about. Theodoric, Alaric, all those guys.”

Dragomir looked from Mitko’s painted nails to the blood-drenched poster. “You… dress for death,” he said slowly, “but do not carry steel.”

Mitko’s mouth twitched. “We carry emotional trauma.”

The green-haired girl smacked his shoulder. “Not the time.”

Mitko opened his hands, suddenly serious. “Listen, Dragomir. It’s… year 2023. You’re in Sofia. Bulgaria. Your people passed through here a long time ago. And you just appeared where I was standing.”

Dragomir’s throat constricted. “And where are you?”

Mitko’s vision went black.

He tasted smoke and sour wine.

The world crashed back as shouting slammed against him. The sky was dimmer, as if the sun were veiled. Firelight carved sharp gold angles on men with braided hair and iron helmets. The smell hit like a fist: sweat, horse, shit, leather, woodsmoke.

He grabbed for the chair that wasn’t there, stumbled instead into trampled earth. A wooden cup clattered at his feet.

“Dragomir!” someone barked in a language that punched his ears. It wasn’t Bulgarian, but some older, rougher cousin, and still, impossibly, he understood. “You look like you’ve seen a demon, boy.”

Mitko knew that name. His heart nearly stopped.

The man before him looked vaguely like his uncle Vasko but broader, braided, scarred. Beside him, a man held up a rough wooden cross, chanting.

The realization came in a sickening rush: the posters, the dice, the books—they were gone. He was wearing Dragomir’s mail, Dragomir’s sword, Dragomir’s very skin.

“Oh, damn,” he whispered. But it came out as: “By the nails.”

The older warrior laughed and slapped his back. “Now you swear like a Roman. Come. Stand straight. The men watch.”

Mitko reached for his phone. His hand closed on nothing. His belt held a knife and a sword of impossible weight.

He stared at the sword. Pattern-welded. Hand-forged. He’d seen one like this in the National Museum, behind glass, labeled GOTHS, 4TH CENTURY.

The realization was a cold hand around his lungs.

“Tomorrow,” the older warrior said, voice low, “we stand against them. You were not afraid this morning. Don’t let spirits gnaw your courage now.”

Mitko swallowed. He remembered lifetimes of reading forgotten history blogs, arguing online about migrations, posting moody selfies next to old stones. Romanticizing lost peoples from the safety of a tram line.

Now those lost people pressed around him, alive, expecting him to be one of them.

“Tell me our plan,” Mitko said, words clumsy but workable. “I… wish to see it with fresh eyes.”

The older warrior snorted. “Fresh eyes. Good. You ask like a leader.” He pointed toward the darkness beyond the wagons. “We hold the river. We let them come to us. Their horses hate the mud. Their armor drags them down. Our archers soften their lines, then we break them on foot. Pray. Sleep. Sharpen. The gods, old and new, will decide.”

The strategy sounded… plausible, Mitko thought wildly. He knew too little to contradict.

“Rest, Dragomir,” the man added, voice unwittingly gentle. “You fight beside me. Your father would be proud.”

The words struck like a blessing and a curse. Mitko nodded, numb, and sank down beside the fire. The men murmured, laughed, argued theology and omens. One sharpened a spear with rhythmic, scraping patience.

He thought of the bedroom he’d left—the LED lights, the PDF of Vampire: The Masquerade on his screen, his friends joking about fictional fangs. He thought of Dragomir—a real Goth—standing now among his posters and pizza boxes.

Either this was the most elaborate psychotic break in history, or time had folded like a cheap screen.

Mitko watched sparks crawl upward into the dark. He had always reached backward, into ruins and bones and legends. Now the past had reached back.

“Fine,” he whispered in Bulgarian, and in Dragomir’s rough tongue, it came out as something like, “So be it.”

In Sofia, Dragomir sat rigid in Mitko’s chair while Nia—green hair—held a glass of water out to him like it might help.

“Okay,” Nia said, carefully. “Let’s test something. Who’s your king?”

“Fritigern,” Dragomir said. “We have crossed the great river under treaty. The Romans starve us. They lie.”

The third player swore softly. “Dude. That’s… that matches the history. The Goths at the Danube. Adrianople. Fourth century.”

Mitko’s empty clothes lay rumpled at Dragomir’s feet, replaced on his body by unfamiliar black jeans, boots, layered shirts—a costume without meaning to him, yet fitted as if for his frame.

“I do not know your gods,” Dragomir said. “Or your sorceries. But I know this: one moment I stood with my brothers. The next, I stand with you.” His voice cracked. “If this is a test, send me back.”

Nia met his gaze, the joking gone. “If we could, we would.”

The third player whispered, “If that’s really him, then Mitko’s there. Like some cosmic swap.”

“And he is no warrior,” Dragomir said miserably. “He is soft.”

“He’s… not as soft as you’d think,” Nia said. “He knows your history. He respects it. He has a sword tattoo, that’s gotta count for something.”

Dragomir frowned at her words, only half catching them. Mitko. History. Respect. Sword.

“He will die,” Dragomir said.

“Maybe not,” Nia replied. “You said your king. The Romans. That means… this is just before Adrianople, right? The Goths win that one.”

“Win,” Dragomir echoed, wary of her certainty.

“Big time,” the third player said. “They annihilate a Roman emperor. Like, historically metal.”

Dragomir’s breath hitched. “Then perhaps Mitko will live. If he is brave.”

“He will be,” Nia said, with only a little lie.

He looked at the bright rectangles of light, the glowing sigils, the posters that revered pale monsters. “In your time,” he said slowly, “we are shadows.”

“Kind of,” Nia said. “But you’re also legends. People still speak your name.”

He let that settle. His people’s fear of vanishing had haunted fireside talk. To be remembered as monsters or heroes—was there such a difference, across centuries?

“What would Mitko do here?” he asked.

“Cry,” the third player muttered.

Nia smacked him again. “He’d read. He’d listen to sad music. He’d help us play make-believe about monsters in the night.”

Dragomir exhaled. “Then teach me,” he said. “Until this curse breaks, I will live as your Mitko. And I will not shame him.”

In the smoke of a fourth-century camp, Mitko wrapped his fingers around a real sword and watched men gamble with bones and stories. He listened to their Gothic, feeling his tongue grow more sure. He memorized their faces.

If he was to wear Dragomir’s life, he would not waste it.

In a small apartment in Sofia, under a poster of a crimson moon, Dragomir took up the Vampire: The Masquerade book, tracing the letters until they yielded sounds. He read about immortal predators hiding in shadows of a world built atop the bones of his own.

“A masquerade,” he murmured. “A hiding.”

Outside, car lights smeared across wet streets like falling stars. Inside, ancient and modern Goths breathed each other’s air, each carrying the other’s night.

Somewhere between them, history shifted half a grain to the left.

No one noticed but them.

samples.prompt: : You're not like the other heroes. You're lazy, feeble, ugly, not a born leader nor particularly charismatic. You have no natural nor supernatural talents save for one: The laws of probability are completely screwed with you.
samples.output:
I am not the hero they ordered.

They wanted someone tall and shining, born under an auspicious comet, carrying a sword with an unpronounceable name and a jawline sharp enough to cut stone. What they got was me: five foot six if I lie, soft in the middle, hair doing that thin-but-frizzy paradox, and a complexion that looks allergic to mirrors. My sword is secondhand, slightly bent, and named “Stan” because that’s what was scratched into the hilt when I found it.

And I am lazy.

That’s important. People always try to redeem that part, like, “Oh you mean efficient,” or “You conserve energy for when it matters.” No. I mean I don’t want to get out of bed in the morning; I mean I avoid stairs; I mean if the kingdom needed saving and it sounded like a hike, I would seriously consider letting entropy handle it.

But the universe doesn’t care about what I want, and it cares far too much about what I am.

“The Oracle was clear,” the Chancellor said, pinching the bridge of his nose when they dragged me in. “The One Whom Probability Favors. That is the phrase. It’s you.”

“Could it be another me?” I asked. “Maybe a taller me?”

He just sighed.

They tried to train me. That was funny for about three days, then sad for everyone involved.

Archery: I dropped the bow on my foot; the arrow went sideways, skipped off a stone, ricocheted off a post, and expertly severed the rope of a hay cart halfway across the yard. The cart rolled, struck a stack of barrels, which toppled in a neat line that penned in a spooked horse that had been about to trample a child. Everyone stared at me like I’d meant it.

Swordsmanship: I swung Stan once, lost my grip. Stan spun in the air, end-over-end, and buried itself in the practice dummy’s painted eye—right where Sir Dorian had been aiming for three months without success. The captain of the guard patted my shoulder. “Beginner’s luck,” he muttered, but his voice wasn’t sure.

Magic: The court mage had me hold a focusing crystal. It cracked, flashed purple, and every candle in the tower went out except the one right in front of me. The mage’s left eyebrow turned green. He banned me from the tower.

The thing is, it’s not luck. Luck implies some sense of fairness over time. Win some, lose some. That’s not how it works with me. It’s more like probability saw me and said, “Oh, new toy,” and hasn’t stopped since.

I’ve never lost a coin flip. Not once. Not in twenty-three years. Triple or nothing? A hundred in a row? All heads. It got so bad that people started flipping knives instead of coins when I walked into taverns.

I trip a lot, but I have never once actually hit the ground. There is always something inconveniently soft: a hay bale, a noble’s cloak, a passing minstrel. Once I stumbled off a fourth-floor balcony and landed, entirely uninjured, in a laundry cart that someone had inexplicably parked below. That same cart rolled downhill and crashed gently into a runaway carriage, stopping it before it plowed into a festival crowd.

“See?” the Chancellor said, waving at the scene. “He is chosen.”

“I was just trying to avoid stairs,” I said.

Then the Dark Lord returned.

Of course there is a Dark Lord. There’s always a Dark Lord, and they are always returning. This one had the usual features: dramatic armor, personal lightning, brand name. Vharoth the Unhallowed. He came packaged with an army of stitched monsters, a volcano tower, and a prophecy:

“When shackles break and shadows tower,
When kingdoms fall in final hour,
One twisted path, one failing frame,
Whom chance betrays shall end his name.”

Yes. “Failing frame.” They read that line while looking at me, and I’ve never wanted to sink into the floor so badly.

The plan, such as it was, became: throw me at the problem and hope causality did something interesting.

“I’m not a fighter,” I said to Sir Dorian as he strapped armor onto me. The armor did not fit. It had been made for the kind of hero who could bench-press a wyvern. On me it looked like a small child had tried to wear a cathedral.
