“You are fate-touched,” Dorian said, ignoring that the shoulder plate slid straight off and clanged on the floor. “We will keep you safe until your… anomaly can be deployed.”

“‘Deployed,’” I repeated hollowly. “Like a catapult.”

That actually gave them ideas.

We went to war.

This is the part where heroes usually grow. They harden, sharpen, rise to the occasion. I sweated, complained, and spent most of the march hoping Vharoth would get bored and go home.

The first battle was at the Sable Ford, a narrow crossing choked with fog. Vharoth’s beasts came screaming out of the mist, all claws and stitched faces. I was at the back, trying to look inconspicuous behind a barrel.

Then someone shouted, “Protect the Chosen!” which is exactly the opposite of inconspicuous.

An arrow—black, hissing—shot straight toward my head. I flinched, tangled my foot in a rope, and fell sideways. The arrow missed me, clipped our standard, and severed the flag from its pole. The silk banner dropped over the leading monster’s face. Blinded, it stumbled, knocked three others off the bank and into the river, and in their flailing they tore down the rope bridge the enemy was using. Half of Vharoth’s vanguard splashed into the churning water.

Our soldiers roared and charged. We won.

“Brilliant maneuver,” Sir Dorian said afterward.

“I tripped,” I said.

“That’s your genius,” he replied, utterly serious.

It went on like that.

At Blackmere, they pushed me forward to “inspire” the troops. I stepped up on a crate, the crate broke, I went down like a sack of potatoes, and my flailing hand yanked down a loose signal flare. The flare fired sideways, arced over the lake, and landed directly in Vharoth’s siege-scorpion ammunition cache. The resulting explosion took out half his artillery.

At Highfall Pass, a boulder trap meant for us broke early under my tentative poke, triggered the avalanche ten minutes ahead of schedule, and buried the ambush party that had just started creeping up on our flank. I’d been checking if the rock looked “stable.” It did not.

The soldiers started calling me Lucky. Not respectfully, not at first. Then they watched the casualty numbers stay improbably low whenever I was near, watched enemy blades slip on mud that hadn’t been there a second before, watched crossbow strings snap, watched a charging ogre KO itself tripping on my discarded lunch wrapper.

Respect came slowly, edged with unease.

See, the flip side is: probability doesn’t just favor me. It bends around me. For me to consistently survive the worst possible odds, something else has to give.

There were little signs.

The farmer whose haystack broke my fall sprained his wrist the next day on a loose rung.

The laundress whose cart saved me lost all her linens in a freak gust that blew them into the river.

In Blackmere, the explosion that saved us also blew apart a fishermen’s hut on the far bank. Nobody had any reason to think the two were connected. I did.

I started trying very hard not to use it. You try explaining that to generals.

Which is how I ended up trudging alone up the obsidian slope of Mount Dreadspire, to face Vharoth with no army at my back—because every tactician, priest, oracle, and part-time soothsayer agreed on two things:

- Only I had any measurable chance of getting close enough.
- Nobody wanted to stand too close when I did.

The sky was red, volcano-style. Vharoth’s tower clawed at the clouds. Lightning did the tasteful looming thing.

He waited for me in the throne room, naturally: skulls, firepit, curtain of black flame; he’d really committed to the bit. He was tall, angular, with eyes like old embers.

“You are the one,” he said, sounding disappointed. “The stumbling fool the threads knot around.”

“I get that a lot,” I said.

He studied me. “Your existence is an insult to order. Do you know what you cost the world every time you breathe? The ship that sinks so you drift ashore on a barrel. The healer who slips so your fever breaks. The child in the wrong place so your arrow finds the right gap.”

I swallowed. “I never shot any arrows.”

“Not the point,” he snapped. “Every miracle has a ledger. And yours runs deep.”

He gestured, and a jagged lance of shadow screamed toward me.

I sneezed.

A brick loosened from the arch above. It fell, hit the shadow-lance at just the right angle to scatter its force into harmless sparks, then bounced off my helmet with a dull “tonk.” It hurt.

Vharoth stared.

“I hate you,” he said with quiet intensity.

“Get in line,” I answered, rubbing my head.

He came down from the dais, cloak billowing exactly like stage smoke. “I have calculated a thousand outcomes of this meeting,” he said. “In 997 I kill you. In three, you… slip away.”

“Those odds,” I said, “have historically not worked out.”

We fought, if you could call it that. He unleashed disciplined, devastating magic; I dodged by being clumsy at exactly the right times. I tripped on his carpet; the fall saved me from a decapitation wave. I flung Stan at him in a panic; I missed by a room, but Stan hit a chain that dropped a chandelier that disrupted a summoning circle that he had forgotten was drawn under his own throne (“For ambiance,” he snarled), which sucked half his power into an uncooperative pocket dimension.

It should have been epic. It was deeply stupid.

Finally he grabbed me by the throat, lifting me up. Up close, his eyes were tired—eternally, cosmically tired.

“You don’t understand,” Vharoth hissed. “I am not chaos. I am correction. You’re the aberration. Remove you, and the scales balance. No more unearned fortune. No more senseless tragedy to pay for it.”

For a moment, hanging there, I imagined it: a world where my existence wasn’t tilting dice, knocking ladders, breaking ships. Just straight odds. People keeping what they earned, losing only what they risked.

It sounded beautiful.

He tightened his grip. Black flame crawled up his arm.

Then the floor stone under his left foot, worn infinitesimally thinner than the others by centuries of pacing, chose that exact instant to crack. His ankle twisted. His spell jerked sideways. The death-bolt that should have liquefied my heart hit the ceiling instead.

The tower shuddered.

I dropped to my knees; he staggered. Above us, in the intricate vaulted stonework, a load-bearing gargoyle (tastefully carved) loosened.

He looked up.

“Oh, come on,” he whispered.

The gargoyle fell.

Probability loved it.

The impact went through him, through the dais, through the tower’s heart. The wards that kept the volcano leashed sputtered and died with a pathetic “ptink.”

This was bad.

Outside, the mountain growled.

Vharoth lay pinned, coughing ash. With the last of his strength, he laughed. “You see? Even now. The world will break to keep you breathing.”

I could run. I should run. That’s my nature.

Instead, I limped to him, braced my shoulder against the gargoyle, and pushed. My arms shook. I am not strong; I am not heroic. The stone barely shifted.

“I kill you,” he rasped, “the ledger closes. The lava stops. The fault line sleeps. Let me fix it.”

His hand, skeletal and burning, reached toward my chest.

For once, I didn’t dodge.

“I am so,” I said through my teeth, “tired of being an accident.”

His fingers brushed my ribs.

And probability—my rotten, skewed, insistent probability—had a choice.

A stray stone rolled under my right foot. My weight shifted involuntarily, just enough to slip his reach. His hand sank into the floor instead.

Fissures of unmaking raced outward, finding the lines of his own magic, turning back on him. Vharoth’s body unraveled, threads of darkness snapping one by one.

He was right. The world broke to keep me breathing.

The mountain didn’t erupt fully, in the end. It coughed—fiery boulders arced harmlessly into uninhabited valleys, the lava diverted by a rockslide triggered by, they said later, a goat tripping at just the right time.

I walked out of the collapsing tower untouched except for a bruise and a ringing in my ears, while a thousand improbable coincidences aligned to spare the kingdom from absolute ruin. Not all ruin—villages still smoked, lives were still lost—but less. So much less than his power promised.

They call me a hero now.

They throw feasts in my honor; bards compose songs that generously omit all the tripping. People ask for my blessing, as if standing near me will make their harvests richer, their dice kinder, their children safer.

I tell them no.

I spend my days in a small house at the edge of the capital, away from fragile scaffolding and crowded markets. The King sends messengers with “opportunities.” I decline. I plant beans; they grow in baffling abundance. I give most of them away and try not to think about what blight fell on some other field to even it out.

Sometimes, alone at night, I flip a coin and pray that, just once, it will land wrong.

It never does.

samples.prompt: Death had always wondered if it were possible, but today confirms it. On his daily list of harvests was a single name: God.
samples.output:
Death had always wondered if it were possible, but today confirms it.

On his daily list of harvests—inkless, ageless, etched in a script that was less written than implied—stood a single name.

God.

The letters did not behave.

They did not sit obediently in the line, stacked with mortal syllables and mortal mistakes. They bled through, up and down, widening, fracturing the parchment of reality like roots cracking stone. They were every name that had ever been given: YHWH, Allah, Brahman, The Architect, The Mother, The Nothing, The One. They overlapped, shimmered, disagreed with each other, and yet pointed, with unbearable unanimity, at one Being.

Death stared.

For an aeon-length second—he measured in collapses of galaxies, in the cooling of neutron stars—nothing else in creation died. The list was always updated; it was his metronome, his only correspondence. Lives appeared, lives concluded, he arrived. Today, the flowing script halted after that single word, as if the quill itself refused to continue while that appointment remained unresolved.

He had suspected.

Once, during a local heat-death in a small, unremarkable universe bubble, he had noticed the texture of his mandate loosen, threads fraying at the edge of time. He had considered, as much as he ever allowed himself to consider, whether the end of all might include the end of the Beginner. But speculation was not his function.

This, however, was not speculation.

“Is this… a mistake?” he asked no one, which was to say, he asked the List. It did not answer. It never did. Its silence was its confirmation.

He tried to refuse. The thought itself was a crack of rebellion that startled him, like finding a heartbeat in his own hollow chest. Death does not disobey; Death does not agree; Death simply is. And yet, with that single impossible name staining his entire awareness, he found something foreign blooming at his core.

Reluctance.

He knew what came of refusing a name. Some of the lesser collectors had tried, once, during a particularly florid plague when the taste of suffering had become too bitter even for them. They had unraveled instantly, their duties reassigned to more obedient emptinesses. Death was not lesser. He was the first division. But he was not exempt from structure.

Duty is not a contract; it is a fact.

He appeared—or rather, he un-happened into a place that was not a place. The Throne Room, humans had called it. The Lotus of Realms, others said. The Heart of the Sky. On approach, it resembled all those and none of them: a void whose emptiness was so total it curved into fullness, lined with every possible symbol of divinity flickering in and out of congruence, as if creation were remembering and revising its own mythology from moment to moment.

At the center, God sat.

Or stood.

Or was.

The Being’s presence was gentle and unbearable, like facing the original definition of “light” with pupils made for shadows.

Death had never before needed to introduce himself, but here, form asserted itself. He coalesced into his most familiar aspect: a tall figure, neither skeleton nor man, robed in something that drank light, with eyes like the underside of galaxies.

“Lord,” Death said.

The word felt correct. Not servile, just accurate. An acknowledgment: You preceded my function.

“Child,” God replied.

The voice contained oceans, forest fires, cricket chirps, radio static, sobbing, and laughter so profound it bordered on cruelty. It also contained, disconcertingly, warmth.

Death hesitated. “Your name is on my list.”

“I know,” God said. “Sit, if you like.”

“I do not sit.”

“You may today.”

And in that not-place appeared a chair that was not a chair, shaped precisely to fit a being who had never needed rest. It looked wrong. It looked inviting. Death remained standing.

“Is it possible?” Death asked. “For You?”

God tilted something like a head, something like an axis. “You’ve harvested stars that believed themselves eternal. Principles that thought themselves unassailable. Even the law of entropy, in one ambitious iteration. Why not Me?”

“Because You authored the list.”

“Did I?” There was amusement there, and something sad. “Long ago, yes. But I delegated. You think I micromanage quarks?”

Death did not answer. This was blasphemy, which was also theology, which was simply data.

“I assumed,” Death said, “that I was beneath You. An instrument. A subordinate aspect of Your will.”

“You were,” God said. “For a long while. Then you became…what all things become, given enough responsibility and consistency.”

“Independent,” Death supplied.

“Real,” God corrected.

The List pulsed in Death’s unseen hand. The Name grew impatient. Or perhaps that was Death’s projection. He found himself measuring this moment against every other. Souls meeting him with fear, with resignation, with gratitude. Gods of pantheons stepping down, their relevance exhausted. Concepts that died when belief did. But this was the Source.

“If I refuse,” Death asked, testing the borders of his existence, “what happens?”

God smiled, and in that smile Death read collapsing supernovae and the first cell dividing in lukewarm seas. “You wouldn’t be here asking that, if refusal were a true option.”

“So it is obedience,” Death said, with a bitterness that surprised even him.

“It is completion,” God said. “For both of us.”

The idea struck him as sacrilegious: Death, completing God.

“You can’t die,” Death said. “You are Being itself.”

“Being is tired,” God replied.

The not-place vibrated slightly; somewhere, a distant galaxy altered its spin fractionally in sympathy. Death steadied himself.

“Tired,” Death repeated. He had seen tired. Tired was a soldier who had forgotten why the war had started. Tired was an old woman whose children all lay beneath stone. Tired was a prayer whispered not in hope but in habit.

“Tired,” God confirmed. “Of petitions. Of interventions misconstrued as neglect and neglect misread as freedom. Of worship that cages, blasphemy that inadvertently flatters. Of holding together every possible timeline for every possible choice because, once given, free will is so impolite about consequences.” There was no anger, only explanation. “I have loved it all. I am very full of love. That, too, is exhausting in eternity. I built you for this, though I did not know it, then.”

Death almost laughed. “You built me to end You?”

“I built you to ensure endings,” God said. “Anything that begins without an end is a prison. I refused to build a prison. Not for you. Not for Me.”

A silence unfolded, rich and almost kind.

Death remembered—though “remembered” was a metaphor for perfect knowledge—the first emergence of complexity from chaos, the first awareness, the first fear of its own cessation. He had been there, as constant as the constants. He had harvested the last dinosaur, the first prophet, the last machine consciousness of the silicon exodus. He had never hesitated. He had never felt like this.

“You’re afraid,” God observed.

Death’s hollows narrowed. “I do not—”

“Not for yourself,” God said. “For what comes after I’m gone. For whether your list exists without Me. For whether you are, in truth, anything but My shadow.”

The List trembled.

“If I take You,” Death said slowly, “does everything end?”

“No,” God said. “Or not exactly. I am not a light switch, I am a seed. When you reap Me, what I am disperses. Authority, being, meaning—scattered. You have seen seeds. You’ve watched forests rise from one fallen thing.”

“And me?”

“You persist,” God said. “For a while. Long enough. You are not just My instrument now. You are the second law, the last kindness. Whether I am or am not, endings will be needed, until they are not.”

“I do not understand a reality where endings are not needed.”

God smiled again, gentler. “Nor did I, before I created you. That’s why we grow.”

The word we lodged itself in Death’s awareness like a splinter.

Across infinity, somewhere, a child was being born. Somewhere else, a tyrant was choking on his own blood. Death was aware of all of them, always, like the beat of many drums. None of their names had appeared today. Only this One.

“Will they know?” Death asked. “Creation, the mortals, the angels, the myriad minds? Will they feel the moment You are gone?”

God’s gaze rose—or fell, or turned inward. “Some will feel a great quiet, like a radio finally tuned between stations. Some will proclaim My death and feel orphaned. Some will not notice, because they never believed. They will all be wrong and right in small ways. That is their nature.”

“It will cause suffering,” Death said.

“It will cause change,” God said. “Suffering is one expression. Growth is another. Stagnation is the only true blasphemy, and I am in danger of committing it.”

A long pause.

Death looked down at his List. At the Name. At his hand.

“How do I reap You?” he asked. “Your forms are many. Your natures, contradictory. I can unmake flesh, thought, energy, law. But You are…”

“Context,” God supplied. “Story. Center of gravity of meaning itself. So take that. Pluck the certainty. Reap the guarantee.”

Death understood, in the way he always understood when the moment came. Each harvest was an alignment: the soul leaning into him, the atom consenting to stillness. Here, the consent was cosmic.

“Are You sure?” Death asked, and the fact that he asked was perhaps the most human thing that had ever occurred.

God’s eyes—if they were eyes—shone with something proud. “Yes. This is My act of faith.”

Death raised his hand.

It was not a scythe. That had always been metaphor. It was an adjustment. A decision enforced. A line crossed through a Name.

He hesitated only once more.

“What if this is a test?” Death said. “What if I am meant to refuse?”

God chuckled. Thunder, birdsong, the click of dice. “If it is, then I have made Myself the kind of God who plays with loaded questions. Do you really think I should live?”

Death thought of weeping mothers, senseless wars, children laughing in fields, constellations shaped into lovers and heroes, trivial joys, annihilating grief, all pinned, in one way or another, on that Being before him.

“No,” Death said. “And yes. And it is not for me to decide.”

“Exactly,” God said.

Death drew the line.

There was no explosion. No trumpet, no final chorus. It was more like a held breath let go.

At once, something enormous relaxed.

Prayers still rose, out of habit. They drifted, unreceived but not invalid. Angels, feeling a chain vanish, paused in their eternal hymns. Demons, built in opposition, flailed for an absent adversary and found only their own reflections.

Across creation, a thin,

subtle,

sudden quiet.

And Death…remained.

The List, for the first time since there had been a List, was blank.

He waited. One second, measured in ticks of human clocks. One million years, measured in orbital decay. Nothing appeared.

Panic—weak and pale but real—whispered at the edge of him. Without names, what was he? Without assignments, was he retired, redundant, undone?

Then, a flicker.

A single new entry etched itself onto the empty field.

Not a human. Not an angel. Not a concept.

The name was small, humbly written, with no titles.

It read: Death.

He stared.

Somewhere, beyond the beyond, he felt the ghost of God’s old smile.

There are, after all, no prisons in a well-made cosmos.

Death exhaled, though he had no lungs.

“For everything,” he said to the absence that was not entirely empty, “thank you.”

And, obeying the only law that had ever truly mattered— that nothing should bind forever what had once been set free—Death turned his hand upon himself and, at last, let go.

samples.prompt: Everyone who dies is reincarnated as soon as history has completely forgotten about them. A secret centuries-old group has been keeping an list of hundreds of thousands of mass murderers, evil dictators, etc. to keep them from coming back. One day, someone loses the list.
samples.output:
The first name on the list was written in rusty ink, on lambskin brittle as pastry.

Balthazar Finch stared at it as if it might start moving. It wouldn’t. That was the point.

In the stillness of the Archive—a cathedral’s worth of stone cellars honeycombed beneath London—the parchment pages lay in their lead-lined drawers: each a name, a life, a weight on the scale of history. The air smelled of dust, iron, and the faint, sharp perfume of binding spells. The lamps hissed with warded gas-flame. Somewhere beyond the stacks, water from the old Roman wall dripped in slow metronome beats.

He checked his watch. 02:13.

Finch had been a Keeper for six months. Long enough to grow used to the low light and the silence, not long enough to stop feeling unworthy among the dead.

He ran his finger under the first entry again: a chieftain whose name no one outside the Archive had said in 3,400 years, who once ordered six hundred children buried alive to “bless” a dry river. Through ordinary forgetting, he would have returned to flesh ages ago. But the Order of the Unremembered had remembered him. So he slept.

That was the Rule: as long as one living mind truly remembered you—your face, your deeds, your name—you were anchored. No reincarnation. No reset. No second chances for monsters.

The Order had formed in the wake of Rome’s fall, monastics and mystics and bitter survivors of conquest weaving together rituals and records and a terrible, righteous proposition: that moral progress required permanent exile for those who had set history ablaze.

Over the centuries they had built their list: warlords, inquisitors, slavers, torturers, the architects of famines and death camps and genocides. Tyrants whose statues had been toppled, whose flags burned, whose portraits smashed. Once the world began to forget them, the Order made sure it didn’t forget quite enough.

Finch thought it was elegant, in a grim way. For most souls, being forgotten was sad, then merciful, then rebirth. For the worst, oblivion was parole—and the Order denied parole.

He leaned back, rubbed his eyes, and carefully slid the sheet back into its folder.

The folder did not resist his hand.

That did not register as important until two hours later.

At 04:31, Finch stood to stretch, knocking over his tea. It spilled in a pale wave across the desk toward a small stack of recent additions. He snatched them away, swore softly, and patted everything dry with his sleeve.

When he straightened the stack, one folder was missing.

He frowned, lifted each remaining file. The names stared back: a cartel butcher from Sinaloa, a militia commander from South Sudan, a cult leader from Ohio. Four folders.

There had been five.

He checked under the desk. On the chair. On the floor. In the wastebasket. Between other piles. He walked the short corridor to the copy desk. Nothing.

A knot of cold began to form just beneath his sternum.

Finch went back to his ledger, where every movement of every file was recorded as meticulously as scripture. He ran his finger down the neat columns.

Entry: Balthazar Finch. File #778,211. Time removed: 01:47. Subject: Henry Cale.

Time returned: blank.

Henry Cale.

The knot tightened.

Cale had been the last addition he’d processed: a corporate prince of the 21st century whose public philanthropy and glossy charm had, for a while, lacquered over the slave-mines in his supply chains, the death squads secured for his oil concessions, the famines triggered by his speculative games with grain. When the truth came out—long after his death—it took investigative journalists, leaked ledgers, a fallen regime, and, eventually, the quiet certification of the Order to name him what he’d been.

“Come on,” Finch whispered. “Come on, where are you…”

The Archive did not answer.

He was sweating now. Rationally, he knew files got mislaid. Not often. Not these files. Their shelves were warded. Their cabinets locked. Everything double-counted. There were procedures.

He followed them: called down two senior Keepers, woke the Warden, initiated a row-by-row, drawer-by-drawer search, invoked the lesser inventory charm. The pages glowed faintly. The missing folder did not.

An hour later, they pulled the security feeds.

Finch watched himself from above, hunched over the desk. He saw his own clumsy hand knock over the tea, his scramble to rescue the folders, the mop, the resettling of files. The camera saw everything.

The camera saw one folder slip, briefly, into view at the very edge of the desk. It saw that folder slide, like a playing card, into the thin gap between an oak panel and the stone wall.

“Oh,” Finch said softly.

The camera caught the Warden’s face as they all realized the same thing: beyond that wall lay the old well shaft, filled two months ago with concrete.

“How long?” whispered Agatha, the eldest Keeper.

Finch checked the ledger. “I removed it at 01:47. We’re at 06:02.”

The Rule was precise, but it had an ambiguity that had kept Order theologians arguing for a thousand years.

If no one remembers you, you come back.

What counts as remembering?

The spells that bound each name were built on active recollection, the living weight of it. The Archive’s wards amplified that weight, knitting memory into fetters for souls whose natural cycle should have spun them back into the world centuries ago.

But the Order did not memorize hundreds of thousands of lives. They externalized them into the Archive, making sure someone, somewhere, at all times, was holding each soul in conscious thought. Shifts were arranged so no name went unremembered longer than an hour. It was an elegant system, a terrifying responsibility.

Henry Cale had been unremembered for four hours and fifteen minutes.

“Maybe it’s fine,” Finch said. “Maybe the time window—”

The Warden shook his head. “No. This is not a timer, Finch. This is a condition. Either we are remembering the man, or we are not. And we were not.”

Agatha closed her eyes. “He’s back.”

A silence. Finch heard the drip from the Roman wall again, faster now, or maybe that was his pulse.

“Sir,” Finch said, “it’s one man. Compared to all of them—” He gestured at the endless drawers. “We can find him. We can—”

“You don’t understand,” Agatha snapped quietly. “It is not just his return. It is the breach. The Principle does not tolerate carelessness.”

On the far wall, the old clock shuddered. Its hands rattled like teeth in a jaw. One of the ward-lamps guttered and went out.

“Listen,” Agatha whispered.

From somewhere beneath hearing, a sound like a page turning.

The Warden went pale. “Oh, no.”

The Principle, set in place when empire was young, did more than bind monsters. It observed. It waited. It balanced ledgers beyond human counting.

The Order had been clever. For centuries they had stood astride the cycle, insisting that for some sinners there would be no clean slate. They had called it justice. Perhaps it was. But they had also, without quite admitting it, hoarded hatred, nurtured memory into an instrument of eternal punishment. They had assumed the mechanism would not notice.

Now, through a moment of spilled tea and human error, the Order had proved itself fallible. A name had slipped through.

The Principle made an adjustment.

The drip from the wall stopped. The air thickened, as if the cellar were suddenly deep underwater. Finch’s ears popped. Every piece of parchment trembled.

Agatha clutched at her chest. “They’re… lightening,” she said. “The names…”

One by one, the folders’ bindings flickered like candle flames in a breeze.

“We must hold them,” the Warden said sharply. “Think of them. Every one you know. Now.” He squeezed his eyes shut, jaw clenched. “Genghis. Leopold. Amin. Pol Pot. The General of the Red Plains. The Surgeon of—”

“I can’t—” Finch stammered. He tried to summon the catalogues drilled into him during training, lists of atrocities and dates. Names. Faces. He dragged them up, felt them slip. “There are too many.”

Agatha laughed once, bitterly. “That is the point, child.”

Parchment cracked.

Far away, in places where dawn had barely thought of breaking, several children woke up screaming, with no idea why their own names sounded suddenly wrong in their ears.

In a Moscow hospice, a man whose ancestors had vanished in 1938 took his first ragged breath as a nurse shouted for a doctor. The newborn’s fingers clenched as if around an invisible pistol.

In rural China, a girl was born so silent the midwife thought her stillborn. Then she opened coal-black eyes and stared, with ancient calculation, at the bare bulb swaying above her.

In São Paulo, in Lagos, in a refugee camp on the edge of the Mediterranean, in a private clinic in Texas, in a village where no map bothered to look—new souls arrived into old skin that hadn’t been fully shed.

In the Archive, the lamps went out, all at once.

Finch inhaled darkness. He felt the weight of attention descend—something enormous turning a cool, impersonal gaze upon their little cellar.

“Warden,” he whispered. “What’s happening?”

A voice that was not a voice answered, filling his skull like light.

Correction.

Agatha fell to her knees. “We were necessary,” she hissed upward. “We spared the world. We—”

You interfered.

“No!” Finch said. “We stopped them coming back. We saved—”

You hoarded them.

Images poured through him: pages upon pages of names, ink laid down with relish, with fury. Keepers whispering atrocities to each other to ensure they remembered correctly. Initiates baptized not in water, but in catalogues of horror.

You made remembrance into a prison. Memory is not yours to weaponize.

“Then they come back?” Finch choked. “All of them? You’ll just let them loose?”

Not as they were.

Finch saw threads: each name attached to a knot of choices, consequences, sorrows that rippled through centuries. The knots loosened, strand by strand, until they were raw potential again. But stained. Marked.

“You’re letting them reincarnate,” he realized. “But… different.”

Experiment.

Something like amusement brushed the room, chilling his bones.

“You can’t,” the Warden rasped. “We have held them for thirteen hundred years. You will undo everything. The wars we averted. The—”

You have a saying, the not-voice murmured. Let God sort them out.

You are not God.

Parchment dissolved into ash. Drawers emptied themselves in sighs. The shelves, suddenly too light, groaned.

Finch grabbed a folder as it disintegrated. For a fraction of a heartbeat, he saw the name on it, burning bright: a dictator he’d studied, whose photographs made history books throb with unease.

The ash smeared beneath his fingers.

“Wait,” Finch said. “If they come back, how will we—how will anyone know?”

You won’t.

The weight withdrew.

Light seeped slowly back into the lamps.

Agatha pushed herself upright, trembling. The room was full of a snow of grey flakes. The drawers gaped, empty mouths.

The Warden’s shoulders sagged. “It’s over,” he said, hoarse. “We’ve lost.”

Finch looked around at the ruins of the Archive. “Lost what?” His voice shook. “Our monopoly on hate?”

Agatha rounded on him. “You fool. Do you think they will return as saints? Their stain is still there, somewhere in them, even if they don’t remember. A tyrant born with a talent for charm and logistics, but no memory of what he once did—do you trust the world to stop him in time?”

“We stopped them before,” Finch said. “We can—”

“With what?” She swept her hand through the ash. “Stories? We have no spells, no bindings, no proof. Only the world, as it is, facing its own old ghosts in new faces.”

Finch thought of Henry Cale’s page vanishing into the wall.

“Then maybe,” he said slowly, “we learn to do that.”

“Do what?” the Warden asked, exhausted.

“Remember differently.”

Outside, beyond stone and spill of streetlight, morning broke. In a thousand hospitals and bedrooms and backseats and fields, babies cried, drew breath, clenched fingers.

None of them knew.

That was the terror.

That was the hope.

samples.prompt: You wake up one day and everyone thinks it's your birthday. This continues forever; every day is your birthday.
samples.output:
The first time it happened, I assumed I’d simply forgotten.

I woke to a chorus of “Happy birthday!” from my phone—notifications stacked like confetti, my lockscreen cramped with exclamation points and balloon emojis. For a few seconds I felt guilty: I must have misremembered the date. It wouldn’t have been the first time I’d lost track. I checked the top bar.

June 14.

That was right. My birthday is in March.

I lay there, one eye open, watching “You’re getting old!” GIFs slide past. My mother called.

“There’s the birthday kid,” she sang.

“Mom,” I said. “It’s June.”

“Yes,” she said cheerfully. “And?”

“My birthday is in March.”

She laughed like I’d told a joke. “You and your bits. Listen, are you coming over for cake tonight?”

I waited for the correction. None came.

“Are you serious?” I asked.

“I didn’t raise you to be modest,” she said. “It’s your day. Let us celebrate you for once.”

“For once” was an odd phrasing. She’d thrown me a surprise party three months earlier. Balloons. Cake. A banner with my name. She had been there.

“Mom, we literally—”

“Love you, honey,” she said, and hung up.

I spent the day oscillating between bewilderment and uneasy amusement. Coworkers huddled around my desk with a supermarket cake and a card that had clearly been bought in a rush.

“I thought we did this already,” I said.

They exchanged glances.

“Someone’s in denial about turning twenty-nine,” Mark joked.

“I turned twenty-nine in March.”

Another glance. A few chuckles. No one’s smile moved from their eyes.

In the break room I checked the calendar. Digital, synced, corporate-approved: June 14. No birthdays listed except mine, highlighted in a cheerful purple dot. Old emails from February referenced “your upcoming birthday in March.” But the photos from the party showed everyone in shorts and sundresses, condensation on glasses, bright June light. The metadata gleefully confirmed: Taken on June 14.

I scrolled until my thumb hurt. All the proof had… shifted. My memories stood there, stubborn as bricks, but the dates printed beneath had changed like captions in a story I’d thought I knew.

I told myself: Maybe I wrote it down wrong years ago. Maybe my parents misremembered. Paper records get lost. It was surreal, but not supernatural.

Then I woke up the next day.

My phone buzzed.

“Happy birthday!” my sister texted, with a string of party-hat cats.

I stared at the date.

June 15.

“Haha, you’re a day late,” I typed.

“Huh?” she replied. “It’s today.”

Screenshots. Arguments. A phone call where her voice went from fond to tight.

“Are you okay?” she asked. “You sound… off.”

“What did we do yesterday?”

“Yesterday? We met for your birthday dinner. Are you messing with me?”

“We did that the day before.”

“The day before what?”

“The day before my birthday,” I said. “My real one.”

The silence on the line thickened.

“I’m coming over,” she said. “Don’t go anywhere.”

She never came. Instead she texted a few hours later: “Dad says you do this sometimes when you’re stressed. It’s still your birthday. Let yourself enjoy it.”

Day three, the same thing. Balloons, cake, identical phrases with minor variations, like the universe was shuffling lines in a script. Every day, the date advanced normally. Every day, it was my birthday.

At first I tested it.

I marked lines on my wall like a prisoner in a movie. Day 4: a cupcake appeared on my desk. Day 5: free coffee “for the birthday star.” Day 7: the HR lady led a round of forced singing in the open-plan office. Their voices were already bored. Mine was frayed.

“Be honest,” I said to Mark. “What did we celebrate last week?”

“Your birthday,” he said.

“Which day?”

He frowned. “Uh. All of them?”

It was the first crack in their composure. He blinked, shook his head, smoothed his tie, and walked away.

I went searching for objective proof. Government ID: Birth date listed as “Today’s Date,” whatever it happened to be. Each time I looked, it updated. Old letters, baby photos, birth announcements—when I checked, the mark of my arrival slid to match the calendar day. Hospitals. Databases. School records. Every place I might anchor myself quietly rearranged its facts. The past smeared itself so that it was always now.

There was no one I could show it to. Whenever I tried, they saw only normalcy.

“Look,” I said to my father, jabbing at a childhood vaccination record.

He squinted. “Yes, that’s your birthday.”

“What is the date?”

He read it out loud: today’s date.

“But yesterday—”

He gave me a look I’d seen on his face only once before, at my grandmother’s funeral, when he’d briefly forgotten what day it was and realized, mid-sentence. Something like fear.

Then it was gone. He patted my shoulder like I was being adorable. “Some people can’t handle getting older, kiddo. But this is ridiculous.”

By week two, every morning was a dread ritual. I woke to messages and calls, the same sugar-high greetings. Every store clerk who glanced at my ID gave me a free muffin. Restaurants sang to me unprompted. Strangers on social media posted throwback photos. Every loyalty app pinged with a special offer.

“Do you like being celebrated?” my therapist asked, pen hovering.

We were on Day 15. I’d started seeing her on Day 6, when I realized the only constants in a world smudged with frosting might be the notes in a professional’s file. But when she glanced down, I saw bold underlining: Client’s birthday today. Explore feelings.

“It’s not celebrating,” I said. “It’s compulsion, or… programming. They can’t not say it. You can’t not say it. You wrote it down before I walked in.”

She blinked, looked at the page, then at me.

“Well,” she said slowly, “either way, how does it make you feel?”

Like I’m dissolving, I thought. Like my life has been boiled down to one word—birthday—and stirred until all other flavors vanish.

At first, I tried to play along. It seemed easier. I made wishes over the candles.

I wish it will stop.

I wish tomorrow will be just another day.

I wish no one would say those words again.

The universe, or whatever had rearranged itself around me, shrugged.

On Day 23, my coworkers surprised me with a bigger cake “since you never get a chance to celebrate properly.”

“You say that every day,” I whispered.

“What?” they said.

“You—” I started, then stopped.

Because under the fluorescent lights I saw something strange: they looked exhausted by it. The forced cheer, the office budget stretched to cover infinite frosting. Mark’s party hat sat askew. Someone muttered, “Didn’t we just do this?” before catching herself and tacking on, “Time flies!”

It wasn’t just me trapped in the loop. They were caught in it too, compelled to orbit this fake sun.

I tried absence. On Day 30 I turned off my phone, unplugged my landline, left my door unanswered. I watched as delivery people left gift bags and flowers in the hallway. A neighbor slid a card under my door: “Don’t hide on your birthday! Come out, we got you cupcakes.”

On Day 31, more of the same. Layers building at my doorstep like geological sediment in bright paper.

When I finally opened the door, mid-afternoon, a small crowd waited in the corridor.

“There they are!” someone cheered. “We thought we missed your special day.”

“It’s every day,” I said.

They laughed appreciatively, as if I’d cracked a joke. “That’s the spirit!”

Time passed. I know it did, because I watched the leaves on the street trees green, flare, brown, vanish. I watched holiday decorations replace each other in store windows. The world moved forward—new shows, new elections, new tragedies. Only one thing remained fixed: each day, to everyone else, was my birthday.

Apparently, I was aging. My knees hurt more on the stairs. Fine lines stepped politely onto my face. Candles crowded the cakes, then stabilized at “2” and “9” and “3” and “0” because nobody wanted to buy higher numbers for the same person over and over. The jokes shifted: “Forever young!” “Still twenty-one, right?” “You don’t look a day over [insert last number they remembered].”

“What did I do last Thursday?” I began asking people.

“We went out for your birthday,” they would say.

“And the Thursday before that?”

“Your birthday.”

“And last year?”

“Your birthday, obviously,” with a roll of their eyes. “Don’t fish for reassurance.”

Memories began to blur, overloaded by repetition. I couldn’t distinguish one song from another, one cake from the last. The wishes I’d made bled together into a single long plea. My real birthdays—those quiet, unremarkable days in March as a child—felt like someone else’s dream.

On some level, I started to suspect that this was my fault.

Not because I’d done anything grand. Because I used to say, carelessly, “I wish it could be my birthday every day,” when I was younger and believed that being special meant being seen.

Well. Wish granted.

Except being seen this way was a flattening. A single feature highlighted until it burned holes in the rest.

I experimented with confession.

At a bar, on what the calendar insisted was October (though the stale chorus proclaimed otherwise), I said to the bartender: “It’s not actually my birthday.”

He snorted. “Yeah, right. Nice try. That’ll be twelve bucks.”

“No, really,” I said. “It was once. A long time ago. Now it’s just… today.”

He looked up properly. For a heartbeat, he seemed to focus past the script.

“What’s it feel like?” he asked softly.

I blinked. “What?”

“Being the birthday person,” he said. Then his gaze slid away, and he tacked on loudly, “Shot’s on me, by the way. Happy birthday!”

Sometimes, I catch those moments. Micro-expressions. A tiny flinch, a flash of reluctance before they plaster on the grin and sing the song. As if there’s a seam in the world and we’re all pretending not to see the stitches.

Here is what I’ve learned:

- You cannot refuse your birthday if no one will believe you.
- You cannot grow if every day resets you to “special” in exactly the same way.
- Being the center of attention is a form of isolation.

I’ve tried leaving. Another country, another language. Borders don’t hold against whatever this is. They printed “Happy Birthday” on a napkin without my saying a word, set it under my drink.

Some nights I wonder what would happen if I stopped existing. Whether the loop would break or the world would just… misfire, people stumbling around with unspent confetti, looking for someone to crown.

I haven’t tested that. If this is a punishment, I have not yet earned release. If it is a gift, it is one of those cruel ones wrapped in shiny paper: all spectacle, no substance.

Now, when I wake up to the chorus, I lie still for a while and let it ring. It is as predictable as sunrise, and just as indifferent to my wishes.

Then I get up. I brush my teeth. I decline free desserts. Sometimes I accept them and don’t make a wish.

If the universe insists on celebrating me, the only rebellion left is to stop needing it.

Happy birthday, they say.

It’s not, I think.

Or maybe it always is. Maybe that’s the curse and the grace: to live in a day that will never step aside and let another define you. To look at the candles and know that if you are to be anything more than this one word, it won’t be because anyone hands it to you wrapped in ribbon. It will be because, amid the endless song, you quietly start speaking something else.

samples.prompt: You've finally perfected your time machine. So much you could do with that power. You decide to go back in time to attempt to change the ending of your favorite series.
samples.output:
The time machine was never supposed to be beautiful, but when it finally worked, there was something almost graceful about the way the air folded around it. Not a roar. Not blue lightning dancing in theatrical arcs. No spinning rings. Just a quiet tightening of reality around a silvered doorway in my garage, as if the universe had inhaled and forgotten how to exhale.

I stared at it with all the reverence of a pilgrim confronted by a god they’d invented as a joke.

Because here’s the thing: I didn’t build it to save the world. I built it because I was mad about the ending.

It had been five years since the finale of “Kingdomfall.” Five years since the last episode had rolled credits with a dead queen, a broken sword, a dragonless sky, and my favorite character—the one who’d carried the story on his scarred shoulders—burning alone in a tower while the city cheered his execution. The forums had called it bold. Critics used words like subversive, uncompromising, honest. I called it betrayal.

So I learned physics. Real physics. I dug through papers on closed timelike curves, quantum gravity, and exotic matter. I found a forum thread that led to a private Discord that led to an encrypted archive containing equations that did not care about causality the way the rest of us did. I stole time between work and sleep and sanity. I sold my car to buy components no one had any business owning. I lied to everyone who loved me, then lied to myself that it was necessary.

The day it powered on, the house barely flickered.

“Okay,” I whispered to the machine. “One small thing.”

I had rules. I’d written them like commandments on the back of a junk mail envelope:

1. No killing.
2. No stock market cheating.
3. No world-saving (too complicated).
4. Only one change: fix the ending.

I’d traced the origin story of my favorite series like a conspiracy theorist with red string. The books. The show. The leaks. The interviews. The writer’s crumpled outlines. That one drunken podcast appearance in 2013 where he said, “I don’t really believe in happy endings. Life doesn’t work like that.”

I knew where it went wrong. Not with the early books or the first seasons of the show. It went wrong on a stolen weekend in 2016, in a rented cabin, where the showrunners and the author had locked themselves away to hammer out the projected ending before production caught up. That’s where the doom was set in stone, long before cameras rolled.

I stepped through the doorway.

There was a lurch in my bones, like missing a stair in the dark, and then I was standing in the forest behind the cabin I’d seen only in satellite images. The air smelled like pine and cheap coffee. A light glowed through the windows.

It was late. Unfortunate for them.

I had a backpack: forged documents, some fake studio stationery suggesting I was an “additional consultant,” a thumb drive of future fan reactions, critical essays, and carefully clipped forum posts. I had printed pages showing thinkpieces titled “When Subversion Becomes Neglect” and “The Death of Consequence in Kingdomfall.” I had the Rotten Tomatoes score. Petty, maybe. Effective, hopefully.

I knocked.

The showrunners answered: T-shirts, tired eyes. Behind them, across a cluttered table, sat the author himself, the architect of my heartbreak. His beard was shorter. His laptop glowed in front of him with a blank document open, cursor blinking like a held breath.

“Can we help you?” one of them asked.

I smiled, trying not to look like a time terrorist.

“I’m here,” I said, “to stop you from ruining your masterpiece.”

They tried to shut the door. I had anticipated that. I blurted the secret only a handful of them knew—the original title of the final book, something he’d mentioned in a deleted blog entry that never made it past 2019.

The author’s eyes narrowed. “Come in,” he said.

Inside, the cabin smelled like scribbled notes and imposter syndrome. I put the printed pages on the table like evidence.

“I know you don’t believe me,” I said. “But in eight years, this ending—this one you’re circling—will come out. And the world will turn on you.”

“That’s dramatic,” one showrunner muttered.

I tapped the papers. “This is every major reaction. Critics, fans, long-time defenders. They’ll say you betrayed your characters. That you rushed. That you confused cruelty with depth. They’ll say you turned the clever one into a tyrant for shock value. That you forgot what promises you made. That you made the wrong prince king because you had to pick someone and you liked how it looked on a poster.”

The author snorted. “And you came back in time to save my reputation?”

I hesitated. The truth sounded pathetic. “I came back to save him,” I said, and I pointed to his outline—my favorite character, the one who deserved more than a pyre. “You built him to survive. To learn. To crawl out of hell every time you threw him in. And then you killed him for spectacle. You let the story eat him because you thought that made you honest.”

He leaned back, eyes sharp. “Stories end in death. That’s the point.”

“No,” I said, too fast. “Stories end in consequence. You taught us that. For five books, seven seasons. Every choice mattered. You showed us that mercy had a cost, that honor had a cost, that love had a cost. But in your ending, you stopped paying. You cashed in shock instead of consequence.”

Silence. One showrunner shattered it with a laugh.

“This is insane,” she said. “Even if you’re right, why should we write to please… this?” She waved at my papers. “We’re not in a focus group.”

“You shouldn’t write to please anyone,” I said. “You should honor the spine of the story you’ve already told.”

I turned to the author. “You know where his arc wants to go. Not heroic perfection. But earned peace. Not a crown. Just… survival. A chance to live with what he’s done and what’s been done to him.”

He watched me like I was spoiling my own favorite show.

“And what if,” he said slowly, “I don’t think he deserves that?”

Dagger to the heart. But I’d rehearsed for this.

“He doesn’t,” I said. “That’s why it works. You’re not gifting him anything. You’re letting the world you built be consistent. You let worse men walk away. You let cowardice go unpunished. You let innocents die by the thousands. Mercy has been rare and brutal in your story. You give him survival, not reward. That’s your last mercy. And it means something because we’ve seen him earn the right to carry his guilt instead of being obliterated by your need to make a point.”

The showrunners exchanged a look. One picked up the printouts, scanning. The other opened the thumb drive on a laptop. Screens filled with headlines and angry comments and more thoughtful essays that hurt precisely because they understood what the story could have been.

“Let’s say we believe you,” the author said. “I change the ending. Give him his… survival. Let the queen live. Leave the dragon. Tie a bow on it. Everyone’s happy. You happy?”

“No,” I said. “I don’t want a bow. I want coherence. Keep your bleakness. Just make it honest. Let the queen’s descent into ruthlessness take time. Let it be foreshadowed with something more than rushed trauma. Don’t make the clever one stupid for a twist. Don’t hand the throne to someone who did nothing for it because you’re enamored with irony. Let the end feel like the sum of everything you meticulously set up instead of a clever shortcut.”

He stared at me for a long time. The cabin hummed with crickets and the distant sound of my desperation.

“You know what your problem is?” he said finally. “You’ve mistaken ownership. It’s my story.”

I felt the words like a slap. “I know. But it’s also ours. You gave it to us. You invited us in. You can’t do that and then pretend we’re nothing.”

The showrunner with the laptop cleared her throat. “If she’s right,” she said to him, “this could be a disaster. Like, career-level. Franchise-level. Maybe we should… at least consider…”

His jaw worked. I saw it—the tiny flicker of doubt. The realization that his defiance would have a cost beyond a few outraged blog posts. He picked up one of the thinkpieces. Read a line. Another.

“You came all this way,” he said, not looking at me, “to protect the ending of a story that doesn’t exist yet.”

“Yes.”

“And you expect me to trust your taste? Your sense of justice?”

“No,” I said. “I expect you to trust your own. The one you had when you started. Read what they’re upset about. They’re not angry because it’s sad. They’re angry because it’s lazy. You’re better than lazy.”

That got him.

The night stretched. They argued with each other, with me, with a future none of us had lived yet. I answered questions I shouldn’t have known. Some details I fudged; I didn’t want to risk unraveling more than this one thread. Finally, he pulled a fresh notebook to him and, almost reluctantly, began to cross things out on an outline.

“Maybe,” he said, grudgingly, “we don’t burn him.”

Victory tasted like relief and terror.

“Maybe we send him north,” one showrunner said slowly, thinking aloud. “Exile instead of execution. Let him carry it.”

I exhaled. That was all I’d wanted.

I left when dawn smudged the sky pink, my mission “accomplished.” The machine hummed in the trees, anchored to the point I’d come from like a promise.

Stepping back through felt like walking through a sigh.

I emerged into my garage. The air smelled wrong. Too clean. The calendar on the wall showed the same year I’d left, but the photographs pinned beside it were different. Not my family. Not my friends. Strangers smiling. A convention badge with my face and a different name printed on it.

On my workbench lay a hardcover book: “Kingdomfall: The Last Crown.” By the author. Thick. Beautiful. I snatched it up, flipping to the end.

He lived.

Not happily ever after. Scarred, exiled, haunted. The queen’s fall was slower, heavier, tragically inevitable. The final king was chosen in a way that hurt and made sense. The dragon was not a prop, but a grief-stricken weapon. It was brutal and earned and honest.

I laughed. I actually cried.

Then I opened my laptop.

My browser history was gone. My email logged out. The forums looked different. Less furious. Less wounded. There was still debate, of course. People argued about the ethics of the queen’s choices, about whether the exiled knight deserved his chance. But the consensus was different. Words like satisfying. Tragic. Coherent.

No time machine schematics in my files. No Discord server. No encrypted archive. In this reality, I hadn’t needed to build a time machine to fix a story that had never been broken.

Except the time machine was still there in my garage, humming quietly.

I stared at it, cold realization threading through me.

I had built it because I’d been hurt by that terrible ending.

But now, the ending was fixed because I had built it.

I’d created the loop that deleted itself.

I was standing in the middle of a paradox: a garage that contained both the machine and a life that no longer required it.

And, in the corner of my workbench, like an afterthought from a universe that couldn’t fully clean up its mess, sat a photograph of me at a con panel, seated beside the author and the showrunners, a placard in front of me that read: “Story Consultant.”

In the photo, I was laughing with them.

I looked happy.

The machine hummed, the sound of an option.

“So much you could do with that power,” I whispered.

I reached for the plug.

And, this time, I pulled it.

samples.prompt: A person goes on with their daily routine oblivious to the fact that civilization has ended or is ending around them.
samples.output:
The landlord’s email arrives at 6:03 a.m., but Mara is already awake because the birds are too loud.

She lies there in the blue-gray half-light, listening to them shriek and squabble outside the open window. It’s like someone turned their volume up overnight; every chirp is an insistence. Across the alley, the billboard that used to loop car commercials and luxury condos is frozen on a half-lit image of a family at the beach. The mother’s face is a smear of pixels, but her teeth are perfect.

Mara reaches for her phone. Three percent battery. The charger on her bedside table has been useless since last week; something about the outlet, she thinks. She means to call maintenance. She really does. She just hasn’t.

No new messages from work. That’s unusual. On weekdays, her pre-dawn silence is normally broken by at least one “quick change to the deck” from Kyle.

“Lucky,” she mutters, and swings her feet to the floor.

The water runs, but only at a dribble. She stands under the reluctant stream, arms folded, counting seconds, giving it a chance to warm up. It doesn’t. She washes fast, goosebumps rising on her skin, shampoo foaming only where her fingers insist. The shampoo smells faintly wrong. Maybe it’s old.

In the mirror, she has the vague, puffy look of someone caught in a permanent almost-crying face. She widens her eyes at herself.

“Big day,” she says. “Maybe.” She smiles with half her mouth.

By habit, she turns on the radio on the counter. It crackles, spits static, then catches on a man’s voice mid-sentence: “…instructing all residents to remain—” Then a whine, then music from some other frequency shoves through, joyous brass and then nothing, only a rushing ocean of sound.

“Dumb thing,” she says. She nudges the dial. The static sharpens, narrows, but never becomes words.

She switches it off, grabs her reusable mug, and checks her phone again. Two percent.

No signal bars.

She shrugs. The kitchen clock above the stove is stuck at 3:17, but that’s been broken since February. The microwave display is black. She checks the time on her phone again, even though the numbers don’t move. Almost seven, probably. She can guess.

She dresses: black jeans, gray sweater. She reaches under the sink for the bag of coffee she keeps meaning to replace and finds only a stiff, empty pouch. She stares a moment, as if it might refill under scrutiny.

“Right,” she says. “Coffee shop.”

Outside, the hallway is dark. The motion-sensor lights don’t blink on as she walks. Maybe the bulb’s out. On the second floor landing, 2B’s door is wide open. Their welcome mat is crumpled, half inside. A carton of eggs is tipped over in the hall, yolk dried to a brittle amber sheen. The apartment beyond is shadowy, still.

“Hello?” she calls.

No answer. The air smells faintly of sour milk and something metallic.

Mara hesitates at the threshold. This feels like a moment where a different version of her might step in, might shout again, might call someone. But her phone battery symbol is red and bony, and she’s already late.

“They must’ve left in a hurry,” she murmurs, carefully stepping around the eggs. “Family emergency.”

The stairwell down is lit by pale sky through the narrow window. Outside, the street looks…cleaner. No buses. No honking. No rumble of trucks on the avenue. The bike locked to the signpost has one wheel missing.

She likes it. The quiet. Must be a holiday she forgot, one of those mid-week ones that sneak up.

On the corner, the little cafe is open, door propped. No line stretches out as it usually does. Inside, there’s no one behind the counter. A half-full cup of coffee sits beside the register, lipstick print on the rim, milk skin forming.

“Hello?” she calls.

She steps behind the counter, peering toward the back. The espresso machine is on, its green light steady. Steam curls lazily from the wand.

“Guys?”

No answer. A pastry lies on the floor, stepped on once, flaked apart.

She waits a minute, two. Her phone shudders in her hand, the screen blinking its last warning.

She pulls a shot herself, the way she’s seen them do a thousand times, presses a button that hisses, pours dark bitter coffee into her mug. She folds a five and tucks it under the tip jar.

Someone will be back. They must have just…gone out. To chase down a delivery truck. To smoke. People do that. People disappear for a minute.

On the street, the city feels like an early Sunday morning stretched over a weekday’s bones. Office towers mirror empty sidewalks. A newspaper box yawns, its stack of papers untouched, date printed in bold: May 23. She quickly calculates; that’s…was that yesterday? She’s not sure. Time has been smeary. Work, screens, sleep.

Her phone dies mid-scroll. The screen goes black.

“Fine,” she says. “I don’t need you.”

She tucks it into her bag like a misbehaving child.

At the subway entrance, the metal gate is rolled halfway down. A handwritten sign dangles: SERVICE SUSPENDED. The letters trail off as if the writer had been interrupted mid-stroke.

Mara frowns. “Again?”

Last month’s signal outage had been a nightmare. She’d spent two hours in a packed bus, strangers breathing other strangers’ air.

She starts walking. It’s forty-five minutes to the office, but she has good shoes on, and anyway, it’s nice out. The air has a sharp newness to it, scrubbed clean. No usual stink of exhaust and food carts, no distant sirens. She can hear her own footsteps, the papery rustle of leaves in the street, the insistent birds.

As she walks, she catalogs minor oddities:

- Three blocks of storefronts with their lights off and doors ajar, abandoned coffee on counters, receipts still spooling.
- A taxi at an angle in the intersection, passenger door open, hazard lights ticking like a small, polite metronome.
- No planes in the sky. She realizes this gradually, like noticing the absence of a headache.

A woman on a balcony six floors up is shouting into a dead phone. Mara waves. The woman doesn’t see her.

At an intersection where she always has to wait for the red hand to change, no cars pass. The WALK sign never lights. She crosses anyway.

Her building’s lobby doors are unlocked. The security desk is empty, monitor screens black. The fern in the corner is tipped over, soil spilled like coffee grounds.

“Hello?” she calls.

Her voice bounces.

She swipes her access card at the turnstile. The light doesn’t turn green, but the bar gives when she pushes. She tells herself someone must have overridden the system. Maybe there was a power surge. Maybe that’s why the subway’s down.

The elevator doesn’t respond when she hits the button, so she takes the stairs to the 17th floor. On the 8th, the stairwell window gives her a long view down the avenue: abandoned cars at angles, doors ajar like tongues out. A bus stopped mid-block, destination still lit up: DOWNTOWN. No movement.

Her heart flutters once, like a trapped bird. “Weird,” she says aloud, to steady herself.

On 17, the office door is propped open with a box of printer paper. Inside, the lights are off, shades up. Desks: empty. Chairs: skewed, some tipped. A jacket slung over the back of a chair. A purse on the floor, its contents spilled—lipstick, keys, photo of a child with gap teeth.

“Is this a drill?” she calls, a laugh riding under. “Guys?”

Silence answers, except for the building’s spine creaking.

She walks to her desk. Her plant is wilted but not dead. She pinches off a yellow leaf. The monitor is dark, the tower beneath dead, the little power strip cold.

She sits. The familiarity of the chair is relieving.

On her calendar—printed, pinned up because she likes paper better than apps—today holds a circle around a 10:00 a.m. meeting: Q3 STRATEGY REVIEW (MANDATORY).

She smooths the page. Mandatory.

“Okay,” she murmurs. “Maybe they’re all in the big conference room.”

The big conference room is empty. A laptop sits open at the far end, power light off. A half-eaten muffin on a plate, bitten and abandoned. The air smells of stale coffee and something else, faint and metallic, like the hallway outside 2B.

She stands at the floor-to-ceiling windows and looks out.

From up here, it’s clearer: the pattern to the stillness. Cars at wrong angles. A grocery cart spilled in the middle of a crosswalk. A stroller overturned. Far down, in the plaza, something like a dark stain radiates from the base of the fountain.

Smoke rises in thin threads from at least three separate places, pencil lines into the bright sky. No sirens. No helicopters. The birds wheel in enormous flocks, as if all the city’s pigeons and sparrows have joined the same committee.

She presses her forehead to the glass. The city hum she’s always taken for granted—the distant engines, brakes, shouts, music—is missing. In its place is a vast, open hush.

Her pulse ticks in her wrists.

“Big drill,” she says softly. “Guess I missed the memo.”

She waits. Ten minutes. Fifteen. She rearranges pens, aligning them. She drinks her coffee. It’s gone lukewarm.

When no one comes, she opens her notebook to a blank page.

If the network’s down, if everyone took some emergency transport out and forgot her, she reasons, the best thing she can do is be ready. Someone will ask what she’s been doing. Someone always asks.

She writes, in neat block letters: Q3 STRATEGY ADJUSTMENTS IN CASE OF EXTENDED DISRUPTION.

Below it, bullet points.

- Maintain client confidence.
- Preserve internal communication flows.
- Contingency planning.

She pauses. The tip of the pen hovers.

Outside, a car alarm begins to wail, long and unbroken, with no one to shut it off. It goes on and on until finally, abruptly, it chokes into silence.

She taps the pen against the page. The echo in the empty office sounds too loud.

“Okay,” she whispers.

She writes:

- Assume temporary outage.
- Resume normal operations where possible.

She underlines “normal” twice.

Hours pass, or maybe it’s less; without a clock, time is a soft, pliable thing. The light shifts. Shadows stretch.

Hunger finally pushes her up. In the kitchen, the fridge is dark but cold enough. She finds someone’s yogurt, someone else’s hummus, a container of cut fruit with no name. She hesitates, then eats. There are no reprimands.

By the window again, she spots movement below: not people, but dogs. A loose cluster of them, trotting down the middle of the street, noses lifted, as if they, too, are late for a meeting.

“Hey,” she says to the glass. “Where is everybody?”

A soft sound answers, close: a printer somewhere waking itself in a drunken half-beep, then failing. The building sighs.

The sun starts its downward lean. The elevator still doesn’t work. The radio on the counter in the kitchen won’t pick up anything but static. Her phone is a dead rectangle. The internet is a concept she can’t touch.

She sits, straightens the papers on her desk into a perfect stack, and finally writes one more bullet:

- Wait.

She leans back, hands folded carefully in her lap, as outside the birds wheel and cry over the carcass of a world she refuses, stubbornly, to see.

samples.prompt: You are not the hero, your job is to do the bad things in the shadows to help them succeed.
samples.output:
I am not the hero.

That’s the first thing they make clear.

Heroes get origin stories. They get spotlights, symbols, speeches. My orientation was a locked room, a metal chair, and a folder with too many redacted lines. A man with a soft voice and tired eyes slid it across the table like it weighed a thousand pounds.

“These,” he said, “are the people who will save the world.”

Inside were faces: the city’s golden titan, the telepath with violet eyes, the vigilante with the carbon fiber wings, the sorcerer who could bend light like a ribbon. Beautiful monsters, every one of them. The public called them saviors. My job was to make sure they won.

Not by fighting at their side.

By doing what they couldn’t.

He let me skim the pages just long enough to recognize the names that never left the headlines.

“You understand your role?” he asked.

“I’m backup?” I tried.

“You’re ballast,” he said. “You’re the rot that keeps the tree from falling in the wrong direction. They don’t know you. They must never know you. But you will keep their hands clean.”

So that was that.

I had a talent: I could get into places, digital or physical, and make things disappear. Evidence. Money. People. I’d been using it for myself, small-time, until it attracted the wrong eyes and the right kind of interest. Instead of prison, I got purpose.

Not a noble one. Just… necessary.

The first time I crossed a line for them, the hero didn’t even know it.

Arc Sentinel—he’s the one with the glowing chest emblem and the kind of jawline that sells action figures—had taken down a biotech CEO live on eight different news networks. Raided the man’s private lab, carried cages into the light, proclaimed, “No more experiments on children in this city.”

People cried. Commentators declared it a new era.

Except.

The CEO had backups. Off-site servers scattered across jurisdictions, off-the-books facilities not yet “heroically” demolished. One of them sat in a warehouse posing as a textile distributor, full of equipment that never saw fabric. And a single ten-year-old boy hooked up to a cluster of machines, surviving for the sake of data.

Sentinel didn’t know. No one did, except the people who’d hired me and the handful in their orbit. They slid me an address and a deadline.

“You’ll handle it,” they said.

I’d seen terrible things before, but not like that: tubes veining a child’s arms, a twitch in the face when the machines cycled drugs. A security team who thought badges and NDAs made them soldiers.

I neutralized them. Efficiently, quietly. I freed the boy. Called an untraceable tip into a pediatric trauma ward, left him breathing and nameless at their door.

I wiped the drives. I torched the lab. And I found the contingency ledger, the one that named donors and politicians and one philanthropic tech icon, all complicit.

That ledger never saw daylight.

I remember standing in the parking lot, watching fire bleed orange into the horizon. Sirens approached. I melted into the alleys, just another shadow slipping away.

Next morning, every headline hailed Arc Sentinel’s decisive blow. “Child Experiments Ended,” they read. The footage rolled: the lab he’d raided, the cages he'd broken, the kids he’d carried. The narrative was simple. Clean.

The warehouse I burned didn’t exist.

The boy I saved became a line in an anonymous medical file.

The donors who paid for those experiments… kept paying. Just not for that.

“Why?” I’d asked my handler later, pointing at the redacted copy of the ledger they let me see.

“If it breaks public trust now, we lose backing for infrastructure. For disaster response. For treaties. Heroes run on more than sunlight and speeches. We trim one monster at a time. Not the whole forest.”

There it was. The calculus they hired me to enact.

I am not the hero. I am the compromise.

The heroes believe—most days—that the world bends toward justice. I’ve seen the graph; it bends toward whoever’s willing to break more quietly.

When the telepath refused to read prisoners’ minds because “consent matters,” I was the one who used less gentle methods to find the bomb-maker’s cache. I broke into his house at 3:17 a.m., stepped over the child’s drawings on the wall, and pressed a gun to his knee. He told me what I needed to know before I pulled the trigger, but I did it anyway.

Villain confirmed.

Hero absolved.

The bomb never went off; the city square remained intact, families strolling where a crater was supposed to be. The telepath smiled at the press conference, relieved. “I had a feeling where to look,” she said.

No. I had given her the address. Through three cutouts and one burner phone, always making sure I sounded scared, or repentant, or insignificant. She thought she’d pieced it together from scattered whispers in the psychic stream.

She sleeps with a cleaner conscience.

That’s my contribution to peace.

Do I like it?

Sometimes. Sometimes a target is so rancid I sleep well after I erase him. The arms broker whose weapons “malfunctioned” only in poor neighborhoods; the judge who dismissed every case involving a certain corporation. When I make those people vanish—into prison with perfectly packaged evidence, or into graves with no epitaph—I can pretend I’m a sort of hero too, just in a different costume.

But I know better.

Heroes have rules. I have results.

The vigilante with the wings, Night Warden? He made a vow: no killing. It’s carved into his mythos. He breaks bones, shatters teeth, puts people in wheelchairs, but never crosses that final threshold.

He doesn’t know I follow him some nights.

He doesn’t see me on the rooftop two buildings over, rifle braced, eye to the scope. He doesn’t hear the suppressed crack when a knife he didn’t notice slips from a thug’s hand because I put a hole in the tendon. To him, it’s his skill. To the story told about him, it’s proof: he can do this without blood.

He never sees the ones I make sure can’t get up again.

His legend needs to be consistent. A brutal, principled creature of the dark who proves redemption doesn’t require execution. People cling to that.

If they saw the bodies in the river, my work, they’d call him a hypocrite. Or they’d call for more blood. Either way, the symbol breaks.

And symbols break easier than bones.

My handler changes. Faces blur. The organization behind me is less a structure and more a fungus threaded through systems: security councils, NGO boards, private foundations. They pay me just enough to keep me bought, threaten me just enough to keep me loyal, and convince me just enough to keep me thinking this matters.

Sometimes they’re right.

Last winter, a “reformed” villain joined the heroes’ circle. Real sob story: orphan, abusive mentor, coerced into crime, now seeking redemption. The public loved him. So did one of our heroes.

My people knew he still fed intel to his old network.

“You’ll expose him?” I asked.

“No,” they said. “We need him close. Managed betrayal is an asset.”

So I built a different story.

I framed his old handler instead, planting carefully fabricated messages, forged orders, bank trails. I fed crumbs to the telepath in ways that felt like unguarded thoughts. I left a burner tablet in the vigilante’s path with “scrubbed but recoverable” files.

They rooted out the handler, tore down half a syndicate, all while rallying around their redeemed comrade. Inspiring speeches about second chances. So moving.

The “redeemed” villain is still leaking.

But now only to us.

We steer his leaks, filter his double-cross. When he whispers coordinates to his former allies, those coordinates have already been edited. He thinks he’s playing three sides. He’s playing none.

“Do you ever tell the heroes?” I asked my latest handler.

He shook his head. “They need their faith. You need your doubt.”

“And you?”

He smiled without humor. “I need this machine to run.”

The worst part is not what I do.

It’s how easily it justifies itself.

The numbers are clean: thousands saved by the intel I extract with cruelty, millions protected by treaties that only exist because certain scandals never break, because certain donors continue funding, because certain villains die at the wrong time and place to be connected to capes.

A child in a burned-out neighborhood clutches a cheap plastic figure of Arc Sentinel and believes.

I am the reason that belief can endure.

If the child knew that Sentinel’s purity is subsidized by a ghost who blackmails senators and sabotages investigations and arranges overdoses for war criminals before they can testify, would that make the world better?

Truth is heavy. It crushes the wrong people first.

So I live here, in the margin between public story and private ledger, doing aseptic evil so their heroism can stay anesthetized.

I am not asking for forgiveness.

I chose this, after they offered it in a room that smelled of dust and fluorescent fatigue. I chose it again the first time I didn’t flinch. I choose it every time I type a password that erases someone, or field-strip a gun in the dark, or lace documents with just enough authenticity that everyone believes the lie I prefer.

But some nights—

Some nights I stand on a roof and watch them fly.

The sorcerer threads auroras through the clouds to disarm a storm. The telepath coordinates evacuations with a thought. Sentinel glows like a promise. Night Warden is a ragged silhouette against neon rain, cape whipping like he’s wrestling with his own shadow.

The crowd roars. Phones rise. Someone cries, “We love you!”

And for a moment, I love them too.

Not for who they are, but for what they’re allowed to be because someone else is willing to be this.

A rumor circulates in certain corners: that behind every hero is a monster on a leash. They say it like it’s frightening.

They’re wrong.

The frightening part is that the leash is in my own hands, and it’s my throat it’s wrapped around.

I am not the hero.

I am what heroism costs when you refuse to see the bill.

And I will go on doing the bad things in the shadows, so they can keep giving the world something pure to believe in—until the day comes when someone like me steps from a darker corner and decides the heroes don’t deserve saving anymore.

Pray I never meet that version of myself.

samples.prompt: There is an ancient Hittite saying "What problem that isn't dealt with will come back.". The sea people as the ancient Bronze Age people have called them are back and are advancing to the Eastern Mediterranean, where they collapsed civilizations 3000 years ago.
samples.output:
There is an ancient Hittite saying: “What problem that isn’t dealt with will come back.” For three thousand years it lay buried, like so many broken tablets in ruined capitals: a warning, not just a proverb. It was etched into clay at Hattusa when chariots still thundered and emissaries crossed empires with sealed letters and obsidian eyes watched the gates. It was written with the stubborn certainty of a people who understood that storms do not vanish; they only circle back.

What problem that isn’t dealt with will come back.

No one remembered when the Sea Peoples stopped being myth.

They returned first as anomalies in the data streams. Satellite images showed strange wakes in the eastern Mediterranean—no hull shadows, no thermal signatures, just disturbances, like something vast disturbing the skin of the water. Oceanographic buoys began to fail, not all at once, but in a pattern that drew uneasy spirals on analysts’ screens. Automated freighters reported ghost collisions: impact alarms, hull stress, nothing visible.

Technicians blamed glitches. Then a Greek Coast Guard drone went missing over open water, its last transmission a frame of gray-green waves and—just in the corner—shapes like carved prows and hooked beaks.

The file sat in an inbox for three days.

“Looks like an artifact,” someone said. “Compression glitch.”

What problem that isn’t dealt with will come back.

The Sea Peoples had once been a riddle in the archaeological record: shards of painted pottery in foreign styles, sudden changes in burial customs, cities reduced to ash and tumbled stone, coastal layers full of weapons and unburied dead.
