The scholars argued: migrants, mercenaries, pirates, climate refugees, warriors displaced by famine and fire. A convergence of crises, they said. No single invader, just a name scrawled by desperate kings who needed someone to blame.

Now, the name was back.

They announced their return not with a declaration but with an erasure.

On a cool spring morning, the container port at Ashdod went silent. Cameras facing the sea turned white and then black. Harbor sensors recorded a surge, a trough, and an impact like a fist. When the feeds came back, three supercontainers ships lay canted, half-submerged, their sides gashed open as if something had torn at them from below. The water boiled with bubbles, then stilled.

No storm. No torpedo wakes. No claim.

In Beirut, a week later, people filmed the horizon: a serrated dark line, like oars. Too far to be clear, too many to be plausible. The footage stuttered as if ashamed of itself.

The talking heads called it a coordinated cyberattack on maritime infrastructure. Insurance markets trembled. The Eastern Mediterranean naval forces were put on alert. Patrol craft went out, UAVs droned over empty waves, and sonar reported anomalies that did not match any known signature.

Then came the survivors.

A Turkish fishing boat was found adrift south of Cyprus, its hull scorched and slashed. Of the eight-man crew, three were alive. They could not explain. They whispered about ships without engines, ships of blackened wood that did not burn, and men—or things shaped like men—in helms like fanged crowns, with eyes like tide pools. Hooks bit into their deck, ropes flew like striking snakes, and then—

“And then?” someone prompted in the hospital.

“And then the old stories,” one fisherman said. “But worse.”

The phrase “Sea Peoples” appeared in a minor op-ed two days later.

It took off in twenty-four hours.

In Hattusa, the ruins slept under spring flowers, the cuneiform tablets untroubled by the headlines that now said: ARE THE SEA PEOPLES BACK? and THE RETURN OF ANCIENT TERRORS. Interviews with archaeologists rolled familiar footage: carved reliefs of horned helmets and feathered headdresses, lines of warriors, ships with curling prows.

“This is sensationalism,” one scholar protested. “The Sea Peoples were a confederation, a complex phenomenon—”

But the images coming in from merchant crews pushed nuance aside. Grainy pictures of low, sleek silhouettes gliding against the light. The glint of bronze—bronze?—on arms that rowed in terrifying unison. Arrows that sparked against modern hulls, tipped with something that bit through alloys. A style, a shape, a horror out of museum glass.

“What we are seeing,” said a military analyst on live television, “appears to be a highly advanced technological mimicry of Late Bronze Age maritime cultures, deployed as psychological warfare. There is no evidence these are ‘the same’ Sea Peoples from three thousand years ago.”

On the same split screen, a map hung red with flagged incidents stretching from Sicily to Haifa.

In an underground situation room in Ankara, a historian stood facing a row of admirals and ministers. She had been dragged from a conference on climate archaeology to explain something no one had properly listened to when it was mere scholarship.

“The Hittite proverb,” she said carefully, “is not just about enemies. It’s about unresolved crises. At the end of the Late Bronze Age, they faced systemic drought, overextended trade routes, fragile food supplies, reliance on mercenaries, political fragmentation. They didn’t address the foundations. When stress came, everything snapped. The Sea Peoples were one wave in a storm of problems everyone ignored.”

“And now?” an admiral asked.

“And now,” she replied, “we have overfished seas, destabilized states along this coast, climate refugees, privatized navies, and a global economy throttled by chokepoints we treat as inviolable.”

“We have fleets,” said the admiral. “Satellites. Missiles. Drones.”

“The Hittites had chariots and walls,” she said. “And a proverb.”

When the real assault began, it bypassed strength and struck weakness, as before.

- Fiber-optic cables on the seabed: cut in an hour one night off Crete.
- Three LNG tankers: vanished in clear weather between Alexandria and Piraeus, their last transmissions full of static overlaid with hollow horn notes.
- A refugee convoy from the Levant: found burned to the waterline near Rhodes, rafts torn apart, life jackets bobbing amid splintered planks that did not match any modern vessel.

NATO task forces sailed, sleek and confident. They made contact at dusk.

The engagement would be replayed in simulations for years without producing consensus.

For seventeen minutes, all systems functioned. Drone swarms fanned out. Targeting computers blinked green. Sonar painted flickers: many small craft, dense formation. Then the sensory field flooded. Signals multiplied, folded, twisted back. Radar painted wooden hulls where nothing should have reflected. LIDAR saw empty air. Visual feeds showed rows of ships with square sails against a wind that had died.

“They’re spoofing everything,” muttered a technician.

“Weapons free,” ordered the commodore.

Missiles knifed toward the phantom fleet. Some hit water. Some struck hulls that did not shatter as wood or steel should, rippling instead like tar solidified at the edge. One feed, never officially released, showed an impact blossoming into black foam that climbed the sky like smoke and then fell, hissing, acid-bright into the sea.

Then the fleet’s systems went blind.

Not just jammed; severed.

In the silence, the Sea Peoples advanced.

They came in close, their shapes now unmistakable: hulls carved with eyes and beaks, paddles and oars that did not quite match any museum reconstruction, armor that shone in a shade of metal that was not bronze and not steel, woven shields like living things. Their prows broke modern hulls as if they knew exactly where to strike.

Boarding actions—boarding actions in the twenty-first century—were recorded on body cameras that only later struggled up through corrupted data. Figures with plaited beards and crests like stone wings moved with practiced efficiency, wielding spears that shorted out electronics with a touch and blades that left wounds smoking. They said little. When they did, linguists later traced echoes of Luwian, Mycenaean Greek, tongues scraped from clay and guessed at.

It was impossible. It was happening.

“What do you want?” shouted one captured commander, his words translated through three terrified interpreters.

A leader of the Sea Peoples regarded him. His eyes were like polished river stones, old and clear.

“You invited us,” he said in a voice like surf on shingle. “You left your coasts hollow. You let your people drift. You let the sea grow hungry.”

“We did not—”

“You forgot,” the man said. “We remember.”

It spread quickly from that interrogation, real or staged, that eerie answer: You invited us.

That was the part people understood, because it fit the proverb. Problems do not vanish. They metastasize in the dark. The late Bronze Age had cracked under the weight of its own complexity and blindness; the Sea Peoples had been catalyst, symptom, punishment, or all at once. Now, after centuries of warnings—about climate, about inequality, about brittle systems and outsourced violence—the modern world faced its own returning wave.

In Cairo, Athens, Tel Aviv, Istanbul, people watched the horizon with old fear. Governments scrambled to adapt tactics, to treat this not merely as an enemy fleet but as the embodiment of everything unattended: broken fisheries, drowned villages, stateless populations willing to crew any ship that offered them a flag and food. Intelligence reports suggested alliances of mercenaries, biotech smugglers, ex-military from half a dozen nations, cloaking themselves in archaic imagery for effect. Others insisted there was something older under it all, something that had learned across millennia and waited for its moment.

The distinction mattered less than the pattern.

“What problem that isn’t dealt with will come back,” murmured the historian in another briefing. “We like to think history is a line. It’s not. It’s a tide. Ignore the pull long enough, and it arrives all at once.”

Across the embattled sea, a new coalition formed—not just of warships, but of reluctant reforms. Emergency measures shored up collapsing ports. Food and water convoys were rerouted to places long neglected. Agreements were hammered out in frantic, night-lit conferences to share patrols, data, burdens. Old rivals coordinated defense. They began, belatedly, to treat the sea not as an endless dumping ground and highway, but as a living frontier whose anger was now personified in oars and spears and impossible ships.

The Sea Peoples did not vanish overnight. They harried, tested, withdrew. Each clash cost blood and steel. Each encounter etched deeper the realization that they were feeding on cracks already there.

It was months before the attacks ebbed, years before trade felt steady. In that uneasy quiet, the proverb returned to textbooks and graffiti, to speeches and whispered arguments.

“What problem that isn’t dealt with will come back.”

The world had named the problem in the shape of spectral raiders on archaic ships, but under that image lay the true adversary: its own refusal to act until the past came rowing out of legend to collect its due.

The sea, patient and old, waited to see if this time, they had learned.

samples.prompt: You wake one day to find that one of your friends doesn't exist anymore, no one remembers him, and no one thinks he even existed. Later, you get a message with 5 words from an unknown number. you scream in horror as you read the message.
samples.output:
The first thing I noticed was the empty chair.

It sat across from me at our regular table by the window, one leg wrapped in duct tape from when Noah had kicked it out in a fit of drunken sincerity about “structural integrity of relationships.” The waitress set down my coffee and a muffin, glanced at the opposite side as if checking for a second order, then moved on. No extra mug. No second plate.

I checked my phone.

Me: yo where are you

Noah: (no recent messages)

The last text from him was two days old—a meme about pigeons. I scrolled up through months of conversation: late-night rants, half-finished poems, photos of his chipped guitar, screenshots of our arguments with strangers online. They were there. Solid.

I typed again.

Me: Noah?

The message sent. One gray check. Two.

“Expecting someone?” the waitress asked as she passed.

“My friend. He’s late.”

She frowned. “You’re always alone here, sweetheart.”

I laughed once, uncomfortably. “No, I’m—he comes here all the time. Tall, loud, messy hair. Noah.”

Blank stare. “I’ve never served you with anyone else.”

She walked away. I watched her go, a cold, small hollow opening under my ribs.

I left the coffee half-finished.

Outside, the morning felt overexposed, like someone had turned the brightness up on reality. The air smelled too sharp. I called him. Straight to voicemail. No greeting, just the generic robotic woman: “The person you have called…”

I remembered his greeting used to be there. Some self-deprecating joke about not leaving a message unless I was a time traveler. It wasn’t funny, but it was him. Now it was gone.

I frowned, checked the number. It was framed by the green of “recent calls,” a dozen interactions. Same number. Great. Fine.

I walked three blocks to his apartment.

The building’s red brick familiar, the chipped blue paint on the front door the same color we’d made fun of. I buzzed 3B.

A man’s voice crackled through, annoyed. “Yeah?”

“Uh, is Noah there?”

“Who?”

“Noah. Lives in 3B.”

“Been here six years,” the man said. “Ain’t no Noah. Wrong buzzer.”

He hung up.

Heart rate up now. I buzzed again. This time, he just shouted, “Seriously, knock it off,” and killed the line.

I tried the landlord’s number taped beside the call box. He picked up on the second ring.

“Hi, I’m looking for Noah Greene? In 3B?”

“Noah who?” he said.

“Greene. He’s been here for, like, four years. Tall, curly hair, always pays late? Guitar? Look, this isn’t funny—”

“There’s no Greene on my records,” he said, impatience creeping in. “Hasn’t been. 3B is Matthews.”

My mouth went dry. “I was here last week.”

“Then you visited Matthews,” the landlord said, and hung up.

I stood there with my phone in my hand until the cold sank through my jacket.

Okay. Okay. Crazy, glitchy morning. I opened our photos.

There should have been hundreds—Noah at my birthday, Noah at the lake, Noah holding up a soggy slice of pizza like a trophy.

What I saw instead were holes.

Not literal blank spaces. The images were there: my birthday, the lake, the pizza parlor. Everyone arranged around… nothing. Gaps where he should be standing. Sometimes the composition made sense—I could imagine we’d just left a space. But in others people were angled toward emptiness, arms around absence like they were hugging air. In one, my hand was raised in a toast toward the empty space. My smile reached for someone no longer there.

I tapped on one image, zoomed in. The pixels where he should be were just background.

I scrolled faster. No photos of him. No tags of “Noah Greene.” My search came up empty.

I opened Instagram, typed his username into the search bar.

No results.

I checked our mutual friends’ lists. Our circle: Micah, Jess, Lena. None of them followed him. None of them had.

I added his full name. Nothing.

By the time I called Micah, my hands shook.

He picked up on the second ring. “Yo.”

“Where’s Noah?” I demanded.

“Who?”

“Noah. Our friend. Don’t screw with me.”

Silence. Then a short laugh. “You okay, man? I think you’re mixing up names. Who’re you talking about?”

“You’ve known him for six years,” I said. “He literally introduced us. He spilled beer on you at that terrible poetry night—”

“Dude, I met you through Jess,” he said. “At her old job. Are you high?”

I put him on speaker, scrolled up through our group chat: “The Disaster Coven.” It used to be the four of us.

Now it was three.

Every thread I remembered with Noah’s sarcasm, Noah’s badly timed jokes, was rearranged: my replies now talking to no one, or not there at all. The flow of conversations seamless, as if he’d never been part of them.

I hung up on Micah.

Panic is slow at first. A drip. Then the realization turns the faucet all the way open. I sat on a bench because my legs wouldn’t hold me.

I tried my sister. “Hey,” she said. “Everything okay?”

“Do you remember Noah?”

“Noah who?”

I stared at the pigeons pecking at crumbs. “Tall, curly hair, I brought him to Mom’s last Thanksgiving. He dropped the turkey. Mom almost killed him.”

“We didn’t have anyone extra last year,” she said carefully. “You carved the turkey yourself. Remember?”

“I can send pictures,” I said.

“I’ve got pictures,” she said. “You’re the only idiot holding the knife.”

She texted one.

In it, I’m grinning with exaggerated concentration at the turkey. No one next to me. No curly-haired nuisance knocking things over.

I didn’t answer her. I didn’t answer anyone. I just sat there, world tilting, questions spinning:

Brain tumor? Psychotic break? Elaborate prank?

At home, I pulled out the box.

The one with the polaroids, ticket stubs, notes he’d scribbled and crumpled up. The one Noah had once called “physical proof we exist.”

Inside:

• Ticket to the concert we’d gone to together. Only one, with my seat circled.
• A polaroid of me on the hood of my car, hand outstretched toward an awkward gap.
• A sticky note in my handwriting: “Next time answer your damn phone — N.” Except the dash was faint. The N looked like a smudge.

Everything that was him had been edited, like reality had done a sloppy Photoshop job and hoped I wouldn’t zoom in.

But I remembered.

The stupid way he’d hum when he was thinking.
His chipped front tooth.
The way he’d say, “If I vanish, you better notice.”

The thought hit with enough force to rock me: What if this wasn’t forgetfulness, but removal?

My phone buzzed.

Unknown number.

I almost didn’t answer. But the world had already tipped off its axis. I had nothing left to lose.

I opened the text.

5 words.

“YOU WERE SUPPOSED TO FORGET.”

I didn’t scream right away.

At first, my mind snagged on the wrong thing: the capitalization, the lack of punctuation. The way the words didn’t fit any scam script, any mundane explanation.

Then it was like all the air in the room reversed directions.

The phone slid from my hand onto the floor with a crack. My heart hammered so hard it hurt.

I heard myself make a sound—half gasp, half sob, half animal.

Supposed to.

Not accidentally didn’t. Not mysteriously couldn’t. Supposed to.

Someone had done this.

Someone knew.

I snatched the phone up again, fingers clumsy. I typed:

Who is this?

No response.

I typed faster.

Where is Noah?
What did you do?
WHO ARE YOU?

Three dots appeared.

Then vanished.

Three dots again.

Vanish.

Finally: “This is a problem.”

I stared. My reflection blinked back at me in the dark screen while the conversation hung there, a thin thread suspending me between dread and something worse.

I typed: Who are you?

This time, the answer came quicker.

“Not here. Not supposed. Don’t remember.”

I read it three times, each pass making less sense. Or too much.

“I DO remember,” I wrote. “I remember everything. You erased him. Why?”

Nothing.

Minutes crawled. My apartment ticked and hummed. Someone upstairs walked across their floor like a metronome. My breathing sounded too loud.

A new message arrived.

“Stop looking. Please.”

Something about the “please” chilled me more than any threat.

“What happens if I don’t?” I asked.

This time the dots didn’t hesitate.

“He goes again.”

I swallowed. My throat was sand.

“Again?”

“You’re not the first,” the reply said. “You weren’t meant to keep him.”

A pressure built behind my eyes. My hands went cold.

I scrolled up to the first message: YOU WERE SUPPOSED TO FORGET.

The words rearranged themselves in my head, overlaying every glitch, every absence. There was a shape here. A pattern.

Not delusion.

Design.

I typed with stiff fingers: Who is he?

For a long time, nothing.

I thought they were done, that whoever or whatever was on the other end had decided silence was safer. I imagined them pulling strings I couldn’t see, closing doors I didn’t know existed.

Then: “Wrong place. Wrong time. Wrong world.”

The room felt smaller. The edges of everything too sharp.

“He doesn’t belong,” they added. “He was here by mistake. We fixed it. You were supposed to forget.”

I squeezed the phone so hard my knuckles ached. The images came in flashes: Noah’s lopsided grin. His way of appearing when I needed him most, like he’d known before I did. His offhand jokes about “where I’m really from.” Me laughing them off.

“What if I don’t let him go?” I whispered, then forced my thumbs to move. “Bring him back.”

No answer.

“Bring. Him. Back.”

The dots appeared one last time.

“He’s safer if you don’t.”

I stared, waiting.

There were no more messages.

Outside, a siren wailed and faded. A dog barked twice.

I looked down at the open box of almost-proof, the photos bending light around someone no one else remembered, and thought of the first time Noah had looked at me and said, very softly, “Thank you for seeing me.”

I’d rolled my eyes then. Told him he was being dramatic.

Now I understood.

You were supposed to forget.

I didn’t.

And somewhere, because I remembered, something had noticed.

samples.prompt: "Baby, did it hurt when you fell from heaven?"Her eyes swiveled to mine in panic and her eyes flashed golden briefly, and asked with a shocked and slightly apprehensive expression "How did you know about that?"
samples.output:
“Baby, did it hurt when you fell from heaven?”

I meant it as a joke. A stupid, tired-line-at-midnight kind of joke, tossed across the bar like a paper airplane I didn’t expect to land.

But her eyes snapped to mine as if I’d pulled a gun.

The low amber bar light caught in them—and then, for a heartbeat, shifted. Gold. Not metaphorical golden-brown, not the warm hazel that poets are always raving about. Gold. Metallic, sharp, luminous. Wrong.

Her expression crumpled into shock, the ice tinkling against the side of her glass as her fingers tensed.

“How did you know about that?” she whispered.

The noise of the bar rushed around us: laughter, clinking glasses, the dull thump of music. But the world between us went vacuum-still.

I swallowed. “Know about… what? It’s just a line.”

“People don’t ‘just’ say that to me,” she said. She leaned in, gaze flicking over my face like she was scanning for something. “Say it again.”

“Uh.” I huffed out a laugh. “It’s not that good of a line.”

“Say it again.”

I did. “Did it hurt when you fell from heaven?”

The gold flashed again. This time it lingered, turning her irises into molten coins. She flinched, raised a hand as though to cover her eyes, then seemed to remember herself and dropped it.

“Okay,” she murmured. “Okay. That’s… not ideal.”

I looked at my drink, then back at her. “Is this—are you messing with me?”

“I could ask you the same thing.” Her voice had steadied. She studied me like I was a chess problem with too few pieces on the board. “Why did you say that line?”

“Because I have no game and Google is free, I don’t know.” I felt defensive, heat crawling up my neck. “I always thought it was cheesy and funny, and you looked like you needed to laugh. You’ve been staring at that gin like it insulted your ancestors.”

Her lips twitched. “It did, actually. Long story.” A pause. “You said it without anyone suggesting it?”

“I… yes? I wasn’t prompted by the divine, if that’s what you’re asking.”

She winced. “Please don’t say ‘divine’ so loud.”

I blinked. “You’re serious.”

“Yes.” Her fingers traced the stem of her glass in slow, neat circles. “And we probably shouldn’t talk here.”

I glanced around. The bartender was arguing good-naturedly with some regular, the couple at the end was busy trying to see how far they could crawl into each other’s mouths. No one cared about us.

“We’re in a crowded bar,” I said. “This is literally the safest place to say weird things. That’s why cults recruit in coffee shops.”

“That’s a myth,” she said absentmindedly. “Mostly.”

The gold in her eyes had dulled to specks, like glitter dusted in hazel. But now that I’d seen it, I couldn’t unsee it.

“What are you?” I asked, trying for playful and missing.

She grimaced. “Rude.”

“I mean, are you human? Is this a—what is this?”

“I was,” she said. “Human. Once. A long time ago.”

The urge to run my mouth outweighed the urge to shut up. “And then you got promoted?”

She huffed a laugh that sounded involuntary. “Something like that.”

“You’re an angel.”

“That’s a simplistic term,” she said, finishing her drink. “But close enough.”

I stared at her. At the worn leather jacket, the chipped black nail polish, the faint scar along her jaw, the grocery store name tag clipped to her bag that read MIA in block letters.

“Right,” I said. “Okay. So. If I’m hallucinating, this is at least on-brand for my sense of humor.”

“You’re not hallucinating.”

“Yeah, that’s what a hallucination would say.”

She tilted her head and looked at me—really looked, like she could see each thought form and crumble. “When you were eight, you almost drowned in Lake Silver. You told everyone you slipped. You didn’t slip. The current caught your foot on a rock. You still have the scar on your left ankle.”

My throat closed. Nobody knew that. I’d told people I tripped. I didn’t like thinking about the water closing over my head, the silence, the sudden hand on my ankle—

I pulled my left foot back under the bar stool like I could hide it.

“You,” I said slowly, “were the lifeguard.”

She raised a brow. “I was the storm cloud.”

I stared. “That’s not—”

“The current was too strong to pull you out in time,” she said. “So I calmed it. Nudged a branch loose so it drifted your way. The boy who grabbed you thinks it was his idea. It’s better that way.”

My heart galloped. “Or this is a very elaborate gaslighting attempt.”

“Who uses the sentence ‘very elaborate gaslighting attempt’ in casual conversation?” she muttered. “You’re insufferable.”

She slid off the stool. “Walk with me.”

I hesitated. Her hand brushed my wrist, just the barest touch.

Warm. Too warm. Like sunlight behind thick glass.

That decided it.

Outside, the air was cold and smelled like rain that couldn’t commit. The neon sign above the bar sputtered. She led me down the side street, past dumpsters and a flickering streetlight, until the sounds of the bar thinned.

“Okay,” I said, shoving my hands in my pockets. “Explain. Preferably in a way that doesn’t end with men in suits dragging me into a van.”

“I wouldn’t let them,” she said.

“You’re one of them.”

“That’s complicated.”

“Try me.”

We stopped under the useless streetlight. She looked up at it, then flicked her fingers almost imperceptibly. The light steadied, buzzing into a clear, constant glow.

I stared at the bulb. “Neat trick.”

“Gravity, electromagnetism, entropy,” she said. “All negotiable, in small amounts. They’re rules, but they’re rules with clauses. Angels are the legal team.”

I barked a surprised laugh. “You’re telling me cosmic lawyers are real.”

She smirked. “You’d be amazed how much of existence is paperwork.”

“And you… fell from heaven?”

Her jaw tightened. “Yes.”

“How?”

“Badly.” She shrugged, but it looked forced. “Disobedience. There was an order. I disagreed. They demoted me. Falling is messy; it rearranges you. Now I’m halfway. Not fully bound up there, not fully free down here.”

“Like a probation officer with wings.”

“I don’t have wings anymore,” she said softly. “That’s part of the point.”

Something in her voice made me stop joking.

“What did you disagree about?” I asked more gently.

She looked at me for a long time before answering. “About you.”

The word hung there, ridiculous and heavy.

“Me specifically?”

“Not just you.” She exhaled. “Your kind. Humans. There was a plan. A correction. Numbers on a ledger. You’re messy, disobedient, cruel, brilliant, exhausting. They wanted to… simplify. I argued that you deserved the consequences and triumphs you’d sown. That love wasn’t a rounding error. That free will was the project, not a bug.”

“And they kicked you out for that,” I said.

“They don’t like being contradicted.” The corner of her mouth twitched. “I overdid it. There was shouting. Some… unwise metaphors. Swords. It’s dramatic up there.”

“So they made you human.”

“They made me fall,” she said. “Stripped rank. Cut ties. Left enough of the old in me to hurt.”

“And then you got a job at the grocery store.”

“Rent doesn’t pay itself.”

I studied her; the faint dark circles, the tightness around her mouth, the way she flinched when someone inside dropped a glass.

“And my sad little pickup line freaked you out because…?”

“Because they’re not supposed to see me,” she said. “Fallen, exiled, whatever label—people don’t know. Your minds slide off. It’s a protection: for you and for us. The phrase ‘fell from heaven’ is—was—flagged. An internal keyword.” She grimaced. “If anyone who’s not part of the system says it directly to my face, and means it, the glamour should hold. It did for years. Then you said it and it… glitched. You saw.”

I felt suddenly cold. “Glitched how?”

“The wards slipped,” she said. “You saw my eyes. That means you’re keyed in. Which means either I’m unraveling, or someone up there is paying attention to both of us.”

“Oh,” I said faintly. “Cool. Super cool. Love that for me.”

She stepped closer. The air warmed again. “I’m sorry. I didn’t expect this. I’ve been careful.”

“Why me?” It came out smaller than I wanted. “I’m a bartender with student debt and a dying car. I’m not the Chosen Anything.”

“Good,” she said. “Chosen Ones are insufferable.”

Despite everything, I snorted.

She hesitated, then reached out, touching the scar on my ankle through denim like she could see it. The warmth pulsed, and for an instant, the memory of the lake surfaced: murky green, burning lungs, a sudden stillness in the water as if a hand had smoothed it.

“I argued for you,” she murmured. “You, specifically. At your ledger hearing.”

“My what.”

“Everyone has one.” Her hand dropped. “Snapshots of your potential, probabilities. They wanted you in column B. Collateral. You weren’t statistically significant enough to protect.”

“Wow,” I said. “Rude of the cosmos.”

“I said you mattered.” She gave a little helpless shrug. “That you were kind when nobody was looking. That you tried even when it hurt. That you’d hold open doors and bite your tongue and make one ridiculous kid at a bar go home feeling seen instead of invisible. They said I was sentimental. They were right. I fell. You lived.”

The streetlight hummed. My heart did something complicated.

“You fell for me,” I said, then immediately winced. “Oh God, sorry, that came out—”

“I did,” she said calmly.

I shut up.

“That’s why your line wasn’t funny,” she went on. “It was accurate. And accuracy has consequences.”

I stared at her, at the person who was apparently exiled cosmic middle management turned grocery clerk because she argued that some nobody in Lake Silver did not deserve to become a statistic.

“If I walk away right now,” I said quietly, “what happens?”

“You go home,” she said. “You think about this too much for a week. You decide it was either a weird night or some intricate prank. You live. I keep my head down. Maybe they never notice the glitch.”

“And if I don’t walk away?”

She chewed her lip. “Then I have to decide whether to run with you, or to stand between you and them. Again. And they’re less patient a second time.”

“I don’t want you hurt because of me. Again,” I said.

She smiled, a quick, radiant thing that made the streetlight seem dull. “You don’t get to decide all the variables, you know.”

“I can choose whether to be a variable at all.”

“You already are,” she said. “You always were. That’s the point.”

A gust of wind rattled a loose sign. Somewhere, a siren wailed. The world was big and ordinary and terrifying.

“You fell from heaven to argue I should get to live a normal, unimpressive life,” I said. “That’s… the most beautiful and depressing thing I’ve ever heard.”

“You underestimate unimpressive lives,” she said. “They’re where most of the good happens.”

I took a breath that felt like jumping.

“Okay,” I said. “Then let’s do something unimpressive. Come back inside. I’ll buy you another terrible gin, and you can tell me more about celestial paperwork. We can pretend I’m not a variable.”

She searched my face, like there might be a right answer hidden there.

“That’s dangerous,” she said.

“Is it worth it?”

Her eyes flickered—brown, then molten gold, then brown again. She looked suddenly, achingly young.

“Yes,” she said.

“Then I guess you’re not the only sentimental one,” I replied.

She laughed, soft and incredulous, and let me lead her back toward the noise and the neon, both of us pretending, for now, that heaven wasn’t watching.

samples.prompt: The UK is being battered by a major storm. Write the story of someone desperately trying to make it home from work during the chaos.
samples.output:
By the time Amelia shut down her computer, the office windows were rattling in their frames.

“Go now,” her manager had said, hovering with a frown by the door. “They’re saying it’s only going to get worse.”

She’d nodded, tugged her coat on, stuffed her laptop into her bag. The emergency alerts had been going off all afternoon, but the software deployment hadn’t cared about the weather, and neither had the director in London on the video call. Now, as she stepped out into the corridor, the building’s fluorescent lights flickered once, as if reconsidering their own commitment.

On the ground floor, the revolving door fought her. The wind shoved from the outside, stalling the glass panels so she had to push with both hands to wedge herself through. Then the storm hit her like a wall.

Rain came sideways, thick and needling against her cheeks. The sky was an early, bruised twilight, clouds boiled up and churning. She clamped her hood down with one hand and squinted toward the road, where red tail lights glowed in a long line, unmoving.

A police car’s blue strobes pulsed against the slick pavement. A yellow-suited officer stood at the corner, shouting over the wind: “A406 is closed! Fallen power lines. Avoid all non-essential travel!”

She hesitated. Non-essential. Her brain flickered to an image: her flat, the sagging plant in the kitchen window, the dinosaur-print pyjamas waiting in the drawer, and Noah’s face—four and stubborn, likely standing on the sofa right now, glaring at the storm as if he could shout it away.

Essential, she thought.

She thumbed her phone awake. One bar. The screen wet instantly, raindrops registering as ghost taps.

Mum had texted ten minutes earlier: Still no trains. He’s asking for you. We’re fine. Just get here safe. x

Safe. The word felt both laughable and heavy. She typed back, On my way. Phone died with a sudden blank screen. She swore softly.

The car park was chaos. People clustered by their vehicles, phones in hand, doors slamming. The security guard was waving his arms and trying to shout directions that dissolved in the howling gusts. A wheelie bin cartwheeled past, sparks shooting as it clipped a low wall.

Her little blue Honda sat in the far corner, rocking slightly as a gust hit. Amelia yanked open the door, threw herself in, and slammed it shut. The sound muted, but the car shuddered again. She sat there for a second, breaths shallow, staring at the raindrops streaming like silver threads down the glass.

Engine on. Demister on. Wipers thrashing. Radio: a crackle of static, then a clipped, urgent presenter.

“…Met Office upgrading to red warning for wind in London and the South East. Sustained gusts of eighty to ninety miles per hour in coastal and exposed areas, with risk of structural damage. All rail services are suspended. Motorists are advised—”

She turned it down, her pulse already throbbing in her ears.

If the A406 was closed, she’d have to cut through the side roads, zigzag north, then east, make her way to her mum’s estate where Noah was waiting. Under normal conditions: forty minutes. Now? The question sat there, unanswered.

She pulled out, joining the snake of cars trying to leave the business park. Traffic lights at the junction swung wildly on their cables, lenses smeared by rain. Branches scraped along the tarmac like skeletal fingers.

The line inched forward. Ahead, the reflection of blue lights smeared across wet glass and metal. A lorry had jackknifed somewhere on the main road; word spread backward from car to car, shoulders shrugging, hands waving.

She checked her dead phone again, as if it might change its mind. Nothing.

Come on. She eased out of the queue, drawing angrier honks as she indicated and pushed toward the side street. The little Honda’s tyres sloshed through water pooling where the drains couldn’t cope. She turned left, then right, working off memory, a mental map drawn from years of late buses and long walks.

Outside, trees bowed, twisted. A security shutter tore loose from a shopfront and slammed against brick with a metallic scream. A billboard peeled back like paper. She gripped the wheel tighter.

A flash of movement—something big, dark—shot across the road ahead. She slammed the brakes. A wheelie bin, empty, took flight and smacked into her front bumper before tumbling on, leaving behind a dent and a smear of black plastic.

“Fantastic,” she muttered.

The road narrowed. Terraced houses hunched close together, curtains drawn against the storm. In one window, a TV glowed blue, flickering as the power fought to hold. A tree branch lay across part of the lane, forcing her to mount the curb to get around it.

It was only when she hit the standing water that she realized how deep it was.

The car plunged, waves lapping up over the bonnet. The engine coughed.

“No. No, no, no.”

She didn’t dare stop. She eased the accelerator, coaxing. The Honda crawled through, water sloshing, then climbed up onto higher ground. The engine’s protest smoothed out.

“Good girl,” she whispered, like she used to when it over-revved on hills.

Another mile. Then the high street, normally jammed with buses. Now: eerily sparse. A single double-decker stood parked at an angle, hazard lights blinking, driver on his phone under the shelter of a doorway. Behind it, a tangle of fallen scaffolding blocked the road. Orange poles, twisted mesh, boards.

Amelia slowed. There was no way through.

She pulled into a loading bay, brain racing. The diversion would take her south, away from home, eat precious time. Out there, the storm howled around the car, making it wobble on its suspension.

He’s asking for you.

She saw the blue Lego spaceman Noah never went to bed without. The way he’d waved it at her that morning as she’d wrestled her shoes on, already late. “Come back before dark,” he’d said, dramatic. “Or the monsters come.”

“I’ll always come back,” she’d promised, kissing his curls.

Now darkness was coming early and hard.

She killed the engine.

The quiet was not really quiet at all. The storm filled it completely—wind shrieking along the street, signs clanging, something metallic tumbling out of sight. But inside the car, the decision arrived, solid and simple.

Drive around, risk floodwater and blocked roads, or admit what she already knew from the train alerts and the news ticker and the overturned bins: the city was coming apart. The car, low and old, was as much a liability as a lifeline.

She grabbed her bag, shoved the door open against the wind, and stepped straight into a puddle deep enough to flood her shoes. Cold knifed up her legs.

She locked the car out of habit. Ridiculous. It felt like locking a paper crane.

Head down, shoulders hunched, she pushed forward. The rain was icy now, biting. The wind tried to rip her hood back, so she clamped it down, fingers numb. Streetlights swayed. Somewhere, glass exploded in a crystalline crash.

Her usual twenty-minute bus ride became a fifty-minute walk on a good day. Tonight, who knew.

The first obstacle was the underpass by the retail park. Water churned down the ramp in a brown torrent. A car halfway through sat abandoned, hazard lights blinking, water halfway up its doors.

No chance.

She doubled back, lungs burning with the cold air and effort, and cut across the retail park instead. The big superstore’s automatic doors flapped uselessly. A handful of people clustered under the overhang, faces pinched and pale blue in the emergency lighting. She caught fragments: “roof’s gone at the depot,” “M25 shut,” “they’re saying stay put.”

“Excuse me,” she shouted to no one in particular, “is the footbridge open?”

A security guard, rain dripping off his nose, shrugged. “Far as I know. You shouldn’t be out, love.”

“Got to get to my son,” she said, more sharply than she meant.

He hesitated, then nodded, stepping aside. “Watch the signs. They’re coming off.”

She ran. The wind roared under the exposed steel of the bridge, turning it into an instrument. The metal grates flexed under her boots. Below, the main road was a frozen river of red lights and scattered debris.

Halfway across, a gust hit so hard she staggered. For a second, her foot skidded on the slick grate, and the rail pressed against her ribs as she lurched. Adrenaline flashed white-hot; she clung on, panting, forcing herself not to look down, not to imagine the news headline.

Move.

On the far side, buildings crouched lower: post-war estates, peeling paint. Litter whipped in circles. A wheelbarrow rolled past on its side. Tiles had come down from a nearby roof, lying shattered on the pavement.

The rain eased for a moment, as if the storm was inhaling before another howl. In the lull, a sound reached her: sirens, distant but constant.

Her legs ached. Her socks were soaked, toes numb. She shoved a wet curl out of her eyes with the back of her hand, left a streak of grit. The sky flickered; for a heartbeat, she thought it was lightning, but it was transformers blowing blue somewhere distant.

Two streets from Mum’s. Almost there.

She turned the corner and stopped.

A tree—one of the old plane trees that lined the road—had come down, roots ripped from the earth, blocking most of the street. Its branches tangled with a parked car, alarms shrilling a thin, continuous wail. The only way past was to climb.

She slung her bag across her back, grabbed a low branch, hauled herself up. Bark slick under her fingers, her trainers slipping. She straddled the trunk inelegantly, scraped her shin, and jumped down on the far side, landing hard enough that pain jarred up her spine.

“Keep going,” she told herself, out loud now. Her voice was swallowed, but it steadied her.

Mum’s building loomed ahead, blocky and familiar. Some windows glowed. Others were black, curtains pale in the dark. The communal door was propped open with a brick, swinging a little.

Inside, the stairwell smelled of damp and someone’s overcooked dinner. The emergency lights buzzed.

“Amelia?” Her mum’s voice floated down before she’d reached the second floor. Feet on the landing. A small shape barreling past her.

“Mummy!”

Noah collided with her so hard she stumbled back against the banister. She dropped her bag and wrapped herself around him, burying her face in his damp curls, breathing in the warm, milky scent under the faint smell of crisps. He was solid and alive and clinging to her as if the wind might steal him.

“You came back,” he said into her shoulder, voice wobbly.

“Of course I did,” she murmured, pulling him closer. Behind him, Mum’s eyes shone with relief and reprimand. Another gust rattled the stairwell windows, the storm still raging beyond the concrete walls.

Amelia shut her eyes for a second, holding her son as the building shivered.

Outside, the city bent under the storm.

Inside, she was home.
